Article_Name: 2018年8月下旬臺灣暴雨 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The late August 2018 Taiwan heavy rain refers to the natural disaster caused by intense rainfall from August 23 to August 30, 2018, due to the convergence of a tropical depression and the southwest monsoon, as well as the subsequent development of a large low-pressure zone lingering over South China after the system dissipated, which brought further southwest airflow. Areas such as Yunlin, Chiayi, Nantou, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung experienced widespread flooding, with some localized areas remaining flooded for nearly a week. It was the most severe and prolonged catastrophic heavy rain to affect Taiwan since the Typhoon Morakot disaster. President Tsai Ing-wen of the Republic of China specifically instructed Presidential Office Secretary-General Chen Chu to stay in Kaohsiung to oversee disaster response efforts in southern Taiwan.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation pointed out on the 25th that Taiwan is within a low-pressure zone, influenced by the low-pressure zone and southwesterly airflow, which contributed to this heavy rain event. The Weather Bureau also continued to issue land strong wind warnings and heavy rain warnings for certain areas, reminding the public of potential landslides, falling rocks, debris flows, flash floods, and flooding before the southwesterly airflow affected Taiwan. The Weather Risk Management Development Company stated that compared to the impact of the previous tropical depression, the rainfall brought by this heavy rain event was relatively moderate. The Central Disaster Response Center, established in response to the tropical depression, was dismantled at 7 PM on the 25th and reopened three hours later to address this heavy rain event. Premier Lai Ching-te inspected the Central Disaster Response Center on the 28th and emphasized the importance of strengthening horizontal communication between ministries and vertical cooperation with local governments to help residents return home as soon as possible.  

Due to the continued impact of heavy rain, the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation issued an extremely heavy rain warning for Pingtung County on the evening of the 27th and heavy rain warnings for Tainan City, Kaohsiung City, and Taitung County. The extremely heavy rain warning was extended to Kaohsiung City the following day. The Soil and Water Conservation Bureau of the Council of Agriculture also issued 42 red alerts for debris flows on the morning of the 28th, covering 6 townships and 15 villages in Kaohsiung and Pingtung, and 166 yellow alerts for areas including Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung, and Taitung. They stated that local governments should advise or force residents to evacuate and provide proper resettlement. The Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs issued a level-one flood warning for 13 districts in Kaohsiung City and 5 townships in Pingtung County.

Affected by the heavy rain event, the Kaohsiung City Government stated that the city has emptied all detention basins and artificial lakes to facilitate water storage and established a Level 1 Disaster Response Center at 6:30 PM that evening. The Agriculture and Food Agency of the Council of Agriculture called on farmers to harvest crops that are ready for harvest in a timely manner to reduce losses. The Fisheries Agency of the Council of Agriculture also urged fishermen to take advantage of breaks in the rain to implement disaster prevention measures. The Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs issued a Level 1 flood warning at 6:27 AM on the 28th for 13 districts in Kaohsiung City and 5 towns in Pingtung County.

The Xiaoliuqiu to Donggang ferry route was also affected by the heavy rain event, with reduced services on the 26th and suspension on the 27th. By noon on the 26th, a total of 2,500 people had rushed back to Donggang. Ferries from Taitung to Lanyu and Green Island were also suspended on the 27th, leaving nearly 4,000 tourists stranded. The Maritime and Port Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications stated that due to the heavy rain event, an estimated 58 ferry trips were canceled on the 28th.

The Southern Region Water Resources Office of the Water Resources Agency pointed out that in response to the second wave of heavy rain, Zengwen Reservoir and Mudan Reservoir were both subjected to regulated discharges on the morning of the 27th. It also stated that Agongdian Reservoir is currently in an empty reservoir period for sediment prevention. To prepare for the potential rainfall brought by this wave of heavy rain, the Southern Region Water Resources Office conducted regulated water releases to reserve flood detention space.

This southwest airflow brought heavy rain to Pingtung County, with Xinyuan Township recording over 300 millimeters of rainfall from midnight to 11:30 a.m. on August 28, ranking first in Taiwan. On the same day, Kaohsiung City also recorded over 300 millimeters of daily rainfall. The intense rainfall caused slippery roads in many areas, leading to multiple traffic accidents. In Xinyuan Township, Pingtung County, a car crashed into a utility pole, resulting in one death and three injuries. In Zhuqi Township, Chiayi County, a small car collision, possibly due to slippery roads and poor visibility caused by the rain, resulted in one death and one serious injury. On the 26th, the Pingtung County Police Department reported that a 64-year-old man went to Haishen Temple in Sandimen Township but was found missing after his car door was left open and the right rear wheel was stuck in the riverbed, marking the first missing person case in this heavy rain event.

The heavy rain also affected provincial highways. At the 260-kilometer mark of the Taiwan Route 17 in Qianzai Kou, water accumulation exceeded 20 centimeters and stretched over 100 meters. The Third Engineering Office of the Directorate General of Highways implemented road closures on the morning of the 26th. According to the Pingtung County Disaster Response Center, the Wutan section of Ping 106 in Taiwu Township was preemptively closed due to landslide risks. On the 1-kilometer mark of Route 200A in Manzhou Township, landslides obstructed road drainage, leading to controlled traffic. Additionally, the drainage system on the Fangliao section of Taiwan Route 1 was overwhelmed, causing about 20 centimeters of water accumulation on the road.

Whole_Text.header: Announce the suspension of work and classes controversy

Whole_Text.content: Pingtung County Magistrate Pan Meng-an stated on the evening of the 26th that Pingtung County, based on the Central Weather Bureau's forecast, announced the suspension of work and classes on the 27th. At the same time, it also became one of the counties and cities in the 2018 Republic of China local public office elections to stop accepting candidate registrations. This move was questioned by netizens regarding the standards for declaring a holiday in Pingtung County. Pingtung County Government Personnel Office Director Li Yin-ming emphasized that the weather forecast had reached the standard for suspending work and classes and stated that the top ten rainfall amounts on that day were all within Pingtung County. On the evening of the 27th, the Pingtung County Government announced that a landslide occurred in Shiwen Village and a collapse on County Road 146, causing traffic disruptions. Therefore, only Shiwen Village in Chunri Township, Pingtung County, would suspend work and classes on the 28th. The next day, heavy rain continued to fall in Pingtung County, with daily rainfall in several towns exceeding 200 millimeters. Severe traffic congestion occurred on the Linluo section of Provincial Highway 1 due to water accumulation, and flooding was reported on Guangfu Road near Pingtung Station and Fuxing South Road in Pingtung City, leading residents to question the county government's decision-making. Pingtung residents pointed out that the rainfall in Pingtung was no less than that in Kaohsiung, yet Pingtung County had normal work and classes on the 28th. They further stated that the Pingtung County Government should prioritize the safety of its residents. Pingtung County Government spokesperson Huang Jian-jia apologized in the afternoon, explaining that the rain was concentrated in a few towns and that widespread flooding had not occurred in the early morning.

The Kaohsiung City Government stated on the evening of the 26th that, based on rainfall observation data released by the Central Weather Bureau, work and classes in Kaohsiung City would proceed as usual on the 27th. However, netizens discovered that Acting Mayor Hsu Li-ming had mistakenly posted the quantitative precipitation forecast from the Weather Bureau and subsequently deleted the post. In response, the Kaohsiung City Government explained that the previous post was deleted due to an error and not intentionally removed. From the evening of the 27th to the early morning of the 28th, heavy rainfall continued in Kaohsiung City. The Kaohsiung Weather Station of the Weather Bureau also issued a late-night reminder that heavy rainfall radar echoes had entered the Kaohsiung area, urging the public to take disaster prevention measures. Acting Mayor Hsu Li-ming urgently announced at 6 a.m. on the 28th that work and classes would be suspended that day, prompting public outrage with comments such as "You announce it after we've already left home" and "Can I call for a boat on Uber?" This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the public. In response, Hsu Li-ming apologized on Facebook, while his staff noted that he had stayed up all night monitoring the flooding situation.

On August 24, while the entire nation was busy with disaster relief, Vice President of the Republic of China, Chen Chien-jen, took his whole family to Kinmen for a three-day, two-night vacation, visiting major attractions in both Greater and Lesser Kinmen. He was accompanied by twelve bodyguards, and nearly twenty plainclothes police officers from the Kinmen County Police Bureau were deployed for full-time protection. This incident caused public criticism and negative perception, with Kinmen County legislator Yang Cheng-wu blasting, "He doesn't come when he should, but comes when he shouldn't." Presidential Office spokesperson Alex Huang stated that as a member of the government team, causing negative public perception and criticism of the team, Vice President Chen expressed deep regret and apologized to the public. This incident was compared by the public to former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan getting a haircut before Typhoon Morakot and Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Hsueh Hsiang-chuan eating sweet potato porridge with his father-in-law after overtime, which led to their resignations under heavy criticism from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), presenting a stark contrast.

On August 25, 2018, President Tsai Ing-wen of the Republic of China, accompanied by Chiayi County Magistrate Helen Chang, rode a Clouded Leopard armored vehicle to inspect Budai Township. Smiling, she encouraged disaster victims to stay strong. However, after traveling only about 50 meters, the vehicle was stopped by local residents who angrily shouted, "If you drive further, just run me over!" Kuomintang (KMT) spokesperson Hung Meng-kai harshly criticized on Facebook, calling it "the most arrogant disaster inspection in history," and likened Tsai Ing-wen to a "beauty queen on a parade float." Citizens also vented their anger on Facebook, saying, "Disaster inspection? You won't even step into the water for a show. Riding a Clouded Leopard is bad enough, but can't you at least pretend to be solemn or reflective? What's with the smile? And waving? Are you here to thank voters or campaign? Are you sure you're not on the wrong set?" Many public figures criticized the incident, with Chu Hsueh-heng condemning Tsai Ing-wen for smiling and waving from multiple angles and times, saying, "Her smile sends chills down your spine." Chu remarked that Tsai used to hold others to strict standards, but now that she's being held to the same standards, it's only fair. "If karma strikes, let it strike. Is it so hard not to have double standards?" Hu You-wei commented that the incident occurred in Yong'an Village, symbolizing that Tsai can no longer "be at peace forever." He humorously expressed Tsai's sentiments, saying, "Whoever came up with the bad idea of having the emperor ride a Clouded Leopard armored vehicle for disaster inspection, send them to the Ministry of Punishments for 80 lashes and then to the labor camp to scrub toilets." Chang San-cheng pointed out, "Because they can't feel empathy, the people have been soaking in water for days, and they hope high-ranking officials can understand their pain. But instead, they see President Tsai riding an armored vehicle, 'high above them'!" He criticized Tsai for failing to "share the people's suffering" and lamented, "With a president like this, I truly feel sorrow for our country."

Chiu Yi-ying criticized Kuomintang Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Han Kuo-yu for attending a campaign song release event for a city council candidate, saying, "Kaohsiung people don't need a mayoral candidate like this!" Subsequently, on August 26, Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker Tsai Chi-chang led legislators Lee Chun-yi, Ho Hsin-chun, Chiu Yi-ying, Lin Ching-yi, Lee Li-fen, Chou Chun-mi, and Chang Liao Wan-chien on a visit to Poland's parliament. This sparked controversy, as some questioned the appropriateness of the visit while flood disaster relief in affected areas was still incomplete.

On August 28, 2018, Legislative Yuan Speaker Su Jia-chyuan was spotted in Japan by the public, raising suspicions that he was on a leisure trip. Legislative Yuan Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia stated that Su was invited by the Japanese government for an official visit, accompanied by his wife. However, due to concerns about Taiwan's disaster situation, Su returned to Taiwan early that day.

Article_Name: Aiguat del 9 d'octubre de 2018 a Mallorca - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood of October 9, 2018, in Mallorca was an episode of heavy rainfall that occurred on October 9, 2018, and affected the municipalities of Artà, Sant Llorenç des Cardassar, and Manacor in the eastern part of Mallorca. The flood caused 13 deaths and one missing person when more than 200 l/m² of rain fell in the ca n'Amer stream basin, leading to its overflow in several areas. According to an expert, the stream's flow equaled that of the Ebro River at the peak of the flood in Sant Llorenç. The greatest damage occurred in the towns of Colònia de Sant Pere, Artà, Canyamel, Sant Llorenç des Cardassar, Son Carrió, and S'Illot. The fatalities included thirteen people: seven Spanish citizens (two women and five men), a British couple, a German couple, a Dutch woman, and a German journalist. The victims were found in Artà (4), Sant Llorenç (4), Son Carrió (2), and S'Illot (3).

Whole_Text.content: The flood in France in 2018 caused destruction in the Aude department in the Occitanie region of southwestern France.

The flood occurred on October 15–16, 2018, along the Aude River basin. At that time, the area received seven months' worth of rainfall in six hours, with a peak of 295 millimeters. The French meteorological agency issued a rare red warning for extremely dangerous weather in the Aude department, but not all local residents received the warning in time. The exceptional amount of rainfall caused rivers to flood instantly, water rose into houses, and cars were swept away. Several villages were isolated. According to France's flood monitoring agency Vigicrues, the country had not experienced such a severe flood since 1891. Heavy rains are common in the region in early autumn, but according to the French meteorological agency, the unusually high temperature of the Mediterranean may have intensified the rainfall. The summer of 2018 was the hottest in France's entire recorded history, dating back to 1900.

The town of Trèbes experienced particularly severe damage because it is located at the branch of the Aude River and its tributary, and additionally, the Canal du Midi passes through it. Furthermore, the villages of Conques-sur-Orbiel, Villegailhenc, and Villardonnel suffered significant damage. On Wednesday, October 17, it was reported that 13 people had died and thousands of people had been evacuated.

The 2018 Tunisia floods were floods that hit several areas in the Nabeul Governorate on September 22, 2018. They resulted in the death of 6 people and caused significant material damage, with rainfall reaching 204 mm.

The heavy rainfall began on September 22 at around 8:36 AM Tunis time and continued without interruption until 3:00 PM. As a result, the lower dam outlets in Nabeul were opened by the responsible authorities to reduce the accumulated silt. The water level rose to varying levels between 0.75 meters and 3.25 meters in the delegations of the governorate.

The floods claimed the lives of 6 people and the floodwaters negatively affected both unused and utilized fields, leading to the death of chickens and livestock of various kinds. The floods also caused damage to infrastructure, including roads, bridges, electrical poles, and railways. The floods also swept through more than 35 educational institutions distributed across 10 delegations, including Bou Argoub, Bir Bouregba, Takelsa, Soliman, Beni Khalled, Dar Chaabane El Fehri, Korba, El Mida, Menzel Bouzelfa, and Nabeul city.

Members of civil society, including youth, residents, and school and institute staff, contributed to cleaning facilities from mud and removing stagnant water. Additionally, the National Television Foundation organized what it called a "Telethon," lasting 14 hours of live broadcasting on Sunday, September 30, aiming to collect donations from anyone capable of contributing. The total donations, including current amounts and pledges, reached 9 million dinars.

Whole_Text.content: The Dabaa and Maleeh floods, or the November 9 floods, were floods and flash floods that occurred on the evening of Friday, November 9, 2018, in areas of southern and central Jordan, less than two weeks after the Dead Sea floods of 2018. The floods were concentrated in the Dabaa area on the Desert Highway, south of the capital Amman, and in Maleeh in Jordan. Videos shared by citizens on social media showed strong, muddy, sweeping floods hitting the areas of Maleeh, Al-Wala, and Wadi Hidan, while other footage showed thousands of foreign tourists trapped by water in the ancient city of Petra. The floods caused significant damage to infrastructure and soil erosion. The incident resulted in 12 deaths, including one of the divers involved in rescue operations, and 12 injuries. Additionally, about 3,804 tourists were evacuated, including 3,762 from the city of Petra. The Royal Court announced the lowering of the flag at its main entrance for three days in mourning for the victims.

Whole_Text.content: The bad weather in Liguria on October 29-30, 2018, is a series of atmospheric events that occurred during those days in Liguria, affecting a large part of the municipalities along the coasts of the Riviera di Ponente and Riviera di Levante, the regional capital, and the inland areas, as part of the wave of bad weather in Italy in October-November 2018.

The persistence of adverse weather phenomena for several days, following which the Civil Protection of the Liguria region had already issued yellow and orange weather alert warnings for the respective basins, led the same body to declare a maximum alert level (red alert) for the entire day of Monday, October 29, 2018, for basins B, C, D, and E, corresponding to the Genoese Riviera, part of the western Riviera, the central inland region, and the entire eastern Riviera. For basin A, which includes the stretch of the western Riviera between Ventimiglia and Noli, the entire province of Imperia, and the Centa Valley, the alert remained at yellow and orange levels. In the preceding days, violent torrential rain affected almost the entire Ligurian territory, with significant short-term water accumulations recorded—especially in the Genoese hinterland (upper Scrivia Valley, Trebbia Valley, and Bisagno Valley), Chiavari area (Aveto Valley, Fontanabuona Valley, and Sturla Valley), and the Spezzino area (Cinque Terre and Vara Valley)—and landslides, mudslides, and flooding in various municipalities. In addition to the intense rainfall, another source of danger was the strong gusts of wind (in some measurements in the eastern Liguria exceeding 100-120 km/h and, in the west, up to 180 km/h, as recorded by sensors at the Loano Marina) and the resulting storm surges, which, fueled by the wind's force, affected the entire Ligurian coastline, especially in the Savona, Genoa, and Tigullio areas. The wind was the cause of the death of the only victim of the bad weather: an 88-year-old woman from Albisola Superiore, struck by parts of a roof and cornice blown into the street by the violent and sudden atmospheric phenomenon, who later died at the Savona hospital from the severe injuries sustained. The combined action of the wind gusts and the sea's wave motion caused the most significant damage on October 29 and 30, both in the public and private sectors, during the entire emergency phase of the meteorological event. Violent waves, some as high as 7-10 meters (the maximum height, measured by instruments at the Capo Mele buoy in the Savona area, was 10.31 meters), violently struck the Savona and Genoa coasts, causing the near-total destruction of existing beach establishments (structures, outdoor areas, piers) and the erasure of entire stretches of sandy and pebbly beaches. An initial assessment by the local Italian beach operators' union, in the hours following the storm surge on October 29, estimated that out of approximately 1,300 equipped Ligurian beach establishments, about 100 were completely destroyed, and about 400 were seriously damaged, with damages amounting to at least 50 million euros. In the municipality of Genoa, in addition to monitoring the main Bisagno and Polcevera streams (the latter being a special focus following the collapse of the Morandi Bridge just over two months earlier), the violent storm surge caused damage along the entire Genoese coastline, from Voltri to Nervi. There were collapses of some sections of the Anita Garibaldi promenade in Nervi and devastation in the fishing village of Boccadasse and the private and public infrastructures of the Sturla, Pegli, and Voltri districts, with damages estimated at around 8 million euros. The sea's force also struck port infrastructures: particularly affected were the public port of Santa Margherita Ligure and the international tourist port "Carlo Riva" in Rapallo, with the collapse of their respective breakwaters. The sudden collapse of some sections of the retaining walls caused a consequent vulnerability of the ports themselves, as well as the coastal stretch of the two cities in western Tigullio, with flooding and damage to seafronts and commercial activities located there. In Santa Margherita Ligure, after the collapse of about 10 meters of the breakwater in a section renovated and reinforced with works completed in 2014, damages were recorded to port services and the local Coast Guard barracks, the sinking of boats, and flooding of the main road along the marina. Towards Portofino, the sea's fury caused the complete collapse of a section of the provincial road 227 near the Paraggi hamlet and severe damage to the structure of the famous nightclub Covo di Nord-Est. The road's collapse isolated Portofino from Santa Margherita Ligure—SP 227 being the only drivable artery serving Portofino—making the municipality accessible only by sea, with the help of boats and vessels, or by land via trails and forest paths on the namesake promontory. To address the emergency situation, the Portofino Park Authority and the administrations of Portofino and Santa Margherita Ligure authorized the semi-drivable adaptation (for two-wheeled vehicles and emergency vehicles) of some pedestrian forest paths, particularly the section between Portofino Vetta and Portofino Mare and between the Nozarego hamlet in Santa Margherita and the Gassetta Mill (known as the Gave trail). This intervention, due to some techniques considered too cementitious, was later contested by some environmental associations, followed by actual checks by the forest police; at the end of November of the same year, the park authority also halted work on the trail for the adaptation of the other path towards Portofino. On the provincial road section between Santa Margherita Ligure and Paraggi, a temporary overhanging pedestrian walkway was built between late November and early December 2018, initially used exclusively by local residents and later, during the Christmas period, opened to all pedestrians. Among the damages recorded in Portofino, besides the collapse of part of the central and famous "piazzetta" and the problems in connections with the centers of Santa Margherita Ligure, Rapallo, and the Golfo Paradiso, there was an interruption of electricity and gas services in the days following the event. In nearby Rapallo, on the night between October 29 and 30, the collapse of the breakwater, reinforced and expanded during the 2000s after a similar but less violent atmospheric phenomenon, caused major damages, with the sinking of numerous boats in the area between the public and private ports and, with the breaking of various moorings, the escape of hundreds of boats and yachts from the "Carlo Riva" port, which, adrift and at the mercy of the sea's wave motion, sank in the Rapallo Gulf or ran aground on the Vittorio Veneto seafront embankment and other areas to the west (Lido area and Boate stream mouth) and east of the city (San Francesco stream mouth area, near the local sea castle, and Nagge area). On the same night, 20 boaters trapped in their vessels within the marina due to the sea's fury were rescued by fire brigade teams. The grounding of boats, some of considerable size and owned by prominent individuals, indirectly caused a massive media phenomenon due to the event's exceptional nature and scale, with footage and television reports from various national and international broadcasters. Due to the stranded boats, the city suffered damages to several private accommodation facilities along the seafront (damaged in several places) and especially to beach establishments, with the semi-destruction of fixed structures and piers. Along the seafront, there were several problems related to environmental factors, such as the possible fuel leakage from various boats (for which anti-pollution cloths were quickly installed around the vessels); a huge amount of plastic, wood, and mixed waste was carried by the waves and scattered along the entire coastline, even completely clogging the stormwater drains. Compared to nearby Santa Margherita Ligure, which suffered more damage to public assets, the Rapallo area experienced the highest number of damages in the private sector, with the international tourist port "Carlo Riva" being the most affected. The port infrastructure, built in the 1970s and the first private tourist port in Italy, estimated damages to the structure at 10-15 million euros, and in November, a judicial investigation was opened by the Genoa Prosecutor's Office to establish and ascertain any responsibilities. A similar case file was opened by the Genoese judiciary for the events related to the collapse of the breakwater of the public port in Santa Margherita. In total, about 300 boats, yachts, and vessels were damaged; as of November 15, about 130 had been removed, with complex and delicate operations on the seafront and marina. Within the Rapallo municipal territory, severe damages were also recorded in the marine hamlet of San Michele di Pagana, with the destruction of local beach establishments and various commercial and dining activities, damage to stretches of beach and cliffs, the collapse of the pier in front of the piazzetta, the collapse of a section of the coastal road to Rapallo near the Arches Beach, and the collapse of various portions of retaining walls of lands overlooking the sea and the coastal walkway connecting to the small inhabited nucleus of Prelo. Towards the east, further storm surge damages were recorded in Zoagli, with the collapse of some sections of the cliff (both east and west) and damage to commercial activities, and again in the eastern Tigullio area, with similar but less severe issues in Chiavari, Lavagna, Cavi di Lavagna, Sestri Levante, and Riva Trigoso. In the Spezzino Riviera, damages caused by wind and storm surges were recorded in Monterosso al Mare, Vernazza, Riomaggiore, Portovenere, and the provincial capital itself. In the Western Riviera, atmospheric phenomena affected the municipalities of Arenzano, Cogoleto, Celle Ligure, Albisola Marina, Savona, Bergeggi, Alassio, Finale Ligure, and other locations along the Savona coast. A similar situation also occurred in the province of Imperia, with damages recorded in the capital and Sanremo.

The exceptional nature of the atmospheric event, especially due to the vastness of the affected area, inevitably caused significant monetary damage across all economic sectors and infrastructures, both public and private. An approximate calculation, revised multiple times by the various affected territories, led to an estimate of damages by the Chamber of Commerce of Genoa exceeding 100,000,000 euros in the municipalities of the Genoese province alone: 477 reports were filed by businesses and activities in 25 municipalities of the metropolitan city of Genoa, of which 117 were in Genoa itself (damages of about 33,400,000 euros), 73 in Rapallo (about 23,500,000 euros), and 61 in Santa Margherita Ligure (about 23,300,000 euros). In the Imperia area, the estimate was about 18,000,000 euros for the municipality of Imperia alone. In the province of Savona, the assessment mainly concerned damage to various beach establishments, with a total exceeding 30,000,000 euros, including volumetric and commercial value lost and necessary for restarting. To address the initial critical issues, in January 2019, the National Department of Civil Protection allocated 6,500,000 euros for initial emergency interventions, of which 2,700,000 euros were to cover expenses incurred by municipal entities for assistance interventions and the remaining 4,700,000 euros for the restoration and adjustment of roadways. Specifically, 57 municipalities were involved in the allocation of funding: 21 in the province of Savona, 15 in the province of Genoa, 14 in the province of La Spezia, and 7 in the province of Imperia. This amount was supplemented by an allocation of about 1,500,000 euros from the Liguria Region and an additional 8,000,000 euros allocated by the Stability Law for coastal defenses in Liguria.

Article_Name: Riada de Tenerife de 2010, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The so-called Tenerife Flood of 2010 took place on February 1 of that year (the eve of the Feast of the Virgin of Candelaria), mainly affecting the metropolitan area of Santa Cruz de Tenerife (Canary Islands, Spain). Unlike the previous major flood experienced in Tenerife, namely the flood of 2002, the 2010 flood was not limited to the city of Santa Cruz de Tenerife and its immediate surrounding areas but rather the powerful Atlantic storm affected practically all of the Canary Islands, although with much greater impact in Santa Cruz de Tenerife. Also, and unlike what happened in 2002, the 2010 flood did not result in any fatalities.

During the storm, it is estimated that 187 liters per square meter fell in Santa Cruz de Tenerife, 270 liters in 24 hours in nearby areas such as San Cristóbal de La Laguna, and 253 liters in 12 hours in Anaga. The storm caused a large number of city residents to be evacuated while streets, squares, and tunnels were flooded. The resulting mud rendered roads and commercial establishments inoperative, paralyzing part of the city's economic activity. The rain and wind storm collapsed the main roads and highways and kept the entire archipelago on orange alert. Just days later, on February 18, another storm, although less intense, caused a blackout that affected the entire island of Tenerife. A chain failure of the electrical groups in the island's two power plants occurred, resulting in what is technically known as a zero-energy event, meaning a total blackout due to the collapse of the supply. Five hours after the blackout, the power supply began to recover. This blackout was harshly criticized in the political arena, as it was considered unacceptable for a total blackout to occur on an island with more than 900,000 inhabitants.

Article_Name: سیل ۱۳۹۸ شمال ایران - ویکی‌پدیا، دانشنامهٔ آزاد

Whole_Text.content:
From March 17, 2019, due to heavy rainfall in the northern provinces of Iran, including Golestan, Mazandaran, and North Khorasan, floods occurred. These floods caused financial damages for the residents of these provinces, as well as the death of 13 people and injuries to at least 116 people.  

It is said that during this natural disaster, 300 millimeters of rainfall occurred over two days, which is equivalent to the average annual rainfall of Golestan province. Reports indicate that other areas of this province also experienced rainfall between 50 to 70 percent of the total annual rainfall within a period of less than five days. This amount of rainfall in this region, throughout the entire period of recorded meteorological data, at least in the past seventy years, has been unprecedented. The floods in Golestan and Mazandaran provinces are described as a cyclical flood that occurs once every hundred years.

According to the Director General of Crisis Management of Mazandaran Province, almost all cities in this province were affected by flooding, but the intensity of flooding in Simorgh and Kiakola was greater than in other areas of Mazandaran Province. The village of Hassanabad Miandorud was also completely submerged. Residents of three other villages were evacuated. The head of the Red Crescent Society of Mazandaran announced the number of flood victims in Mazandaran to be 1,591 people. In this province, roads connecting villages to cities were cut off. These rains continued until Nowruz 2019.

In this province, the cities of Gonbad-e Kavus, Aq Qala, Bandar Torkaman, Gomishan, and others located along the paths of the Gharasu and Gorgan rivers were damaged. The flood also affected parts of Golestan Province, especially Gonbad-e Kavus. Heavy rainfall in the eastern part of Golestan Province began on March 17, 2019, and continued for 48 hours in some counties of this province, reaching up to 300 millimeters. This rainfall caused the overflow of the Boostan and Golestan dams in the eastern part of Golestan Province, and the "Chehel Chay" and "Gorgan River" rivers around Gonbad-e Kavus, a district of Golestan Province, to flood.

In these areas, between 50 to 100 percent of the total annual rainfall occurred within a period of less than five days. This amount of rainfall in this region has been unprecedented in all recorded meteorological data, at least in the past seventy years. Continuous rain and snowfall and a drop in temperature in the provinces of Mazandaran and Golestan, which began on Sunday, March 17, 2019, caused flooding in these provinces. Soil erosion due to excessive exploitation of forests, continuous rainfall, and the release of water from behind dams led to flooding on the eve of Nowruz 2019 in two northern provinces of Iran.  
The cause of the destructive flooding in Turkmen Sahra, especially in Aq Qala, must be sought in a combination of mismanagement and natural factors. Heavy rainfall, the full capacity of dams before the start of the rains, and the lack of dredging of the Gorgan, Atrak, and Qareh Su rivers all contributed to the occurrence of the largest natural and environmental disaster in Turkmen Sahra.

Two children, aged 5 and 2, lost their lives during severe flooding in the Kalaleh and Minoodasht counties of Golestan province. In this incident, a child along with their family was trapped under debris in the village of Berenjvin; the family was rescued, but the child lost their life. Another child also lost their life in the village of Qarnaveh, Kalaleh. According to Fars News Agency, Ali Abbasi, head of Mazandaran's forensic medicine, announced on Friday, March 22, that five people have died in the recent floods. Additionally, reports mention one person missing in Miandrood. Following the capsizing of a motorboat with 24 passengers in Gomishan County, two passengers were killed, and four others went missing; hours later, the bodies of three more were discovered, and after some time, the body of another was also found. Furthermore, in the recent floods, five people lost their lives in Mazandaran: a 36-year-old woman and a man in the village of Darabkola, a 27-year-old man (due to a rockfall caused by rain in the Khatirkuh area of the Savadkuh axis), a 34-year-old man, and a 29-year-old woman in Behshahr. One person is also missing.

The rains continued until the evening of Wednesday, March 20, and damage assessment has not yet been conducted. In the first 24 hours of the incident, 300 vehicles trapped in the snow were freed. Drinking water for 51 villages was cut off. Some rural roads were also blocked due to landslides and rockfalls, and their electricity was also cut off. Some villages were evacuated, and residents of some villages were forced to use boats for commuting. It is said that the amount of rainfall in the last three days of 2018 in Mazandaran was unprecedented in the past 30 years. Due to landslides and flooding of railway lines, the Mazandaran train was also stopped, and because water covered the access routes to Sari Airport, flights to Sari were halted.
On March 22, 2019, flooding caused the closure of the Gorgan to Aq Qala road. Additionally, due to the flooding, the Gonbad Kavus – Aq Qala road was also blocked.

On the evening of March 24, 2019, the engineering and demolition battalion "Hazrat Abolfazl," affiliated with the "45th Engineering Group Javad Al-Aemeh" of the IRGC Ground Forces, detonated parts of the Gorgan-Incheh Borun railway line in three locations north of Aq Qala city to release the accumulated water in the area. Mohsen Rezaei referred to these explosions as the "explosions of hope." On March 27, the IRGC engineering and demolition battalion, under the direct order of Mohammad Ali Jafari, detonated part of the "Charaqli-Gomishan" road to open a path for water to flow out. However, shortly after, Hassan Rouhani implicitly criticized this action: "This has no effect; the water has moved from one side to the other. This action has transferred the Aq Qala flood to Gomishan. According to reports, breaking the roads has had no effect. The river must carry the water out." Subsequently, a letter was published in which the Golestan Province Crisis Management Headquarters, with the presence of the Minister of Interior, requested the commander of the Neynava Corps of Golestan Province to remove two to three points of the railway tracks west of Aq Qala city to accelerate the drainage of surface water. Additionally, Commander Jafari defended the IRGC's action in response to the criticisms.

According to the head of Iran's Veterinary Organization, during the flood in Golestan Province from March 20, 2019, to March 26, 2019, 594,500 broiler chickens, 78,000 parent and laying hens, 2,444 small livestock, and 62 large livestock perished. Additionally, 500 hectares of aquaculture farms were damaged. In Mazandaran Province, 76,000 parent chickens, 87,000 broiler chickens, 8,000 native chickens, 58 large livestock, 1,309 small livestock, and 5,680 honeybee colonies were lost.

The first people who came to the aid of the flood victims in Gonbad, Aq Qala, and Gomishan were the local residents, who both tried to slow the flow of water into the cities by creating barriers along the flood path and rushed to help by distributing essential items and food. At this stage, there was no news of government aid or organized relief efforts. Additionally, fishermen from Bandar Torkaman and Gomishan, especially from the villages of Chapaghli, Charaghli, and Aghizli, brought their boats to Aq Qala and came to the aid of the people. After the flood occurred, the people in the south of Gomishan built a 4-kilometer-long dam in just one day to prevent water from entering the city.

On the third day of Farvardin, Seyyed Ali Khamenei, through an order to Mohammad Hossein Bagheri, Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces, requested him to issue instructions for additional resources to be sent for relief efforts alongside the current resources being utilized. [21] Subsequently, Bagheri, through a directive to the commanders of the IRGC, the Army, the Law Enforcement Force, and the Ministry of Defense, instructed them to not only continue their current assistance but also to deploy all necessary facilities and equipment to the affected areas in coordination. [22][23] Bagheri also dispatched Ataollah Salehi, the Deputy Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces, at the head of a delegation of high-ranking military commanders to the flood-stricken areas. [22][23] From Wednesday, the 14th of Farvardin, a heavy-duty dredging machine of the Islamic Republic of Iran Army was also transferred to the city of Aq Qala and stationed in the area to expedite the dredging operations of the Gorganrud and Qarasu rivers to accelerate the drainage of water from this city and Gomishan. [24][25] The Khatam al-Anbiya Construction Headquarters of the IRGC constructed a canal for water transfer. [26]

In addition to the Red Crescent forces, governmental and non-governmental organizations also participated in providing assistance. The Imam Ali Society formed reconnaissance teams in the affected areas to report on the situation and provide aid. It also set up centers in other cities to collect public donations. The Executive Headquarters of Imam's Directive dispatched 22 jihadist groups for assistance from the first day. Mohammad Mokhber, the head of this headquarters, announced the donation of four thousand sets of household items, including refrigerators, carpets, and essential living supplies, to families whose homes were damaged in the flood, as well as four thousand small livestock to 4,000 rural families affected by the flood. It was also decided that the Barakat Foundation, a subsidiary of the Executive Headquarters, would create 3,000 jobs for residents of the flood-affected areas. The Ehsan Barakat Foundation, affiliated with the Executive Headquarters, distributed 40,000 hot meals in the two provinces of Mazandaran and Golestan by April 10. The Tehran Municipality also dispatched 130 waste management personnel to the flood-affected areas.

The World Health Organization, the Turkish Red Crescent, the Kuwaiti Red Crescent, the German Red Cross, and the Ministry of Emergency Situations of Armenia have sent aid. Additionally, the Swiss government, the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), the Qatari Red Crescent, the Danish Red Cross, the Austrian Red Cross, the French non-governmental organization People's Aid, the Indian Red Cross, the Palestinian Red Crescent, and the Islamic Republic of Pakistan have also expressed readiness to assist the flood victims in Iran.

During the construction of walls around the Gomishan canal by volunteer forces, a boat carrying 23 passengers capsized, resulting in 17 people being rescued and 6 fatalities. According to the acting governor of Golestan, those who lost their lives in the Gomishan boat accident had been voluntarily filling sacks with soil for about 10 to 12 days in an effort to create an earthen dike to prevent water from entering the city of Gomishan.

The performance of responsible agencies in providing aid to flood victims and the absence of government officials faced criticism from social media users, flood-affected people, and various individuals such as Ali Daei, Sardar Azmoun, Jafar Sobhani, the commander of the Neynava Corps, and the Sunni Friday prayer leader of Aq Qala. The manner in which the national broadcaster covered the news related to the flood also faced criticism from Hassan Yazdani and the public.

People on social media played a key role in raising awareness about the situation in flood-stricken cities by sharing photos and videos, and the role of social networks, especially filtered platforms like Telegram and Twitter, should not be overlooked.

Whole_Text.content: The Shiraz flood was a flood that occurred on March 25, 2019, due to heavy rainfall in Fars province, resulting in more than 200 vehicles being submerged. On March 26, the flood reached eastern Shiraz, including the Saadi area, Golestan Square, and some other areas, and water entered people's homes.

According to the head of the Forensic Medicine Organization of Fars Province, 19 people have lost their lives, including six men, seven women, and four children, and so far 119 people have been injured.

At 8:00 AM on Monday, March 25, 2019, heavy rain began, and shortly after, it intensified with hail, becoming stronger and stronger. After an hour and a half of rain, a flood engulfed the city.  
The rise in the water level of the Roubari Auzangi River was one of the causes of this flood.  
The construction of roads and streets in the dry riverbed of Shiraz, as well as the construction of a road in the Qaragh Valley near the Quran Gate, played a role in the flooding and the increase in damage and losses.

Article_Name: Alluvione delle Marche e della Romagna del 2011

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Marche and Romagna in 2011
Whole_Text.content: The flood of Marche and Romagna in 2011 was a series of natural disasters that affected the areas between the province of Ascoli Piceno and the province of Ravenna from March 1 to March 6, 2011.

Around 11:00 a.m. on Tuesday, March 1, 2011, extraordinary rainfall began in the province of Fermo, causing significant damage in the inland areas. Numerous inhabited centers were left without electricity, and communications became difficult. The following day, the storm affected almost the entire Marche region, reaching Ascoli Piceno and part of Romagna (Ravenna), and in the evening in Casette d'Ete, a district of Sant'Elpidio a Mare, the overflow of the Ete Morto caused two fatalities: a car was swept away, a man and his daughter died while the wife survived and was found in a state of shock. On March 3, about 143 people were evacuated, the majority in Casette d'Ete, the area most affected by the flood. In Venarotta (Ascoli Piceno), a woman died in a flooded ditch. Rivers and streams overflowed: Ete Vivo, Tronto, Aso, Menocchia, Misa, Esino, Nevola, and Musone. In Cervia, two people died in a car while passing through a flooded underpass. Bora winds, storms, and heavy snowfall in the Umbria-Marche area further complicated communications. For example, the Adriatic state road 16 was covered in mud. In Forlì, schools were closed, and the Ancona-Falconara airport was shut down as a precaution. The flood emergency in Marche and Romagna was declared over on March 6 at 7:40 p.m. with a statement from the Civil Protection Department.

Immediately after the declaration of the concluded emergency, the allocation of funds for damages by the Marche region began. Already in 2012, 25 million euros were ready, cutting the gasoline tax. In 2014, the Renzi government allocated 1.3 million, which would become 1.4 million in 2017.

Whole_Text.content: The 2019 flood in the Irkutsk region, an event that occurred in the Irkutsk region at the end of June 2019, was caused by heavy rains. The floodwaters of the Iya River reached their peak near the city of Tulun, where an exceptional rise in the river level was recorded—14 meters (while the critical high level is set at 700 cm).

As the cause of the flood, mass media and specialists point to torrential and heavy rains. Particularly in focus is the flooding of the Iya River located in the Tulun region. Over three days, from June 25 to 27, record amounts of precipitation were recorded in this area, exceeding the monthly average precipitation by 3.7 times. The cause of the catastrophic precipitation is a weather anomaly observed against the backdrop of global and regional climate changes. The Irkutsk region has also become a focal point of such changes. Employees of the Hydrometeorology and Active Influence on Atmospheric Phenomena Service concluded that an exceptional situation occurred in the western regions of the Irkutsk region due to the simultaneous interaction of three air masses. Since the rise in river levels usually occurs on June 25-26, this period coincided this year with storms characteristic of a tropical cyclone, which involve a greater influx of heat and moisture from the Pacific Ocean. Under conditions of non-uniform terrain, such heat and moisture led to cloudiness and corresponding precipitation. Although initially, the hypothesis circulated that the presence of the Angara Cascade Hydroelectric Power Station contributed to the emergence of such a large amount of precipitation, this hypothesis was later refuted[2].

On June 25, the water level began to rise in the tributaries of the Angara River. A high alert regime was introduced in the Cheremkhovsky and Nizhneudinsky districts. The "Arshaluis" children's camp (Nizhneudinsky district, on the banks of the Uda River) was evacuated. Rescuers departed for the Cheremkhovsky district by Mi-8 helicopter.  
On June 26, a temporary accommodation station for evacuees was prepared in the Solyanaya settlement. In Nizhneudinsk, four shelters were prepared for temporary accommodation, designed for 1,000 people. A high alert regime was declared in the Tayshetsky district due to the threat of flooding in Serebrovo and Solyanaya. A specially organized unit of the Ministry of Emergency Situations (EMERCOM) was sent to the Irkutsk region to evacuate the population to prepared residential shelters. A warning was issued by EMERCOM stating that five districts of the Irkutsk region—Nizhneudinsk, Tulunsky, Ziminsky, Shelekhovsky, and Tayshetsky—were under threat of flooding. A state of emergency was declared in the city of Nizhneudinsk. Water and electricity supplies were cut off in the city. The main division of EMERCOM serving the Irkutsk region was brought to the highest level of readiness.  
On June 27, six residential districts were flooded in the morning. The following regimes were in effect in the morning. At 3:00 PM, a state of emergency was declared throughout the Irkutsk region. From June 28 to 30, the forecast was extended for the water levels of the following rivers to rise: Uda, Iya, Oka, Biryusa, Belaya, and Irkut. In the evening, it was announced that 190 houses in the Tulunsky district were flooded, located in the villages of Krivusha, Uygat, Arshan settlement, Yevdokimova, Kharantey villages, Odon settlement, Yevdokimovsky settlement, and Yevdokimovo village. The population of all the aforementioned areas was evacuated.  
On June 28, Sergey Menyaylo, the plenipotentiary representative of the President of the Russian Federation in the Siberian Federal District, sent a telegram to the commander of the Central Military District requesting assistance for residents evacuated from the flooded areas. 800 people were evacuated from their permanent residences. More than 6,500 evacuees were accommodated in 17 shelters by the relevant authorities. According to EMERCOM data, as of the morning of June 28, 20 residential districts, 2,392 residential houses, and 2,521 household plots were flooded. EMERCOM of the Irkutsk region predicted a rise in the Iya and Tulun rivers to 9.5–10.5 meters. EMERCOM head Yevgeny Zinichev arrived in the Irkutsk region to coordinate rescue and evacuation operations on-site.  
On June 29, according to EMERCOM data, as of 1:00 AM, 31 residential districts in the Nizhneudinsky, Tayshetsky, Tulunsky, and Chunsky districts were flooded. Russian President Vladimir Putin also arrived in the affected region.  
On June 30, according to data published on June 30, the death toll had reached 5, and more than 100 people had been hospitalized. Numerous household plots and 4,000 houses were submerged.  
On July 1, Russian Deputy Prime Minister Vitaly Mutko reported that the death toll from the flood in the Irkutsk region of the Russian Federation had reached 12. According to the Deputy Prime Minister, the data was constantly changing. According to the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the number of affected people was 751, of whom 153 were in hospitals.  
On July 2, the water level began to decrease in all flooded areas. Efforts to eliminate the consequences of the disaster began. Work to restore electricity also commenced. According to a representative of the emergency services of the Irkutsk region of the Russian Federation, the death toll from the flood had reached 14, while 13 people were missing, including one child. It was reported that 2,600 people, including 600 children, were evacuated from zones posing a danger to the population. Later, it became known that the death toll had reached 18, and 17 people were missing.

The road infrastructure is partially collapsed. Dozens of populated areas have become targets of floods and inundations. More than 6,700 residential houses have been flooded. Over 2,600 people have been evacuated from the flood-affected areas. The death toll has reached 18.
Decisions have been made.

President of Armenia Armen Sarkissian and President of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev sent condolence telegrams to the President of the Russian Federation Vladimir Putin regarding the flood that occurred in the Irkutsk region.

Article_Name: Inundaciones en Centroamérica de 2011, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The floods in Central America in 2011 affected the territories of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Panama. They were caused by low-pressure systems that lasted more than a week, and the impact of the meteorological phenomenon caused damage to local infrastructure, over one hundred deaths, and at least 800,000 affected people. The intensity of the events has been attributed to climate change by experts on the subject.

The rains in Costa Rica began approximately on October 7, and in the following days, a preliminary amount of 17 cantons in the Pacific coast and Central Valley were reported to be affected by landslides and floods. On October 10, the National Emergency Commission (CNE) declared a green alert, based on the presence of a low-pressure system near the country that was producing "intense rainfall with accumulations between 150 to 200 mm in 254 hours." By the 19th and 20th, the National Emergency Commission (CNE) estimated 12,000 affected people, 995 evacuated, four dead, and two missing, "as a consequence of the climatic contingency, which exceeded the monthly average rainfall." Meanwhile, the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock estimated losses in pastures (20,000 hectares destroyed) and the sugarcane sector (4,300 hectares), rice (3,200 hectares), and tomatoes. The storm, which was classified as one of the longest in the history of the United States, broke the record for the most damaging storm in terms of road infrastructure, after reporting damage to more than 1,590 kilometers of roads across the country, as well as 4,300 hectares of sugarcane, 3,200 hectares of rice, and 20,000 hectares of pasture flooded after the storm.

The rains began in El Salvador on October 10, and in the following ten days, a historic record of 1,504 millimeters of water accumulated, surpassing the levels of Hurricane Mitch in 1998. Additionally, an estimated 10% of the territory was affected by the floods, along with damage to agriculture, destruction of bridges and roads caused by river overflows and landslides. According to a report from the National Territorial Studies Service on October 17, "the large amount of precipitation was caused by a Low Pressure system that was later classified as Tropical Depression 12E, preceded by a broad depression field formed in Central America." President Mauricio Funes declared a state of emergency throughout the territory on October 14. Likewise, in a speech delivered on the 19th of the same month, he stated: Meanwhile, the Legislative Assembly declared a State of Public Calamity and Disaster on the 17th. In a report from the General Directorate of Civil Protection on October 20, it was revealed that a total of 34 people had lost their lives, four bridges had collapsed, 879 landslides occurred on various roads in the country, and an estimated at least 1 million Salvadorans were "more closely impacted." On the 21st, it was reported that a total of 181 municipalities in the country were affected. Data from the Ministry of Agriculture authorities revealed "the loss of 987,890 quintals of corn, 369,835 quintals of beans, 228,502 quintals of sorghum, and 92,252 quintals of rice."

Tropical Depression 12E struck Guatemala starting on October 11, and after 14 hours of uninterrupted rain, 42 road sections were reported damaged by landslides, in addition to overflowing rivers and floods. About 14 of the country's 22 departments were affected. On October 17, President Álvaro Colom declared a state of public calamity. In a speech, the president stated: By October 20, the National Coordinator for Disaster Reduction reported that the rains had resulted in 38 deaths, 5 missing persons, and 524,480 affected individuals. Meanwhile, the Guatemalan Chamber of Agriculture detailed that the country's agricultural income could "decrease... by up to about 37.5 million dollars." Additionally, the Ministry of Agriculture asserted that according to its "partial calculations," the damage caused by the rains to agricultural crops would reach 43 million quetzals (about 5.3 million dollars).

In the southern region of Honduras, the rains began on October 11, causing the overflow of the Choluteca River, which affected the capital city of the department with the same name. Another department where damages were reported was Valle, as well as Texiguat, in El Paraíso. The floods affected various road sections in the area. President Porfirio Lobo declared an emergency in the southern region of the country on October 16, part of his speech included: By October 20, the Permanent Contingency Commission (COPECO) issued a report stating a total of 18 deaths, 59,663 people affected, 549 displaced, 52 damaged roads, and 11 destroyed bridges, among other calamities caused by the conditions of the "intertropical convergence zone." Additionally, around 9,000 manzanas of crops were reported lost. The devastation reached the departments of Valle, Choluteca, Francisco Morazán, El Paraíso, Lempira, and Intibucá.

Also in Nicaragua, rains were reported starting October 10, and within the first 12 hours, river overflows and damage to the road network in the departments of Chinandega and León were recorded; as well as in Managua and Masaya, an undetermined number of homes ended up flooded. In response to the emergency, the Nicaraguan government, led by President Daniel Ortega, declared a state of calamity and disaster throughout the national territory on October 17. It was also announced that 133,858 people had been affected across the country, mainly in Managua, Carazo, Granada, Chinandega, León, Madriz, and Estelí, where "15,000 families were isolated due to road cuts and floods." By the 19th, official data revealed figures of "12 dead, one missing, and 150,000 people affected, as well as 75,000 isolated and 10,300 sheltered in 104 temporary shelters," as a result of the relentless rains.

In Panama, on October 11, around 900 people were evacuated following the overflow of the Chiriquí Viejo River and the rupture of a natural dam—formed by landslides that blocked the waters of the Palo Blanco River—in the localities of Progreso, La Esperanza, and Baco in the Barú district. President Ricardo Martinelli requested that people in the risk zone cooperate with the evacuation, which saved many lives in Chiriquí. According to government data, 450 people were relocated to shelters: 250 of them in a gymnasium and 150 in a high school located in Puerto Armuelles, while the rest took refuge in the homes of relatives and/or friends.

The Salvadoran Foreign Minister Hugo Martínez announced the call for a meeting between the presidents of the so-called "Northern Triangle," composed of Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, in the city of San Salvador. Additionally, an invitation was extended to "other leaders of the member countries of the Central American Integration System (SICA), which includes Belize, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Panama," all "with the purpose of presenting a request for aid to the international community." On the other hand, it was intended that each country present a report on the damages caused by the weather and the resources required to "undertake reconstruction." The meeting, held on October 25 and hosted by President Mauricio Funes, was attended by the leaders Álvaro Colom, Laura Chinchilla, and Porfirio Lobo, along with the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos and the ambassadors of Belize, Panama, and the Dominican Republic.

Article_Name: Inundaciones en la región litoral del Ecuador de 2008, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods in the coastal region of Ecuador in 2008
Whole_Text.content: The floods in the coastal region of Ecuador were a large-scale natural disaster that occurred in early January 2008, affecting the entire coastal region of Ecuador, in the provinces of Guayas, Santa Elena, El Oro, Manabí, Los Ríos, and Esmeraldas.

The winter season on the Ecuadorian coast caused great damage to the rural population of the region, disproportionately suffering the consequences of the disaster, being vulnerable to risks that affected health, housing, agriculture, education, goods, and services. The increase in rain, temperature, and air humidity as a result of global warming caused a greater impact on various socioeconomic sectors. The lack of early warning mechanisms and the poor management of dikes and dams, for various reasons, are considered factors that have increased the magnitude of the disaster.

Humidity unleashed hurricane-force winds in the Province of Guayas, in Milagro, Naranjito, Santa Lucía, and El Empalme. The hurricane-force winds, which were accompanied by heavy rains and thunderstorms, are due to climate change and deforestation.

34 fatalities have been reported due to floods, river overflows, landslides, etc. So far, 12,000 people have been evacuated to 281 shelters. Around 75,000 productive hectares have been affected, 55,000 lost, and $63 million in agricultural and livestock losses. Landslides buried vehicles and roads. A torrent of stones, rocks, and mud fell on the night of March 8 on the Portoviejo-Quevedo road, in the San Plácido sector, crushing three vehicles: a bus from the Reales Tamarindos cooperative, a car, and a truck.

The National Government of the Republic of Ecuador instructed the Ministry of the Coast to work with all Regional Subsecretariats on a contingency plan to provide aid and rescue to those affected in the impacted areas. This work was carried out in coordination with the three branches of the Armed Forces of Ecuador, the National Police, Civil Defense, and with the collaboration of international aid organizations. Eight working groups were established to outline and set the parameters for assistance.

Article_Name: Inundación de Formosa en 1983, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Formosa in 1983 arrived on May 31 of that same year, when the river reached its peak and about 60,000 people were evacuated.

Since the founding of the City in 1879, new settlements had to be established in lower areas, closer to the coast, closer to the river, as if challenging its territory, even though knowing this represented an indefinite risk. Thus, a significant percentage of the urban area developed on the periphery of the original settlement, creating populous and densely populated neighborhoods. After several decades, the inhabitants and rulers believed they were completely safe, thinking that nothing and no one could devastate the already established urban area. They began "reclaiming" land from the river by partially filling in coastal areas, altering the ecosystem, destroying forests, degrading the soil, and building houses and factories in risk-prone zones. Large projects were also planned, such as a Coastal Avenue. However, these were nothing more than simple political promises. At that time, the floods of the Paraguay River were rare, weak, and manageable. The inhabitants knew how far the water would reach during each event. But during the 1960s and 1970s, the floods became characterized by greater frequency, longer duration, and increasingly significant hydrometric readings. By 1979, with a maximum height of 8.32 meters, the Paraguay River caused significant losses and thousands of evacuations, serving as a sort of warning of what was to come. After these inconveniences, settlements near the riverbanks were reestablished, believing it would not happen again. By July 1982, a new river flood raised the waters to 8.68 meters, surpassing the 1979 mark, causing millions of pesos in losses and affecting more than 18,000 people, marking the beginning of what would become the greatest flood of the century recorded in the Argentine littoral. From then on, the water remained stagnant, rising and falling but always within normal parameters.

Due to the low temperatures and heavy rains in the Paraná River basins, by the end of April 1983, the Paraguay River levels had already reached 8.90 meters in height at the Formosa port. The provinces of Santa Fe, Misiones, Corrientes, and Chaco had already been in a state of emergency for almost a month, and even the Barranqueras port had disappeared under the ever-rising waters. As the situation became uncontrollable, Formosa was declared in a state of emergency; the Paraguay River had surpassed 9 meters, and the disaster began to worsen, first in the island and riverside areas, and then in the peripheral neighborhoods of the capital and nearby towns, threateningly surrounding populated centers without defenses or adequate resources to face such an overflow. Then, everything turned to outrage and sadness. The waters had already devastated towns like Clorinda and Herradura, cut off roads and highways, and were still advancing. In response, both in the capital and in Clorinda, desperate construction of coastal defense works began, surrounding the urban core, built on the highest perimeters with compacted soil brought in by trucks operating tirelessly and piled up by road machinery, forming a containment barrier. This grueling effort involved the movement of 340 trucks and 119 heavy equipment units between the two cities, the transport of over 1,000,000 cubic meters of soil, and the tireless and selfless work of thousands of anonymous hands who reinforced the embankments day and night with sandbags, driving stakes, and fighting to save what belonged to everyone. But the river kept rising, advancing past the 10-meter mark with no intention of stopping. At the local port, activity was relentless; thousands of evacuated families with the few belongings they could salvage were assisted by every available vessel, such as the sand dredger Capri VI, which made tireless trips transporting populations from nearby areas like Alberdi in Paraguay and the most affected island sectors, or the Navy ship 'Piloto Alsina,' which served as shelter and assistance for hundreds of affected families. On May 31, 1983, the river reached its maximum level: 10.73 meters, plunging the city of Formosa into the worst chaos: schools turned into evacuation centers, classes suspended, basic services provided inadequately, supermarkets out of stock, businesses closing, producers losing everything, and more than 10,000 Formosa residents deciding to leave a province that suddenly frightened them. But many stayed; they helped distribute food, clothing, and medicine among the more than 75 evacuation centers scattered throughout the city, to reinforce hope in the containment barriers, to collaborate with Civil Defense, the Red Cross, the Coast Guard, the Air Force, the Army, and the Gendarmerie in whatever was necessary, to try to save what belonged to them and fight to the end in a sort of personal battle to avenge the misfortune of nearly 70,000 people affected by the waters of a river that showed no mercy, that was relentless, and that exacted a heavy toll for human recklessness. By mid-June, the water began its steady retreat; it had calmed down and finally gave up. It left behind desolation, sadness, lost dreams, and for many, an inevitable need to start over; it also left in memory the recollection of the solidarity of a community that decided not to give up and fought to save their belongings and their dignity.
The floods of 1983 exceeded the average height of the river by 6.13 meters.

Article_Name: Inundación de León de los Aldama de 1926, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood of León de los Aldama in 1926
Whole_Text.content:
Floods have been one of the scourges that have most frequently afflicted the city of León de los Aldama since its founding in 1576. Partly caused by nature, the negligence of citizens and authorities has also played an important role. León was founded and has grown on almost flat terrain that hardly allows for the rapid drainage of water that comes from higher areas after heavy rains. This excess water, which the rivers crossing the city cannot drain, spills over the urban area and causes catastrophic floods, large and with strong currents. In the early hours of June 23, 1926, much of the population was sleeping peacefully when they were awakened by street cries and police whistles warning of the danger looming over the city: the Río de Los Gómez was overflowing on 5 de Mayo Street! At dawn, the El Muerto stream also began to spill over the town of El Coecillo, collapsing fragile adobe houses and killing their occupants. To make matters worse, at nine in the morning, a second, more violent current followed, caused by the destruction of the dam wall of the Hacienda de Arriba.

The bells of the temples rang furiously, warning people to flee, but upon leaving their homes, they found that the streets had turned into rushing torrents that inexorably rose in level, sweeping everything in their path. The current flowed past the facades, carrying furniture, mattresses, clothes, and a few human and animal corpses in its wake. With difficulty, people began to cross the streets, clinging to doors, window bars, or lampposts, carrying their youngest children and some of their most precious belongings on their backs.

Most tried to reach high places like Bellavista and the hills of La Soledad or El Santuario, while others found refuge in the Teatro Doblado, the Seminary, the Municipal Palace, the Reforma Bullring, and even the Modelo School, Círculo Leonés Mutualista, and private homes.

The people of León had almost no resources and managed however they could to eat and endure. A thousand homes and buildings collapsed, material losses were estimated at twelve million pesos, and the dead—according to official figures—were more than eighty. On June 29, the municipal president Guadalupe Núñez and several residents created the "Relief Committee," which was responsible for organizing relief activities and managing the funds that were being collected. This committee was chaired by Don Enrique Aranda. The reconstruction of the city took place during difficult times, as the Mexican Revolution had just ended, but what would become the Cristero War was already brewing. Many families emigrated, and those who stayed had to face the misery caused by the catastrophe. Even today, León is crossed by numerous rivers, streams, and canals, so floods remain a daily occurrence: We must not forget that waters always find and follow their path.
The flood of 1907, popularly known as the "great flood," was a catastrophic flood that took place during the early hours of Tuesday, September 24, 1907, in the Spanish city of Málaga.

The one in September 1907 was the fourth in a series of floods that occurred at the beginning of the century: in 1901, on November 4, 1902, and on September 4, 1905. Previously, there is evidence of other severe floods that occurred in 1661, 1764, and 1786, among others. With the distribution of Malaga's lands carried out after the Christian conquest of Málaga, the forests of the Montes de Málaga began to be cut down, and the lands were cleared for vine cultivation, leaving the city, located at the end of a steep valley at the mouth of the Guadalmedina, defenseless against storms. The situation worsened with the phylloxera plague that devastated the province in the last third of the 19th century and the consequent abandonment of the vineyards.

The flood occurred without any rain in the city, when a torrent of water and mud from the Guadalmedina basin, where there had been heavy downpours, rushed into Málaga around one in the morning. The wall of water, mud, and sludge first knocked down the old La Aurora bridge, which blocked the water's path as it got stuck at the Santo Domingo bridge, until this one also gave way, with the same situation repeating at the Tetuán bridge, located downstream and the only one that withstood the force, as the next bridge, the railway bridge, was also destroyed. The sudden increase in water flow caused the river to overflow, quickly flooding the neighborhoods of El Perchel and La Trinidad and many other low-lying areas of the city. During the catastrophe, twenty-one people drowned, and many others were injured. The waters reached up to five meters in height, and according to witnesses, the amount of mud and debris was such that it was possible to access some houses through the balconies. The material damages were estimated at around five and a half million pesetas of the time, and it took up to two months to completely clean the streets.

Alfonso XIII ordered that, with the utmost urgency, the necessary works be carried out to prevent the recurrence of floods in Málaga. In 1908, the Málaga-born engineer Manuel Jiménez Lombardo presented the project for the construction of the Agujero dam to the Hydraulic Division of Southern Spain. The dam would retain the waters of the large autumn floods of the Guadalmedina, storing approximately 4.5 cubic hectometers, which would gradually be released through a tunnel with a capacity of 360 m³ and outlets of 60 m³/second. Likewise, given the scale of the catastrophe and also in gratitude for the behavior of the city of Málaga during the shipwreck of the frigate SMS Gneisenau, the German government gifted the city the Puente de los Alemanes (Bridge of the Germans), inaugurated in 1909. The Agujero dam, although efficient in its limited function, could not be the ultimate solution to the flood problem, as hydrological studies of the basin showed that it did not fully guarantee the city's safety. After decades of discussions and debates between supporters of solutions based solely on hydraulic works—civil engineers—and supporters of hydrological-forestry restoration—forestry engineers—the reforestation of the river basin was undertaken, accompanied by the construction of sediment retention dikes. In 1919, José Almagro San Martín, a forestry engineer from the 7th Hydrological-Forestry Division, completed the drafting of the "Project for the Correction of the Guadalmedina Basin." Its execution began in 1929 with the arrival in the city of another forestry engineer, José Martínez Falero. Nearly 5,000 hectares on the left bank of the river were expropriated and reforested, and 30 hydraulic masonry dikes were built. Colonizing species such as Aleppo pine and stone pine were used, effectively fulfilling the protective and restorative objective for the basin's soils, forming the forest mass of the Montes de Málaga natural park. Years later, in 1983, 2.5 km downstream from El Agujero, the El Limonero reservoir was built with a capacity of 25 cubic hectometers, rendering the old El Agujero reservoir obsolete—today its gates and spillways are out of use, though operational, as the Limonero dam is located further downstream—and, together with the aforementioned reforestation measures, solved the severe floods that Málaga had historically faced. The last governmental initiative aimed at increasing the forested area of the Guadalmedina basin was carried out by the Málaga City Council in 2002, with the expropriation of nearly 400 hectares on the right bank, which were reforested in collaboration with the Ministry of the Environment.
