Article_Name: Riada en la rambla Nogalte de 1973, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood in the Nogalte ravine of 1973
Whole_Text.content: The flood of October 19, 1973, is considered one of the worst known floods that occurred on the Iberian Peninsula. Precipitation of around 250 ml was recorded. A maximum flow of 3000 m³/s was reached, and the water reached 15 meters in height in Puerto Lumbreras and 10 meters in Lorca. The significant load of solid materials carried (30% of the flow) increased the destructive capacity of the waters as they passed through Puerto Lumbreras, causing 89 deaths and numerous damages in the town, to which 13 fatalities in Lorca (also in Murcia), 10 in Zurgena, Vélez Rubio, and Macael (Almería), and more than 50 in La Rábita (Granada) must be added.

Most of the area drained by the Nogalte ravine is located within the isohyet of an average annual precipitation of 400 mm, with a marked decrease during the summer months. On some occasions, intense rainfall occurs over short periods of time, causing strong surface runoff that is increased by contributions from other ravines that flow into the Nogalte ravine. Historical records of such floods in the Nogalte ravine are kept in the Municipal Archive of Lorca: the "Deluge" flood in September 1568, the one on September 17, 1623, the one on October 15, 1651 "San Calixto," the one on June 28, 1877, the one on October 14, 1879 "Santa Teresa," preceded by the damaging, terrible, copious, and devastating flood of June 27, 1877. Already in the 20th century, another catastrophic flood occurred in 1948, known as the "ranchito" flood.

On October 17, 18, and 19, 1973, a large amount of rainfall occurred, primarily concentrated in the upper basin of the Guadalentín River, that is, the Vélez, Luchena rivers, and the Nogalte ravine. On October 19, 151.5 mm were recorded in Vélez Rubio and 95.6 mm in Puerto Lumbreras, with maximum rainfall in the part of the Almería province within the Segura basin reaching 300 mm in less than two hours. With such intense rainfall, combined with the lack of vegetation cover, the main basins in the area overflowed. In the province of Almería, the main receiving basins recorded more than 600 million m³, and in some areas, the waters exceeded 15 meters in height. However, it was in the Region of Murcia where the flood was most severe. In Lorca, a flow rate of over 2500 m³/s was recorded in the Guadalentín. In Puerto Lumbreras, the Nogalte ravine reached 1,974 m³/s, of which 814 m³/s were solid flow and 1,160 m³/s were liquid flow, with a specific flow of 14,200 l/s/km². The sediment accounted for 41.18% of the total flow, 70.02% of the liquid flow, a very high figure when similar basins typically accepted values of 40 to 50%.[2] Successive floods were caused by continuous blockages-unblockages and landslides of tons of soil upstream of the channel. Notably, in just two hours, 12 hm³ of water and 8,000 m² of solid material passed through this town, destroying everything in their path.[1]

In the province of Almería, 10 fatalities were recorded in the towns of Zurgena, Vélez Rubio, and Macael. There were numerous material losses, both in infrastructure and housing, as well as in agriculture, with losses of trees, crops, and 8,000 farm animals. In the province of Granada, in the town of La Rábita, the bridge passing directly above the urban center was blocked. This created a dam that, upon breaking, released a massive amount of water and tons of accumulated sediment, destroying dozens of houses and causing the death of more than fifty people. In Lorca, 13 people died, while in Puerto Lumbreras, which was the hardest hit, the total number rose to 89. The flood destroyed 3 km of the national road to Murcia, overflowing the bridge over the dry riverbed, which has a height of over 8 meters. In a letter sent three days after the disaster by the Mayor to the Minister of Finance, it was reported that almost all municipal services had disappeared, such as the Market Square, the Municipal Slaughterhouse, the Potable Water Pumping Station, the Weighbridge, or the Fountain, watering trough, and washing area of Los Caños. In the rest of the region, the waters of the Guadalentín River, to which the Nogalte dry riverbed is a tributary, in turn flooded the Segura River, of which it is a tributary, affecting large depressions in Sangonera la Verde, much of the Murcia orchard, and the Vega Baja.

Article_Name: Riada de San Policarpo, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The San Policarpo Flood was a flood caused by the overflow of the Tormes River that affected numerous homes, religious temples, and infrastructures in the city of Salamanca (Spain). The flood occurred on January 26, 1626. This overflow of the Tormes caused nearly one and a half hundred deaths, affected more than one and a half thousand homes to varying degrees, and destroyed vital infrastructures for the proper functioning of the city. The rise managed to reach the level of the back part of what is now the Convent of San Esteban and flooded a large part of the Salamanca suburb.

The year 1626 begins with abundant snow, followed by a period of intense rains that cause widespread flooding in the Duero basin, affected by the overflows of several of its tributaries. The Tormes River, being one of them, experiences an uncontrolled and sudden increase in flow that occurs within a short interval of less than five hours during the night of January 26-27 (the feast day of Saint Polycarp). This sudden flood causes numerous damages and deaths in the city’s plain, remaining in history as the so-called Night of Saint Polycarp. In the flood, 142 people who were caught off guard during the night died. The churches located in the river plain were seriously affected. The Roman bridge crossing the river suffered severe damage, requiring significant restoration. Four arches on the side farthest from the city completely collapsed, leaving the city cut off on that side; in the following days, more arches collapsed until stopping at the central tower. The bridge was rebuilt starting in 1627, during the reign of Philip IV. The rains caused another flood in February of the same year but with lesser consequences.

Article_Name: Barrancada d'o camping Las Nieves de Biescas - Biquipedia, a enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood at the Las Nieves campsite in Biescas
Whole_Text.content: The flash flood at the Las Nieves campsite in Biescas was a hydrological catastrophe that occurred on August 7, 1996, at the Virgen de las Nieves campsite in Biescas (Alto Gállego, Aragón). Heavy torrential rains triggered a rapid rise in the Arás ravine, where the Las Nieves campsite was located, which was completely swept away by a mudslide, rocks, and trees in a matter of minutes. 87 people died, and 183 were injured.

The Dubraventsy flood — a flood on April 10, 1942, in Mogilev, caused by the breach of a settled embankment through the Dubravenka River. The largest natural-human disaster in Belarus, which resulted in the death of 2,000 people.

During the retreat from Mogilev in July 1941, Red Army soldiers blew up the railway embankment that crosses the Dubravenka River. Due to subsidence, the embankment blocked the riverbed. By winter, a lake had formed behind the embankment, with the water level reaching the rails. In early April 1942, the German occupation authorities sent a brigade to pierce the embankment with several pipes.

On April 10, 1942, repair workers reached the remains of the pipe where Soviet soldiers had planted explosives. When the embankment broke in the second half of the day, the wave instantly swept away all the repair workers. Within 20 minutes, most people, 129 houses, a synagogue, and the Bykhov market were swept into the Dnieper. Unconscious bodies gathered on the banks were placed in one pit. Most of the deceased were not buried due to the swampy deposits of silt and clay, which prevented access to the river for several weeks. Bodies in the dried silt were still being found throughout the year.

Through the expansion of information about the flood at the scientific conference "Mogilev: History and Modernity" in 2006, students of the Belarusian-Russian University organized a petition to the Mogilev City Executive Committee requesting the installation of a monument to the victims of the disaster.

Article_Name: Pantanada de Tous - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content:
The Tous flood (popularly known as "la pantanà") is the name given to the great flood that occurred on October 20, 1982, as a result of the collapse of the Tous dam due to torrential rains that reached 700 mm/day in some areas of the Ayora Valley and the Canal de Navarrés, causing a flood of 16,000 m³/s that devastated the Ribera del Xúquer. In some localities, the rainfall reached a total of 1000 mm from October 19 to 21. However, the magnitude of the disaster was multiplied when, at 7:15 PM on October 20, after several hours during which the Tous dam overflowed from the top, it broke. The collapse of the Tous dam caused a flood in the Xúquer River of 16,000 m³/s, even greater than that of 1864, and devastated the regions of Ribera Alta and Ribera Baixa, especially towns such as Sumacàrcer, Gavarda, Beneixida, Alberic, Carcaixent, and Algemesí. The flooded area covered 290 km². The A-7 highway and the railway line from Silla to Gandia also played an important role in retaining the waters. According to official figures, 8 people died (40 people according to other sources), and approximately 300,000 people were left homeless in the following days. Many homes were permanently lost. Furthermore, towns like Gavarda and Beneixida were relocated in the following years (although some residents tried to rebuild their homes in their original locations). The damages exceeded 60 billion pesetas, only in the province of Valencia.

The affected people opted for various means to seek financial compensation. Some of them, who chose the judicial route, waited in courts for more than twenty years to receive their compensations. Physicist Fernando Senent Pérez conducted a study on the effect of the flood on radioactivity and concluded that it did not cause any significant changes despite the operation of the Cofrents Nuclear Power Plant. The Tous flood has been one of the greatest catastrophes in the modern history of the Valencian Community, comparable, perhaps, to the Great Flood of Valencia and the DANA of 2024.

Article_Name: Enchentes e deslizamentos em Caraguatatuba em 1967 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Floods and landslides in Caraguatatuba in 1967
Whole_Text.content: The floods and landslides in Caraguatatuba in 1967, collectively referred to as the "Hecatomb" or "Catastrophe,"[1] refer to the occurrence of extreme events caused by rainfall in Caraguatatuba on March 18, 1967. The floods resulted in 436 deaths, according to official figures.[2] Around 3,000 people lost their homes, 10 neighborhoods were affected, and it is estimated that 30,000 trees were swept away by the mass movement.[3] The disaster is considered one of the largest in the country and was one of the reasons for the creation of the Civil Defense of the State of São Paulo.[3]

The region of the Northern Coast of the State of São Paulo experienced rapid urban activity expansion at the beginning of the 20th century. The establishment of the São Sebastião Farm, also known as the English Farm, in 1927, dedicated to banana and citrus cultivation, was followed by the development of an extensive railway network, which reached 120 kilometers of expansion with 40 branches. The English Farm was located in the Juqueriquerê River basin and significantly altered the natural drainage and water flow conditions of the region. In the 1960 demographic census, the city already had 9,819 inhabitants, 4,655 of whom lived in the urban area. Combined with accelerated anthropization, the natural configurations of the municipality contribute to the risk of landslides. Situated between the Atlantic Ocean and the Serra do Mar, Caraguatatuba extends along the slopes of that mountain range, which in some sections have gradients exceeding 40%, causing instability and tending to facilitate mass movements. The meteorological conditions of the northern coast are also sensitive to extreme events, as it is a region with high rainfall, varying between monthly averages of 41 mm (August) to 210 mm (January). According to newspapers, it had been raining intensely since March 16, 1967, with the rain intensifying at night. The intense precipitation was a consequence of a precipitation anomaly in Brazil that month, related to frontal systems and the orographic conditions of the region. The month of March had been marked by daily rains, which intensified on the 17th and 18th. According to the English Farm station, the rainfall index for March was 851 mm, with 420 mm on the 18th alone, with no higher index recorded due to the saturation of the rain gauge.

During the day of March 17, Friday, intermittent rain already caused some flooding points in the municipality. The precipitation became heavy on the morning of Saturday, March 18, and landslides began, most of them occurring in the afternoon. At 1:00 PM, an avalanche of rocks, trees, and mud occurred from the Cruzeiro, Jaraguá, and Jaraguazinho hills near the city. Loud noises were heard by the population, but since visibility was impaired by the rain (estimated to be only 20 meters), it was not possible to assess the city's situation at that time. Around 3:30 PM, mass landslides occurred, and the city became isolated. The Tamoios Highway was destroyed, and several cars were trapped in the mountainous section. Access to Ubatuba and São Sebastião, neighboring cities, was blocked, and help could only arrive by sea and air. The Santo Antônio River increased its width from 40 to 200 meters. The mud flowed along with the river. At 4:30 PM, another front opened in the Santo Antônio River valley. In the Rio do Ouro neighborhood, gigantic barriers began to fall in the morning, forming a massive dam that broke a few hours later, wiping out the neighborhood and displacing the main bridge of that river. If the dam had not broken, the entire city would have been flooded and covered by water. As a result, the mountain road was mostly destroyed, making it impossible to recognize its former path in many sections, where cliffs over 100 meters deep formed. The Ubatuba Road suffered landslides in the sections of Maranduba, Getuba, Sumaré, Prainha, and Martim de Sá, covering the road with 80 centimeters of mud. There was a power outage for three days. The official death toll was 436. However, according to residents, the number was higher, with many bodies carried away by the sea or never found under the mud. Due to the scale of the disaster, it became difficult to determine the number of missing people, as those who could report others missing were also simultaneously unaccounted for. Due to the damage to agriculture and the economic decline observed since World War II, the Fazenda dos Ingleses ceased its activities after the 1967 flood.

The landslide at Åkerström on October 6, 1648, is the largest documented landslide along the Göta River in contemporary sources. The landslide was so massive that it dammed the entire river. It carried away fields, trees, meadows, forests, and houses, and it also caused enormous flood waves that swept away people and buildings along the river. Various sources state that between 85 and 127 people perished in the natural disaster. The catastrophe affected both sides of the river, which at the time had a Norwegian and a Swedish side. The location of the landslide was near the villages of Intagan and Åkerström. According to the clergyman Torsten Wassenius in Vassända, the event occurred on October 6, 1648, around 2:00 PM – although some sources claim it was on October 7. The landslide was described as "a great landslide of 27 alnar" and began at a farm located on the then Norwegian side, near Intagan – then called "Intaka." It was mostly meadows, fields, and farms that were swept away in the collapse, and some large boathouses also disappeared in the masses of debris. The boathouses floated upstream a bit toward Trollhättan after the landslide. The water sought a new path following the landslide and temporarily flowed over the lands of Åkerström and Intagan. Only after 27 days did the river regain its former appearance. Even today, one can see a roughly 200-meter-long remnant of the large piece of land that collapsed on the shore below Stubbered on the other side of the river. Norway attempted to claim this small strip of land in 1649. However, it was only nine years until the Treaty of Roskilde, when the area ceased to be a border region between Norway and Sweden.

The floods in Sweden in 2000 occurred during the period July-November 2000 in Sweden, primarily in the provinces of Dalarna, Dalsland, and Värmland. Already during the period April-June of the same year, the flood-affected areas in southern Norrland had experienced more rain than usual. On July 22, 2000, the local rescue service was forced to burn down a hundred-year-old villa in the village of Torpshammar to prevent the house from being dragged down by the water masses, forming a blockage under a nearby bridge, and undermining the foundation of a gas station. On the night of November 23, 2000, the protective embankments holding back the water masses were close to breaking in Arvika, but the local rescue service still did not want to call the area a "disaster zone." There were also fears that the Carl Larsson house would be affected.

Flooding in Gothenburg 2006 during the second half of 2006, it rained unusually heavily in western Götaland. After almost continuous rain for several weeks, the peak came on December 12 when more than 300 millimeters of rain had already fallen. This is normally the amount for two whole months under usual circumstances. Kållered shopping area was completely or partially underwater, and the Mölndal River was several meters above its banks all the way from Mölndal to its mouth in Gothenburg. In the Gothenburg area, it was primarily Härryda, Mölndal, Lerum, Partille, and central Gothenburg that were affected by extensive flooding from the Mölndal River and Säve River. However, severe flooding also occurred in other locations, such as Kungsbacka, which was flooded by the Kungsbacka River, Horred by the Viskan River, and Svenljunga and Falkenberg by the Ätran River. In central Gothenburg and Mölndal, much of the car and tram traffic came to a halt. Organizers were also forced to cancel the match between Gais and Helsingborgs IF at Gamla Ullevi. The following year, 2007, work was carried out to prevent similar rainstorms from causing similar problems in the future. Among other measures, the Mölndal River was dredged and widened.

Article_Name: 八七水災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The August 7 Flood was a severe flood that occurred in southern and central Taiwan from August 7 to August 9, 1959. It is the third most impactful disaster in terms of affected areas and number of victims in Taiwan's post-war history, following the 1999 "921 Earthquake" and the 2009 "August 8 Flood." The death toll (including missing persons) ranks second only to the 1999 "921 Earthquake" among major disasters.

On August 6, 1959, a tropical depression formed over the sea near Dongsha Island and moved northeastward, gradually approaching Taiwan, but it did not further develop into a tropical storm. On August 7, Typhoon Ellen over the southern seas of Japan, influenced by the Fujiwhara effect, drew the tropical depression near Dongsha Island (081) into Taiwan. At 5 p.m. on August 7, the tropical depression made landfall in Budai Township, Chiayi County. After landfall, it gradually weakened due to the influence of the terrain and dissipated near Puli Township due to the obstruction of the Central Mountain Range. A secondary low-pressure system was induced between Hualien and Xincheng on the eastern side of the Central Mountain Range, which continued to move north-northeastward. During its movement over Taiwan, this tropical depression caused extremely unstable weather in central and southern Taiwan, forming a strong southwest airflow and triggering torrential rain.  

The heavy rain began around 6 p.m. on August 7 and eased by the afternoon of August 8. The southwestern slopes of the central and southern mountainous regions and the adjacent western plains recorded rainfall exceeding 500 millimeters. From August 7 to 9, the cumulative rainfall in central and southern Taiwan reached 800 to 1,200 millimeters over three consecutive days—particularly on August 7, when the daily rainfall reached 500 to 1,000 millimeters, nearly equivalent to the average annual rainfall. There were 15 locations where daily rainfall exceeded 500 millimeters. The main centers of heavy rain were concentrated in Miaoli, Fengyuan, Fenyuan, the upper reaches of the Wu River, Douliu, and Alishan.  

Due to the difficulty in draining surface water and the occurrence of flash floods, river levels rose and breached embankments. The flooding destroyed houses and farmland, resulting in an unprecedented flood disaster. The affected areas included all agricultural regions of Taiwan, with extremely severe damage.

The disaster area of the August 7 Flood covered 13 counties and cities, with Miaoli County, Taichung County, Nantou County, Changhua County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, and Taichung City being the most severely affected. Among these, the Dadu River (Wu River) basin experienced heavy rainfall in its upstream tributaries on the evening of the 7th, causing the river to rise rapidly. Floodwaters surged southward, but due to the narrow waterway near the Changhua Railway Bridge, the water could not be discharged in time. This resulted in the left bank of the Dadu River being breached for 1,102 meters, flooding Changhua City, Hemei Township, and Shengang Township, making them the areas with the most severe damage. On the morning of the 8th, floodwaters entered Changhua City, reaching their peak at noon with a depth of up to 3 meters in the shallowest areas. The floodwaters began to recede afterward, with the city area clearing by the morning of the 9th, while the suburban areas remained flooded until the afternoon of the 9th.

The upstream area of the Beigang River received the highest rainfall during the August 7 Flood, causing the river to overflow and breach its embankments, flooding areas such as Huwei, Douliu, Dapi, Douliu, Tuku, and Beigang, resulting in severe damage. In Miaoli County, the Tana River experienced a sudden rise in water levels on the morning of the 8th, breaching the Wuhu embankment and turning Xihu Township into a vast expanse of water. In the southern region, rivers such as the Bajhang River, Jishui River, Zengwen River, and Yanshui River also overflowed their embankments, causing widespread flooding in areas such as Shuishang Township, Yanshui Township, Xuejia Township, Madou Township, Xinshi Township, Yongkang Township, and parts of Tainan City.

The actual disaster area covered 1,365 square kilometers, affecting over 300,000 residents. The death toll reached 667, with 408 missing and 942 injured. A total of 27,466 houses were completely destroyed, and 18,303 were partially destroyed. Transportation and communication in the disaster areas were almost entirely cut off, with over 130,000 hectares of farmland damaged. The total loss was estimated at NT$3.7 billion, accounting for approximately 12% of the previous year's gross national income.

Due to the severe disaster, the military stationed on the island was quickly dispatched for disaster relief following the President's orders. The government of the Republic of China also mobilized citizens to assist in disaster relief based on the "National Obligatory Labor Act," and the Taiwan Provincial Government distributed relief funds to disaster victims according to the "Taiwan Provincial People's Disaster Relief Measures for Death, Injury, and Housing Collapse." Then-President Chiang Kai-shek issued an emergency order to levy a flood reconstruction donation to raise funds for rebuilding. 

As for foreign aid, the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command (USTDC) immediately deployed three U.S. Navy helicopters for disaster relief after the disaster. A few days later, Washington ordered the helicopter carrier USS Thetis Bay (CVE-90) to redirect from Hong Kong waters, carrying 21 Sikorsky H-34 helicopters from the U.S. Marine Corps HMR(L)-261 squadron to Taiwan for disaster relief. The mission was named "Operation Hunger."

Article_Name: Inondation du 12 juin 1966 à Hong Kong — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.header: Flood of June 12, 1966, in Hong Kong
Whole_Text.content: The flood of June 12, 1966, in Hong Kong is a disaster caused by heavy rains. The floods, landslides, and mudflows resulted in severe human and economic losses, with a total of 64 deaths, 48 missing, and 29 injured.

Since June 1966, an active barometric trough had persisted along the southern coast of China, and the air was unstable along the Guangdong province, generating storm bands for more than ten days. On June 8, in the Kowloon district, an outer wall of La Salle Primary School in Kowloon Tong collapsed, burying 6 people and injuring 16 others, including students aged 12 to 16. On the morning of June 12, a zone of severe thunderstorms hit Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Observatory recorded a rainfall of 108.2 mm between 6 and 7 a.m. that day, the fourth highest ever recorded, and 383 mm over the course of the day.

The affected areas included most districts of Hong Kong, but the most severely impacted were those on Hong Kong Island. For example, the rain turned into torrents of water and caused a sudden flood on Ming Yuen West Street in North Point. Floodwaters descended from the mountain to the harbor, sweeping away and crushing many people and vehicles parked on the street. The rain also eroded steep slopes, causing landslides and mudflows. One of the power plants and water pumps on Hong Kong Island was damaged by the flooding, leading to the suspension of water and electricity supply in some parts of the island. In the Aberdeen area alone, there were 1,200 victims. In the New Territories, particularly in Tai Po and Yuen Long, farmland was severely damaged, including 95% of the rice fields in the former district, according to newspapers. In total, the severe weather caused 64 deaths and over 6,000 victims.

Article_Name: Inundación en La Plata de 2013, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The 2013 flood in La Plata was an event that affected the city of La Plata, the capital of the province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, and its surrounding areas between April 2 and 3, 2013, with a record of extraordinary rainfall, more recurrent in the region, accumulating over 400 mm in four hours. The rains caused a severe flood throughout the Buenos Aires Metropolitan Area, where the confirmed judicial death toll was 89.

On April 2, 2013, the city of La Plata and its surroundings were affected by continuous rainfall. The National Meteorological Service reported that 181 mm fell between 6 PM and 9 PM, with an estimated value of up to 200 mm in other unmeasured areas; the cities of Ensenada and Berisso and the neighborhoods of Los Hornos, Villa Elvira, and Tolosa in La Plata were the most affected, along with the city center. The confirmed number of fatalities was 89. A total of 2,200 people were evacuated.

On March 30, a minimum pressure axis was observed west of the Pacific coast, which quickly evolved into a closed low-pressure center at mid-troposphere levels (known as a cold drop, DANA, or cut-off low). Starting April 1, this closed center moved very slowly from west to east over the center of the country. This low-pressure center created favorable conditions for widespread upward movements in the central-east of Argentina, a necessary condition for cloud formation. On April 2, the development of an incipient frontal wave located in the west of Buenos Aires province, combined with a 1023hPa anticyclone located southeast of Mar del Plata, generated intense and persistent northeast quadrant winds over the east of the province. This condition favored the entry of humid air into the region affected by intense rainfall, evidenced by the sustained increase in water vapor content, which reached maximum values of between 40 and 45 mm in Ezeiza in the early hours of April 2. The emagrams obtained through a radiosonde showed a vertical wind profile from the northeast quadrant in a thickness of approximately 1500 m in height, which extended to greater heights on April 1.

Whole_Text.header: Evolution of the event in the City of La Plata and surroundings
Whole_Text.content: The first areas of precipitation developed over the Río de la Plata and moved in a south-southwest direction. Around 4:00 PM HOA, a significant area of rain and storms entered the districts of Ensenada and Berisso, continuing along the eastern edge of the La Plata district. One of the cells also generated a tornado near the town of Ensenada. Between 5:00 PM and 5:10 PM HOA, an initial storm cell reached the city of La Plata, remaining in that area for approximately one hour. At the same time, successive images show that the storm cells did not display significant movement, suggesting that they were continuously regenerating over the same area, thereby favoring the persistence of rainfall in that region. Although the area affected by the most intense precipitation (according to radar information) extended in a north-south orientation from the boundary between Berisso and Ensenada towards the La Plata district, around 8:00 PM HOA, a fairly intense storm cell developed over the city of La Plata, remaining there for approximately two hours (until 10:00 PM HOA). Subsequently, the entire area of bad weather began to move eastward, towards the Río de la Plata.
The Faculty of Engineering of the National University of La Plata released a report on the causes and consequences of the catastrophe that occurred in La Plata on April 2, 2013.

The architect Roberto Livingston and the environmentalist Osvaldo Guerrica Echevarría pointed to design errors and climate change as the main causes of the floods. There is a theory that the Buenos Aires/La Plata Highway was, in part, a cause of the flooding, as it did not have the necessary number of bridges for proper water drainage, an issue that had been raised but not taken into account during its construction. This deficiency would have left the El Gato stream as the only drainage channel. Thus, the specific observed causes would be: In 2007, a report from the Department of Hydraulics of the Faculty of Engineering of the University of La Plata had identified drainage problems in the El Gato stream basin. It had also warned about the need to address the overflow of the reservoirs on Avenida 32, which, during heavy rains, expelled water instead of retaining it. An underlying issue would be the disorganized demographic growth of real estate in La Plata over the last ten years, which led to the disappearance of large green spaces, historic buildings, and diagonals. It was estimated that more than 800,000 square meters were built between 2003 and 2008, while one million square meters were constructed in the two years prior to the flood. It was also considered that the 2009 Urban Planning Code of La Plata allowed for the construction of more towers in the central area, which may have exacerbated the flooding. Additionally, there is an investigation against the YPF refinery in Ensenada due to an accusation claiming that the closure of a canal gate, carried out to combat a fire caused by the storm, was the main cause of the flooding. The report from the Department of Hydraulics of the Faculty of Engineering of the National University of La Plata states that the hydraulic infrastructure works were not prepared for the event, that the meteorological alert was not issued in time, and that the actions taken by public officials were late, insufficient, and chaotic. The Municipality of La Plata is responsible for the stormwater drainage conduits. Furthermore, the Municipal Emergency Committee has an Emergency Protocol for events like this that should have been activated.

The acting president at the time, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, stated that in the face of "inefficiency and ineffectiveness, those who end up suffering the most are the vulnerable, those who should have the most protection" and emphasized that "there are structural problems that have nothing to do with the storm" and announced an audit. The governor of the province of Buenos Aires, Daniel Scioli, said, "An unprecedented deluge in history." He declared an administrative and educational holiday.

The Secretary of National Security, Sergio Berni, and the Minister of Social Development, Alicia Kirchner, toured the affected areas and visited a donation center. The governor of the Province of Buenos Aires, Daniel Scioli, visited an evacuation center located in Tolosa (one of the most affected areas) and the San Martín Club, a site where aid for those affected by the flood had been concentrated. The head of the national executive branch arrived by helicopter and spoke with those affected by the storm in the Tolosa neighborhood: "I experienced it when I was a girl, I was 15 years old, my house flooded back on 7th Street," she said, adding, "It was the time when the El Gato stream was not channeled, that's why I know, and I wanted to come because I know what it's like to have water up to here, inside your house." "Mom is without electricity and gas but doesn't want to leave the house because the water reached the door, she's afraid it will rain again and doesn't want to leave because there's a leak in the roof," she said. The president was unaware that the El Gato stream was never channeled. The President visited parishes and schools and met with young volunteers, where, sitting on the floor with them, she learned about the mechanisms of aid for those affected. Subsequently, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner declared three days of national mourning through Decree No. 341/13.

The floods caused a fire at the YPF refinery in Ensenada. In a statement, the company reported that "The emergency occurred in the midst of this climatic phenomenon, due to an extraordinary accumulation of rainwater and a power outage across the entire complex" around 8:00 PM on April 1, and that "After four in the morning, the personnel working on-site managed to extinguish the fire. Two fire brigades and specialized company personnel were involved. No injuries were reported during the containment efforts."

YPF implemented an emergency plan to ensure the normal supply of fuel to service stations. There were cross-accusations between the national government, the provincial government, and the municipal government regarding responsibilities, which triggered the discontent of those affected. The mayor of La Plata, Pablo Bruera, from the Social Progress Party (an internal faction of the Justicialist Party in La Plata), provoked the anger of residents by claiming on Twitter that he was touring the affected areas while he was on vacation at a beach in Brazil.
In the city of La Plata, 120,000 users were affected by power outages, 190,000 affected, more than 70,000 homes flooded, and economic losses estimated at 3.4 billion pesos.

Before the Justice, those responsible for the SMN explained that the radar that was supposed to monitor the phenomenon approaching La Plata was broken. The main focus of the storm occurred between 4:00 PM and 7:00 PM that day. It was not until a year later that the Justice system managed to establish the number of fatalities caused by the tragedy. The death toll was 89, 70 percent of whom were over 65 years old. The investigation conducted by the Administrative Litigation Judge of La Plata, Luis Arias, opened the possibility that another 16 people may have died during the storm, although the number could not be conclusively proven. The aforementioned magistrate also ordered the adaptation of death registration procedures, the relocation of people living on the banks of the Del Gato and Maldonado streams, as well as the suspension of real estate developments, among other causes that generated unrest in political and business circles. The Administrative Litigation Judge of La Plata, Luis Arias, was later suspended and removed by a jury initiated during the government of María Eugenia Vidal. The magistrate received support from political, social, and human rights organizations. In fact, the Tolosa Flood Victims Assembly expressed its support for Arias for "promoting a thorough investigation into the number of deaths caused by the flood." Neither Governor Scioli nor Mayor Bruera (the latter with an embarrassing attempt to conceal his vacation in Brazil) were even questioned about these events. The criminal proceedings for the floods in La Plata concluded with a single accused, Sergio Ariel Lezana, a Civil Defense official of that city, who accepted his guilt and requested the maximum penalty for the crime of "failure to fulfill the duties of a public official." Thus, the penalty was established as a payment of $12,500 and a one-year disqualification from holding public office. Lezana was the first official to undergo an oral and public trial for the flood and was to be tried jointly with the provincial Civil Defense chief, Miguel Ángel Di Lorenzo, but the latter passed away months before the trial.

The National University of La Plata, together with the National Technological University, proposed an Integrated Disaster Risk Management Plan (GRID) and created the Water Emergency collection within the Intellectual Creation Dissemination Service, the institutional repository of UNLP, to gather works (articles, technical reports, books, and others) that contribute to the development of the plan and serve as a database for future work in the area.

On April 8, 2013, the national government, through the National Social Security Administration (ANSES), detailed measures to assist those affected by the floods, including low-interest credit lines and subsidies for retirees and pensioners, beneficiaries of the Universal Child Allowance (AUH) and Pregnancy Allowance (AUE), Family Allowances, and Unemployment Insurance, thus covering the most vulnerable affected individuals. Those who received the minimum retirement or a contributory pension, beneficiaries of the Universal Child Allowance, Family Salary, and the Progresar Plan were benefited. Residents requested subsidies for all those affected, and the national government offered them loans to be repaid with low-interest rates, as well as subsidies for retirees and pregnant women. They also requested the cessation of municipal and national tax and fee collections. These benefits would be available to those affected by the floods in the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires, La Plata, La Matanza, San Martín, Berisso, and Ensenada. According to the budget, the Secretariat of Social Development will allocate $30,000,000 in subsidies for residents of La Plata who suffered from the flooding, as reported to Diagonales by official councilors.

According to the Clarín Newspaper, the losses from the floods in La Plata amounted to $2.618 billion. One in four properties was directly affected by the storm, and each affected family would need an average of $78,000 to repair their home and replace the belongings they lost. According to a preliminary report conducted in the municipality of La Plata, 58,582 properties were affected by the rains. Of the total affected properties, 55,716 correspond to homes, while 2,846 are businesses and garages. It is estimated that 25% of La Plata residents were directly affected by the catastrophe, while the figure exceeds 55% of the party's population if those who lost a car or suffered other types of damages are considered. Following the flood, a hydraulic works plan was launched to double the drainage system of the entire Buenos Aires capital region (La Plata, Berisso, and Ensenada). The plan is implemented through the Directorate of Hydraulic Works, which will require an investment of about $2 billion by the province—largely financed by the national government—and will be carried out in parallel stages, where one of the main objectives is to widen the channel of the El Gato stream, which receives 70% of the water that drains in the capital region—carrying all the water from the urban area as well as that from the Regimiento and Pérez streams—and discharges it into the Río de la Plata.

The president decided on military intervention. By order of the Ministry of Defense, the Argentine Army initiated a deployment that would total 1,200 personnel. The I Armored Brigade activated a crisis committee, where the 7th Mechanized Infantry Regiment, the 1st Armored Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron, and the 8th Tank Cavalry Regiment began evacuation and transportation tasks. In the center of La Plata, a mobile water purification plant with a capacity of 2,000 liters of water per hour was installed, supported by a sachet packaging machine. The 601st Engineer Battalion, the 601st Air Assault Regiment, the Buenos Aires Military Garrison Command, the National Military College, the Army Non-Commissioned Officers School "Sargento Cabral," the 1st Infantry Regiment, and the 601st Military Police Company were added to the tasks, which also came to include the loading, transportation, and delivery of supplies in more than 80 mobilized trucks. The overflow in logistics centers due to the large number of donations led the 601st Communications Group to operate as a receiver of items contributed by society, to which the 7th Mechanized Infantry Regiment had to add its facilities days later. The National Military College provided 60 health cadets to the health centers involved in the assistance tasks. From Olavarría, the 1st Armored Engineer Squadron deployed sappers for debris removal tasks, which, with the collaboration of other units, managed to collect tens of thousands of tons. The teleinformatic and integrated support of the Army with the different Security Forces and institutions such as Civil Defense, Caritas, and the Red Cross was handled by the personnel and equipment of the 601st Communications Company, the 602nd Communications Battalion, and the 1st Armored Communications Squadron. These units provided satellite telephony, videoconferencing, image transmission, and Internet, and were supported cartographically by the 1st Armored Intelligence Squadron.

Different sectors of Argentine society mobilized to gather donations for the benefit of those affected. All kinds of goods were collected and sent, including cleaning supplies, food, mattresses, blankets, and even appliances, coming from all parts of the country and distributed in the affected areas. Due to the volume of donations, organizing the shipments became complicated. Thousands of young people from across the country mobilized to the affected areas to perform volunteer work in the restoration of neighborhoods that had been destroyed by the floods. Pope Francis donated US$50,000 to help the flood victims. Although most of the volunteers were self-organized young people, parishes and scout groups also participated, as well as young activists from political and social organizations.

Whole_Text.content: The 2011 Myanmar floods occurred in Myanmar on October 19-20, 2011.

The cyclone (BOB_04) that formed in the Indian Ocean on October 19 made landfall in the border region between Myanmar and Bangladesh from the Bay of Bengal. It caused significant damage, including affecting 35,000 people in the central regions of Magway, Mandalay, and Sagaing. In Pakokku, 1,700 people took refuge in monasteries, and in the Seikphyu area of Magway Region, approximately 3,700 houses in 25 villages were submerged, with about 1,200 of them washed away. The Myanmar government confirmed 215 deaths, and the total, including missing persons, reached 300. The damage in Myanmar amounted to $1.64 million (124 million yen at the time). On October 27, the Japanese government decided to provide emergency relief supplies worth 10 million yen (such as water purifiers and generators). On the 28th, the handover of aid supplies by the Japan International Cooperation Agency took place.
The 7.11 Flood (7.11 Suigai) refers to the flood that occurred in the Shinetsu region from July 11 to 12, 1995 (Heisei 7).

On July 11, 1995 (Heisei 7), when the activity of the rainy season front became active, a torrential downpour occurred in the Joetsu region of Niigata Prefecture, the Hokushin region of Nagano Prefecture, and the eastern region of Toyama Prefecture. Damage occurred around the first-class rivers Himekawa, Sekikawa, and Kurobe River. There were 2 fatalities, and 39 houses were completely or partially destroyed, resulting in relatively minor direct damage to local residents, but over 10,000 people evacuated. It took several years to restore road and railway infrastructure.
This article is a draft related to Niigata Prefecture. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (Portal: Japan's Prefectures/Niigata Prefecture).
The 8.5 Flood refers to the flood that occurred in Tokai, Kanto, Koshin, and Tohoku from August 4 to 5, 1986.

The extratropical cyclone that evolved from Typhoon No. 10 approached Japan from the southern seas, stalled off the Sanriku coast, and eventually dissipated over the eastern seas of Honshu.  
This cyclone brought heavy rain to wide areas of Tokai, Kanto, Koshin, and Tohoku, resulting in 127 casualties, including deaths, missing persons, and injuries across 16 prefectures, and causing damage to a total of 124,959 buildings, including residential and non-residential structures.

Abukuma River, Natori River, Naruse River, etc., breached and overflowed in multiple locations. The entire area, including Sendai City, Iwanuma City, Natori City, Shibata Town, and Kashimadai Town, was flooded.

In Nakadori and Hamadori, a total rainfall of 200mm to 300mm was observed, resulting in heavy rain. Consequently, the Abukuma River and its tributaries overflowed, causing damage to municipalities along the Abukuma River, including Fukushima City. This led to 11 casualties and damage to 14,000 buildings. The 24-hour rainfall observed at the Fukushima Local Meteorological Observatory (Fukushima City) and the Onahama Weather Station (Iwaki City) broke historical records.  

In Fukushima City, significant flooding occurred in Minamimachi near the confluence of the Abukuma River and Arakawa River due to a levee breach, submerging the first floors of buildings completely. In the northern part of Fukushima City, at Iizaka Onsen, the Surikami River, which flows through the center of the hot spring town, overflowed, flooding inns and dealing a severe blow to the summer tourist season.  

In Yanagawa Town, Date District (now Yanagawa area of Date City) in northern Nakadori, as well as Kakuda City and Marumori Town in Igu District, Miyagi Prefecture, damage such as river flooding and inundation was reported. In Koriyama City in central Nakadori, the central industrial complex was flooded, with precision electronics factories submerged and other factories also affected, resulting in damages of 30 billion yen in this industrial complex alone. Including other sectors, the total damage amounted to over 108.5 billion yen.  

In Fukushima Prefecture, there were three fatalities: one in Iwashiro Town, Adachi District (now Nihonmatsu City), and two in Koriyama City.

Overflow and flooding occurred in numerous small rivers across various areas in Tochigi Prefecture. In Motegi Town, the Sakagawa River overflowed and flooded in the early hours of August 5th. Most of the urban area was engulfed by muddy torrents exceeding 1.5 meters. Six fatalities were reported in the town.

From August 8 to September 8, 1986, Fukushima Prefecture established a disaster response headquarters. Fukushima City, Date District Yanagawa Town (now Yanagawa area of Date City), and Adachi District Motomiya Town (now Motomiya City) were subject to the Disaster Relief Act on August 5. Koriyama City and Iwaki City on August 6. Sukagawa City and Soma City on August 7. On September 30, the government designated it as a severe disaster. Following the flooding of the Arakawa and Surigawa Rivers, the former Ministry of Construction was pressed to implement flood control measures, which further promoted the construction of the Surigawa River Dam, a project that had already been planned.
This entry is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this entry (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.content: The 9.12 Flood (9.12 Suigai) was a large-scale flood that occurred in Gifu Prefecture on September 12, 1976 (Showa 51). It is called this because the damage caused by the collapse of the Nagara River was most severe in Anpachi Town, Anpachi District, Gifu Prefecture. It is also referred to as the Anpachi Flood or the 9.12 Heavy Rain. Note: The names of municipalities are indicated as they were at the time.

The rain that began falling in Gifu Prefecture on September 7, 1976 (Showa 51), was influenced by Typhoon No. 17. From September 8 to 14, the recorded rainfall was 1,175 mm at Dainichidake in the Nagara River basin, 1,091 mm in Hachiman Town (now Gujo City), and 840 mm in Mino City. In the Ibi River basin, it was 951 mm in Tarumi (Neo Village, now Motosu City, Neo River) and 824 mm in Ogaki City, marking a record-breaking heavy rainfall.

The rain that began around 10:00 a.m. on September 8 turned into heavy rain, and at 3:30 p.m., a heavy rain and flood advisory was issued, which was upgraded to a heavy rain and flood warning at 11:30 p.m. Due to this torrential rain, from September 8, flooding of small and medium-sized rivers, landslides, and road disruptions occurred in the Mino region, including Gifu and Seino. As of September 9, the damage in Gifu Prefecture included 3 injuries, 2 completely destroyed houses, 2 partially destroyed houses, 653 cases of above-floor flooding, 4,711 cases of below-floor flooding, 61 landslides, and 17 road damages (according to the evening edition of the Gifu Nichinichi Shimbun on September 9). On September 9, Gifu Prefecture established a disaster response headquarters with Governor Saburo Hirano as the head under the Fire and Disaster Management Division. Additionally, Gifu City and Takami Town in Yamagata District were covered under the Disaster Relief Act. Although the advisory was downgraded to a heavy rain and flood advisory at 5:20 p.m., heavy rain resumed from midnight, and a heavy rain and flood warning was issued at 9:40 p.m. On the morning of the 10th, the rain temporarily subsided, and a heavy rain and flood advisory was issued at 1:40 p.m., but intermittent torrential rain resumed in the afternoon, and a heavy rain and flood warning was issued at 9:35 p.m. The rise in the Nagara River was particularly severe, recording a water level of 7.3 meters in Sunomata Town, Ampachi District, at 9:00 a.m. on the 9th. The water level temporarily dropped on the 10th. On September 11, as the damage further expanded due to the overflow of small and medium-sized rivers, dike breaches, and the isolation of areas caused by rising water, the Self-Defense Forces were requested for the first disaster dispatch at 8:30 a.m. based on a request from Gifu City, and the 10th Division of the Ground Self-Defense Force from Moriyama Garrison was dispatched. They were also dispatched to one city, two towns, and one village, including Ogaki City, to conduct rescue operations and recovery work. At this point, the damage in Gifu Prefecture extended to 10 cities, 36 towns, and 18 villages. The water level of the Nagara River in Sunomata Town reached 7.15 meters again at 2:00 p.m. on the 11th. In Gifu City, the Kagamishima area downstream of Chusetsu Bridge was in a dangerous state, and strict vigilance was enforced.

At 5:00 a.m. on September 12, the water level of the Nagara River in Mino-machi reached 7.14 meters, marking the fourth peak. At 7:30 a.m. on the same day, a crack was found in the embankment of the Nagara River in Omori, Ampachi Town, Ampachi District. Reinforcement work was immediately carried out, and the work was completed at 10:20 a.m. A few minutes later, vibrations like an earthquake occurred on the embankment, causing residents engaged in flood prevention activities to feel uneasy and evacuate from the embankment. Then, at 10:28 a.m., the embankment on the right bank of the Nagara River, 300 meters downstream from the Nagara River Bridge of the Tokaido Shinkansen in Omori, Ampachi Town, Ampachi District, breached over a span of about 20 meters. The breach widened due to water pressure, reaching a width of approximately 80 meters. By the evening of the same day, flooding had affected 1,200 households. Additionally, at the Jurenbo embankment of the Waju embankment, located on the border between Ampachi Town and the downstream Wanochi Town, work was carried out to close off the embankment to protect Wanochi Town and to equalize the water levels in Ampachi Town and the Nagara River to stop the muddy flow. As a result, the water, which had nowhere to go, began to flow backward, flooding the entire area of Mino-machi upstream. Furthermore, embankments also breached at five locations, including the Ijira River, a tributary of the Nagara River. Overflow and inundation occurred in various areas, leading to widespread flooding of houses in Gifu City, Ogaki City, Hozumi Town in Motosu District, Takami Town in Yamagata District, and Ijira Village.

Gifu Prefecture applied the Disaster Relief Act to a total of 17 municipalities, including 4 cities, 12 towns, and 1 village, by the 13th. Additionally, considering the actual conditions in the affected areas, the prefecture implemented independent measures equivalent to the act for Kakamigahara City, which did not meet the application criteria, and devoted all efforts to rescue activities. At this point, the number of evacuation centers established and opened in Gifu Prefecture reached 359, with a total capacity of 190,010 people. The duration of establishment extended to 13 days in Anpachi Town and Seka Town.

The human casualties included 8 deaths in Gifu Prefecture, with 5 in Gifu City. There was 1 missing person, 6 seriously injured, and 16 with minor injuries. In Gifu Prefecture, there were 24,209 cases of above-floor flooding and 51,276 cases of below-floor flooding. Particularly severe damage occurred in Anpachi Town and Seka Town, with 1,744 and 1,190 cases of above-floor flooding, respectively, and 366 and 152 cases of below-floor flooding, respectively. The areas most affected were Gifu City, Ogaki City, Mino City, Anpachi Town in Anpachi District, Seka Town, Hozumi Town in Motosu District, Takami Town in Yamagata District, Miyama Town, and Ijira Village. The affected municipalities spanned 74 out of the 100 municipalities in Gifu Prefecture at the time, mainly in the Nagara River, Ibi River, and Kiso River midstream to downstream basins, as well as the Hida region.  

In Anpachi Town, areas such as Nakasu Wajū and Kitaimabuchi Wajū, which were established later than Moribe Wajū, suffered less damage due to relatively higher land elevation. In areas with earlier establishment and lower land elevation, such as Maki Wajū, sandbags and tatami mats were piled on eroded embankment remnants to prevent flooding. Even in Moribe Wajū, where the embankment collapsed, settlements located at the base of the old embankment were spared from damage. However, in Seka Wajū, the southern embankment had been decommissioned, making it impossible to stop the incoming water, which exacerbated the damage.

The Totsukawa Great Flood was a large-scale flood that occurred in August 1889 (Meiji 22) in the Kumano River (Totsukawa) basin. It caused devastating damage to Totsukawa-go, Yoshino District, Nara Prefecture (now Totsukawa Village). It is also referred to as the Totsukawa Great Flood Disaster, Kumano River Great Flood, Kumano River Great Flood Disaster, Kiwa Flood Disaster, or Kiwa Great Flood Disaster (Ki refers to Kishu [Kii Province/Wakayama Prefecture], and Wa refers to Washu [Yamato Province/Nara Prefecture]; notably, the actual number of deaths in Wakayama Prefecture was five times higher than in Nara Prefecture).

The autumn rain front stalled near Japan, and a typhoon approached from the southern seas, bringing heavy rain to the area from Wakayama Prefecture to the southern part of Nara Prefecture between August 18 and 19. The typhoon made landfall in eastern Kochi Prefecture shortly after 6 a.m. on the 19th, moved straight northward, traversed the Shikoku and Chugoku regions, and exited into the Sea of Japan on the 20th. According to records from Wakayama Prefecture, strong southwesterly winds began blowing around 3 a.m. on the 20th, accompanied by a low pressure of 711 mb and wind speeds of 40 m/s, striking the prefecture. Rain continued to fall until September 7. The maximum recorded rainfall in Wakayama Prefecture was a daily rainfall of 901.7 mm observed on the 20th in present-day Motomachi, Tanabe City, with a maximum hourly rainfall of 169.6 mm. In the Yoshino region of Nara Prefecture, the rainfall on the 19th exceeded 1,000 mm, with an estimated hourly rainfall of 130 mm.

In Totsukawa-go, Yoshino District, Nara Prefecture (now Totsukawa Village), large-scale landslides occurred in 1,080 locations. Sediment filled the valleys carved by the Totsukawa River (Kumano River), creating 37 natural dams and resulting in the appearance of many dammed lakes. Floods caused by the collapse of these natural dams led to extensive damage. The sediment deposits drastically altered the terrain, with an estimated average of 30 meters of sand and gravel accumulating on the riverbed. This disaster is recorded as a typical example of deep-seated landslides. Totsukawa-go, consisting of six villages—Kita-Totsukawa Village, Totsukawa Hanazono Village, Naka-Totsukawa Village, Nishi-Totsukawa Village, Minami-Totsukawa Village, and Higashi-Totsukawa Village—suffered significant losses: out of 12,862 residents, 168 died, 426 houses were completely destroyed or washed away, and including partially damaged houses, 610 houses, or one-fourth of the total 2,403 houses, were affected. Additionally, 226 hectares of farmland were buried or washed away, and the damage to forests was severe, leaving approximately 3,000 people without a livelihood. A prefectural official noted that "it may take about 30 years to restore to its original state." In October of the same year, 2,691 disaster victims relocated to Hokkaido, leading to the establishment of Shin-Totsukawa Village.

Whole_Text.header: The disaster situation as seen in "Yoshino District Flood Disaster Record"
Whole_Text.content:
"The 'Meiji 22 Yoshino District Flood Disaster Record' is a comprehensive record of this disaster compiled by the Uchi-Yoshino District Office and published in April 1891 (Meiji 24), consisting of 11 volumes. It conveys detailed records of 12 villages in the Yoshino District that were affected by the disaster. These 12 villages include six villages in the Totsukawa area, as well as Tenkawa Village, Oto Village (now part of Gojo City), Nosegawa Village upstream, and the villages of Sogibai (now part of Gojo City), Nanyoshino (now part of Shimoichi Town and Kurotaki Village), and Kanau (now part of Gojo City) located on the northern side of the watershed adjacent to the Kinokawa River system. Each volume is dedicated to one village, but Volume 10 combines two villages, Sogibai and Nanyoshino, into one, resulting in 11 volumes for 12 villages. 

The damage figures in the table above are summarized from the statistical tables at the end of each volume. The total figures for all villages are provided in the preface of Volume 1, and the figures for each village are included in the main text of each volume. Regarding the number of deaths, washed-away houses, and completely destroyed houses, there are slight discrepancies between the figures in the main text and the statistical tables for some villages, but they are mostly consistent. 

On the other hand, the number of large-scale landslides differs in five out of the 12 villages. For example, Sogibai Village is listed as having zero in the statistical table, but the main text records 101 locations. Summing up the figures in the main text for all villages results in 1,372 locations. Even if the discrepancies between the statistical tables and the main text are considered within a margin of error, the preface states the number of large-scale landslides as 247, which is significantly different. It is possible that the figure of 247 in the preface was a misprint of the survey figure of 1,147. The number of large-scale landslides refers to the occurrence of mountain collapses with dimensions of 50 ken (approximately 90 meters) or more in both length and width. Small-scale landslides occurred everywhere and were either ignored or described as countless depending on the region. 

The large-scale mountain collapses and the formation of new lakes caused by the disaster particularly struck the northern Totsukawa and western Totsukawa villages, as evident from the table above. The sediment from the mountain collapses blocked rivers that were carrying muddy torrents, creating new lakes. Eventually, as the water level rose, the water pressure increased, or the dam overflowed and eventually breached."

In Totsukawa, the river is called Kumano River downstream from the Nara-Wakayama prefectural border, and in Shingu Town (now Shingu City) at its mouth, damage was recorded, including 7 deaths and 591 houses washed away or completely destroyed. In Hongu Village (now Hongu-cho, Tanabe City) in the midstream of the Kumano River, the Kumano Hongu Taisha shrine buildings located on a sandbank were damaged and later relocated closer to the mountains.  

Meanwhile, in the Tonda River, which flows southward through central Wakayama Prefecture, a massive flood with a water level of 18 meters, unprecedented in past records, occurred according to the prefecture's investigation. In the area near the river mouth, now Shirahama Town, around 2 a.m. on the 19th, the embankments simultaneously collapsed, and the muddy torrent reportedly swept away "almost all houses, along with people, many livestock, timber, sand, and rocks, flowing downstream with a roaring sound toward the sea." Across the entire Tonda River basin, the reported damage included 565 deaths, 52 injuries, 749 houses washed away, 47 partially washed away, 459 completely destroyed, 148 partially destroyed, 136 cattle and horses killed, embankments broken in various places, and well-maintained rice fields turned into riverbeds. Some people from this region, like those from Totsukawa Village, migrated to Hokkaido as settlers or general residents.  

Additionally, major rivers in the prefecture, such as the Kinokawa, Aridagawa, Hidakagawa, Aizugawa, and Hiikigawa, experienced severe flooding, causing landslides and devastating damage to riverside settlements and farmland. The number of flooded towns and villages reached 2 towns and 178 villages, with a total death toll of 1,247 (including 565 in the Tonda River basin, 320 in the Aizugawa basin, 49 in the Hiikigawa basin, and 7 in the Kumano River basin). The damage also included 3,675 houses washed away, 1,524 completely destroyed, 2,344 partially destroyed, 33,081 flooded houses, 931 bridges washed away, 247 boats lost, 227 cattle and horses killed, 7,000 hectares of farmland washed away, and 1,072 embankment breaches.

Whole_Text.content: The Kanpō 2nd Year Edo Flood (Kanpō Ninen Edo Kōzui) refers to the damage suffered by Edo during the great flood and storm surge known as the "Kanpō Flood" that struck central Honshu, Japan, from July to August in 1742 (Kanpō 2nd year) according to the old calendar.

Around August 28, 1742 (July 28 in the old calendar of Kanpō 2), a typhoon-induced storm is believed to have struck the Kinai region, and rain began to fall in the Kanto region from this day onward. On the night of August 1, two days later, in Edo, heavy northeast winds initially began to blow along with the rain, but around midnight, the winds shifted to a violent south wind, bringing severe storms ("Zoku Musashi Abumi").

Furthermore, this wind brought storm surges from Edo Bay into the Sumida River and Arakawa River, causing water levels to rise from around dawn on the 2nd day, and by the 6th hour, coinciding with high tide, water levels in some areas rose 8 to 9 shaku (approximately 2.4 to 2.7 meters) above normal, flooding the low-lying areas of Edo with seawater. However, the force of the water at this time was not severe, and as the tide began to recede around the 5th hour, the water level started to drop. 

Meanwhile, around the same time, massive floods that occurred upstream in the Tone River, Arakawa River, and Tama River began flowing downstream toward Edo. Particularly, the water flow from the Tone River, where levees had been destroyed, swept away Sekiyado Castle and headed toward the low-lying areas of Edo. On the night of August 3 (September 1, 1742), just as the water had begun to recede and people in the low-lying areas of Edo were feeling relieved, the floodwaters struck directly. The water level continued to rise until August 7, during which over 900 people drowned in the Honjo, Asakusa, and Shitaya areas alone. According to a report by the town magistrate Masatomo Ishikawa, the water level in Honjo reached 5 shaku (approximately 1.5 meters) in the streets, and in some places, it reached 7 shaku (approximately 2.1 meters), submerging many houses up to their eaves. Additionally, many bridges, including Ryogoku Bridge, Shin-Ohashi Bridge, and Eitai Bridge, were swept away. 

However, on August 8, when the water level had begun to recede, another storm struck Edo, causing the water level to rise again. In Asakusa and Shitaya, the water level finally reached 1 jo (approximately 3 meters) ("Tokugawa Jikki"), and it took several more days for the water to recede. 

Concerned about this situation, the shogunate gathered boats and dispatched them to the low-lying areas, where the distinction between rivers and streets had disappeared, to rescue people being swept away or trembling on rooftops and trees. Furthermore, they distributed porridge and rice to the victims. According to records, the number of people receiving food aid was 6,000 on August 6, 10,000 at the peak of the disaster on August 8, and even on the 16th, when the water had receded and aid was limited to daytime, 7,000 people still required assistance. Additionally, some influential merchants in Edo, who suffered less damage, independently provided food aid. 

The shogunate ordered ten western domains, including Anotsu, Bizen, Choshu, and Higo, which had suffered less damage, to undertake the restoration of levees and irrigation channels along the Tone River and Arakawa River to bring the situation under control.

Whole_Text.header: Assistance construction by western feudal lords
Whole_Text.content:
On October 6, by the decision of the senior councilors Matsudaira Norisada, Matsudaira Nobutsugu, and Honda Tadayoshi, ten feudal lords from the western provinces were ordered to assist in construction work. In cases of construction assistance by feudal lords, the shogunate bore the cost of supplying necessary materials such as timber, pit wood, and iron, while the ordered feudal lords covered expenses for labor, bamboo and timber cutting, transportation, and so on. Each domain appointed senior retainers of the rank of chief retainer as general overseers and dispatched their retainers to the disaster site for restoration work. The shogunate ordered the lords of the Okayama, Tsu, Sabae, Izushi, Obi, and Usuki domains, who were present in Edo, to report directly to the castle, while sending official letters to other domains. 

In the case of the Kumamoto domain, on October 21, a letter from the shogunate's senior councilors was delivered to Kumamoto. Hasegawa Mondo, who served as both a magistrate and construction overseer, received the order and, after raising funds in Osaka, arrived in Edo later than other domain officials. Construction began on December 7. For on-site work and huts, contracts were given to influential townspeople and village headmen in Edo. On April 30 of the following year, senior retainers of the Kumamoto domain visited the private residence of a senior councilor to report that the construction was completed on April 29, and on May 1, they reported the same to Edo Castle. However, there were neither words of reprimand nor praise. The total expenditure of the Kumamoto domain amounted to 127,280 ryō. Although there were rewards from the shogunate, the amount was less than that given to smaller domains. Gifts from the Kumamoto domain to the shogunate were considered perks for officials, but some refused to accept them. The reason is unknown. Considering the amount spent, the Kumamoto domain judged that hiring contractors would have been cheaper, but Takasaki remarked that commercial spirit could not surpass the samurai code.
Rain clouds, believed to be a typhoon, are estimated to have moved from the west of Edo to the northeast, bringing record-breaking heavy rain to the Kanto and Shinshu regions.

The Kanpō Flood and Storm Surge refers to one of the largest-scale wind and water disasters in early modern Japan, which struck various regions of Kinki, Shin'etsu, and Kanto from July 28 (August 28, 1742) to August in the second year of Kanpō. Particularly severe damage was suffered in areas such as the Chikuma River basin and Edo.

The damage caused by the three days of storms on July 28, 29, and August 1 was immense. In Kyoto, the Sanjo Bridge was washed away, and floods struck Fushimi and Yodo downstream of the Katsura River. Additionally, in the Shinano Province, a flood known as "Inu no Mansui" occurred, and the Tone River, Arakawa River, and Tama River in the Kanto region all overflowed simultaneously. Particularly in Edo, located downstream of these rivers, the city was hit directly by a storm surge caused by the storm, flooding from the Tone River's embankment breach, and another storm on the 8th, believed to be separate. Many bridges, including the Ryogoku Bridge, were washed away, and the inundation of residences led to a large number of drowning deaths, causing significant damage, especially in the downtown areas (Kanpo 2nd Year Edo Flood). Significant damage also occurred in places like Takada in the Echigo Province.

The Inunomansui (Inu no Mansui) was a major flood that occurred in August 1742 (Kanpo 2) in the Chikuma River and Sai River basins of Shinano Province (present-day Nagano Prefecture). It was a large-scale disaster known as the "Kanpo Flood and Storm Surge," which struck central Honshu. The heavy rain is believed to have been caused by a typhoon that made landfall near Osaka, passed through the Kanto region, and exited into the Sanriku offshore area.

Since Kanpō 2 corresponds to the year of Mizunoe-inu (Water Dog), the heavily affected Chikuma River basin refers to it as the "Inu no Mansui" (Dog's Full Flood). In the Chikuma and Sai River basins of Shinano Province, the damage on the 1st day of the 8th month in the old calendar (August 30, 1742) was particularly severe. Even over 280 years later, a custom remains of visiting graves on August 1st in the new calendar to mourn the victims, separate from the traditional Obon grave visits. Some companies even list this day as a special holiday in their recruitment information.

The scale of the disaster is conveyed through local traditions, written records, and memorial monuments, with over 2,800 deaths across the basin and extensive loss of farmland, making it an unprecedented catastrophe. Not only did the main stream of the Chikuma River overflow and breach embankments, but small rivers in mountainous areas also flooded in various locations. It is estimated that the volume of water that overflowed was 232 million cubic kilometers.

Based on records from the pillars of Myoshoji Temple's main hall in Nagano City, flood level markers indicating the water levels during the flood have been erected in several locations in Nagano City and surrounding municipalities. Additionally, according to accounts, the water level near the current Tategahana water level observation point is estimated to have reached 36 shaku (10.9 meters).

Keiichi Yamada (1989) estimated that during the flood caused by Typhoon No. 7 in 1959 (Showa 34) (Tategahana water level 10.44m), the water volume of the Sai River system was about the same, but the water volume of the Chikuma River (Ueda and Saku regions) was approximately three times greater.

The Yokota Flood (Yokotagire) was a flood caused by the breach of the Shinano River embankment on July 22, 1896 (Meiji 29). Due to heavy rain that had continued for several days, the water level of the Shinano River rose, and the embankment in Yokota Village, Nishikanbara District, Niigata Prefecture (now Yokota, Tsubame City), breached in a section approximately 360 meters long, along with 874 other locations in the prefecture. As a result, a wide area up to Sekiya in Niigata City was flooded, with a damage area of 180 km². A total of 43,600 houses were flooded, both below and above floor level, and 25,000 houses were washed away. Furthermore, in low-lying areas, there were places where the water did not recede even by autumn, leading to the spread of infectious diseases such as dysentery and typhoid due to stagnant water rotting, resulting in many deaths. In response to this disaster, there was a growing call for the construction of a diversion channel in a section approximately 10 km long from Okawazu, Mishima District, Okawazu Village (now Okawazu, Tsubame City) to Nozumi Village, the same district (now Teradomari Nozumi, Nagaoka City). The Okawazu Diversion began its second phase of construction in 1907 (Meiji 40) and was completed with water flow starting on August 25, 1922 (Taisho 11).
