The Uetsu Heavy Rain (Uetsu Gouu) refers to a torrential downpour that occurred from August 26 to August 29, 1967 (Showa 42). It is also called the Uetsu Flood, and in the affected areas, it is sometimes referred to by dates such as the 8/28 Flood. As the name "Uetsu" suggests, the damage was concentrated mainly in Yamagata Prefecture and the Kaetsu region of Niigata Prefecture. It caused significant damage, resulting in 104 deaths, and was designated as a severe disaster. This disaster prompted a review of flood control plans for rivers such as the Arakawa, Tainai River, and Mogami River.

Around August 26, the atmospheric pressure pattern featured a stationary front extending east-west from the Sea of Japan, lingering from the southern Tohoku region to the northern part of the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture. This was a typical late rainy season situation prone to triggering torrential rains. Warm, moist air from the south flowed into the front, stimulating it and resulting in heavy rainfall. Particularly in the region from southern Yamagata Prefecture to northern Niigata Prefecture, centered around the Iide Mountain Range, record-breaking torrential rains fell, causing the worst flooding in history for rivers sourced in this area, including the Mogami River, Miomote River, Arakawa River, Tainai River, and Kaji River.

The damage caused by this heavy rain was the worst since the post-war period in Niigata and Yamagata Prefectures at the time. However, there are some discrepancies in the reported details of the damage. The Japan Meteorological Agency adopts the damage details based on the Fire White Paper published by the Fire and Disaster Management Agency of the Ministry of Home Affairs. Currently, the damage situation differs depending on each report. Here, the damage situation is presented in a combined form based on the latest information from Niigata and Yamagata Prefectures.

The majority of the damage was concentrated in areas such as Murakami City, Shibata City, Iwafune District, and Kitakanbara District in the Kaetsu region of Niigata Prefecture. Additionally, a torrential downpour (Kaetsu Flood) had occurred on July 17 of the previous year, 1966 (Showa 41), and as the damage from that event had not yet been fully restored, another torrential downpour struck, further exacerbating the damage. The most severe damage occurred in the Arakawa River basin. In this area, a torrential rainfall of approximately 700 millimeters over 30 hours was recorded in Sekikawa Village, Iwafune District. As a result, the Arakawa River and its tributary, the Oishigawa River, overflowed, causing levees to collapse in various locations. The town was buried in muddy water and rocks that flowed down from upstream. This resulted in 34 deaths and 371 houses being completely or partially destroyed in Sekikawa Village alone, with total damages amounting to 17.7 billion yen, which was 60 times the village's annual budget (approximately 300 million yen) at the time. Additionally, the Iwafune Power Plant of Arakawa Hydroelectric Power, constructed on the Arakawa River, suffered damage to its power generation equipment due to flooding caused by the heavy rain. However, the Iwafune Dam, which serves as the intake point, was not significantly affected.

In the Tainai River basin, the Tainai No. 1 Dam of the Niigata Prefecture Enterprise Bureau recorded a total daily rainfall of 645 millimeters, while the Tainai No. 1 Power Plant recorded 542 millimeters. In Nakajo Town and Kurokawa Village (both now part of Tainai City) in Kitakanbara District, levees collapsed at Akagawa in the midstream area and Atsutazaka in the downstream area of the Tainai River, resulting in the flooding of 2,170 houses and 2,330 hectares of farmland and other areas. In the Miomote River basin, a torrential rainfall of 391.5 millimeters was recorded over two days in the upstream area, and flooding damage expanded in Murakami City downstream. In the Kajikawa River basin, torrential rainfall of 496 millimeters was recorded in one day at the Kajikawa Dam of Tohoku Electric Power, with over 300 millimeters recorded in various locations.

As a result, levees that had collapsed during the torrential downpour of the previous year in the Nishinagara area of Shibata City and Mukainakajo in Kajikawa Village (now part of Shibata City) collapsed again. Tributaries such as the Himedagawa River and Sakaigawa River also overflowed, causing Shibata City to suffer significant damage for the second consecutive year. In Murasugi Onsen in Sasakami Village, Yoshio Sato, a local member of the House of Councillors who was on vacation, was caught in a landslide and died. In the Agano River system, the Fukushima Swamp overflowed, causing flooding in surrounding areas, and in Sado, the Kokufu River overflowed, resulting in flooding damage.

In the Kaetsu region, all major rivers, including the Agano River, Kajikawa River, Tainai River, Arakawa River, and Miomote River, overflowed, flooding surrounding areas. The extent of the flooding encompassed most of the lowlands from the southern bank of the Miomote River to the northern bank of the Agano River, creating a situation that resembled the birth of a new lake. As a result, major transportation routes such as National Routes 7, 49, and 113, as well as the Uetsu Main Line and Yonesaka Line of Japanese National Railways, were disrupted by flooding and landslides. The Yonesaka Line took 89 days to be restored, highlighting the significant damage to the region's transportation infrastructure. The total damage in Niigata Prefecture, when converted to current monetary value, amounted to an extremely large sum of approximately 333.8 billion yen.

In Yamagata Prefecture, damage was particularly concentrated in the Okitama region in the southern part of the prefecture. The damage within the prefecture included 8 deaths, 137 injuries, 167 houses destroyed, 10,818 houses flooded above floor level, 11,016 houses flooded below floor level, and 13,180 hectares of farmland inundated, with the total damage estimated at 22.638 billion yen. When converted to the current monetary value, this amounts to an enormous loss of approximately 66.11 billion yen. In Oguni Town, Nishiokitama District, which suffered particularly severe damage, the Arakawa River and its tributary Yokokawa River overflowed, causing flooding within the town. In the mountainous areas, landslides and debris flows occurred frequently, leading to significant impacts such as the entire community of 4 households and 18 residents in the Koedo district abandoning their settlement and relocating. Additionally, the Akashiba Power Plant, owned by Toshiba Denko at the time, was flooded by muddy waters, damaging its power generation equipment and affecting the operations of Toshiba Denko's Oguni Manufacturing Plant (now owned by Covalent Materials), a major industry in Oguni Town. The total damage in Oguni Town amounted to approximately 7.8 billion yen, equivalent to 20 years of the village's budget being wiped out overnight. Furthermore, in the Mogami River system, the Okitama Shirakawa, Okitama Nogawa, and Sagae Rivers overflowed. The Mogami River, where these rivers converge, also experienced flooding that breached levees in Shirataka Town, causing inundation not only in the Okitama region, including Yonezawa City and Nagai City, but also in the Murayama region, including Sagae City. In the Okitama region, in particular, debris flows and driftwood surged downstream, leading to the loss of bridges and further exacerbating the damage.

This heavy rain caused floods that fundamentally overturned the flood control measures that had been implemented traditionally. Normally, the planned maximum water flow is determined based on the worst floods in the past, but during the Uetsu heavy rain, floods exceeding the planned maximum water flow were recorded in almost all rivers. This was due to the record-breaking heavy rain that fell upstream, forcing the Ministry of Construction (now the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism), Niigata Prefecture, and Yamagata Prefecture to fundamentally review their flood control measures. As a result, various measures such as strengthening and extending embankments, widening river widths, and renovating bridges that obstruct water flow were undertaken, but the most focused effort was the construction of dams to control floods in the upstream areas.

First, regarding the Arakawa river system, which became the most severely affected area, the river classification, initially a secondary river, was upgraded to a primary river in 1968. A basic plan for the implementation of construction on the Arakawa river system was formulated, incorporating flood control measures directly managed by the national government. At this time, a plan was made to construct two multipurpose dams in the Arakawa river system. For the main stream of the Arakawa River, there was a post-war plan in 1952 to construct the Arakawa No. 1 Dam and Arakawa No. 2 Dam for flood control. However, since water rights for the Akashiba Power Plant had already been acquired, proceeding with the plan would have submerged the Akashiba Dam, leading to the eventual abandonment of the plan. Subsequently, with the completion of the Iwafune Dam, there were no promising sites for dam construction on the main stream of the Arakawa River. Therefore, a plan was developed to construct dams on the tributaries Oishigawa and Yokokawa, resulting in the completion of the Oishi Dam (Oishigawa) in 1979 and the Yokokawa Dam (Yokokawa) in 2008. Since the completion of the Oishi Dam, no flood disasters causing fatalities have occurred in the Arakawa area.

Regarding the Mogami River system, it had already been designated as a primary river in 1965, and the basic plan for flood control projects, the Mogami River System Construction Implementation Basic Plan, was also formulated in the same year. However, following the damage caused by the Uetsu Heavy Rain, the plan was revised in 1974, adopting a policy of flood control measures using multipurpose dams, similar to the Arakawa River. The Mogami River system had already been designated under the Mogami Special Regional Comprehensive Development Plan following the enactment of the National Comprehensive Development Act in 1950, with river improvements and dam construction carried out in the northern part of the prefecture. This time, however, the focus shifted to river improvements in the southern part of the prefecture, which is the upstream region of the Mogami River. Since there were no suitable sites for dam construction on the main stream of the Mogami River, the plan included the construction of the Okubo Retarding Basin on the main stream and multipurpose dams on three tributaries that had suffered significant damage: Okitama Shirakawa, Okitama Nogawa, and Sagae River. As a result, the Shirakawa Dam (Okitama Shirakawa) was completed in 1981, the Sagae Dam (Sagae River) in 1990, and the Okubo Retarding Basin in 1997. The last remaining Nagai Dam (Okitama Nogawa) was completed in 2011. 

Thanks to this river improvement, during the torrential rains that hit the Mogami River basin in 1997, which were of a similar scale to the Uetsu Heavy Rain, the damage was minimized to 67 flooded houses, demonstrating the effectiveness of the flood control measures. It is worth noting that there was strong opposition to the Shirakawa Dam at the time, but compensation agreements with residents of the planned submerged area were rapidly concluded following the Uetsu Heavy Rain, highlighting the significant impact of the heavy rain disaster.

In Niigata Prefecture, plans were made for multipurpose dams and flood control dams on the Sanmen River, Tainai River, and Kaji River, which are secondary rivers under its jurisdiction. The Sanmen Dam, the first multipurpose dam in the prefecture, was completed on the Sanmen River in 1953. However, following the Uetsu Heavy Rain, a large-scale flood control dam plan was devised upstream of the Sanmen Dam. This became the Oku-Sanmen Dam, which was later expanded into a multipurpose dam in 1976 and completed in 2001 as one of the largest dams in the prefecture. There was also a plan to construct the Takane River Dam on the Takane River, a tributary, but this plan was abandoned. Regarding the Tainai River, the Tainai River Dam was completed in 1976, and the Oku-Tainai Dam is currently under construction upstream. 

On the Kaji River, the Kaji River Flood Control Dam, one of the largest flood control dams in Japan, was completed on the main stream in 1974. Additionally, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (formerly the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry) participated as a flood control operator in the construction of an agricultural dam on the tributary Uchinokura River, completing the Uchinokura Dam in 1972. Regarding Fukushima Swamp, the Fukushima Swamp Drainage Channel was constructed to discharge internal water from the swamp directly into the Sea of Japan. 

The effects of these river improvements were evident during the Niigata-Fukushima Heavy Rain in 2004. While flooding damage was significant in the Shinano River system, the four rivers mentioned above experienced no notable flooding damage. In Yamagata Prefecture, the Tunagi River Dam (on the Tunagi River) was completed in 2006 to strengthen flood control measures in the Onimen River basin. 

To ensure the memory of the Uetsu Heavy Rain does not fade, Niigata and Yamagata Prefectures held numerous events related to the Uetsu Heavy Rain in 2007, marking the 40th anniversary of the disaster, to raise awareness among residents about the damage caused by the heavy rain. In Sekikawa Village, the "Echigo Sekikawa Great Snake Festival," held annually since 1988, takes place on the anniversary of the Uetsu Heavy Rain. The festival is held to pass on the memory of the flood to future generations. The giant snake used as a portable shrine is usually stored at the Oishi Dam and has a total length of 82.8 meters, a number associated with the date of the heavy rain. This reflects how deeply the Uetsu Heavy Rain remains a tragic and unforgettable memory for Sekikawa Village. The festival received the Handmade Hometown Award in fiscal year 2016.

Article_Name: Powodzie w Toruniu – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: This article has been submitted for inclusion on the main page in the "Did you know" section. Help us review it: evaluate the submitted nomination. Floods in Toruń – characteristics of the occurrence of floods in the history of Toruń, caused by the rising water level in the Vistula River. Toruń is the largest city in the Chełmno Land located on the Vistula River[1]. Due to the lack of systematic measurements using objective scales, information about floods and other meteorological and climatic phenomena in Toruń until the end of the 18th century is incomplete[2]. The primary source of information about floods in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries are narrative city chronicles[3]. Systematic measurements of the water level in the Vistula began after 1760[4].

Toruń has been dealing with floods since its very beginning. Frequent floods between 1233 and 1236 forced the Teutonic Order to relocate the settlement from Old Toruń to its current location. According to historian Piotr Oliński, in the 15th–18th centuries, there were dozens of floods in the Chełmno land area, with several of them being extensive. Information about the flood of 1465/1466 comes from several sources, the oldest being records by the parish priest at the church of St. John, H. Waldau, written between 1481 and 1495. The flood reportedly destroyed ships, most of the city baths, the municipal slaughterhouse, and damaged the church of St. John, vineyards, and some residences. In the 16th century, major floods occurred in 1534, 1570, 1584, and 1593, and in the 17th century in 1611 (winter), 1628 (summer), and 1673. Between 1673 and 1718, there were no significant floods in Toruń. Another major flood occurred in the spring of 1719 when ice breaking on the Vistula River caused water to flow into the Bridge Gate. This flood caused significant material damage to the residents of the Vistula lowlands. Subsequent floods occurred in 1729, 1736 (summer), 1740 (spring), 1744, and 1745. Floods frequently damaged the wooden bridge built in 1500. In the 19th century, floods occurred in 1871, 1879, and 1891. During these floods, water reached the height of the Racławice Barracks, and in 1891, water also flowed into the Bridge Gate. Information about these floods comes from preserved flood markers. In July 1934, Toruń faced the largest flood in interwar Poland. During the 2001 flood, the water level exceeded 700 cm. The Vistula River flooded the lowest-lying areas of the city. During the 2010 flood, approximately 1,300 hectares of urban land were flooded. The water inundated, among other places, the Philadelphia Boulevard, the viaduct on Podgórska Street, Kaszczorek, allotment gardens in Rudak, and areas near ks. Popiełuszki and Przybyszewskiego Streets. On May 23, 2010, the water level exceeded 859 cm.

The Flood of the Oathbreaker or the Flood of Valariko was a major flood that occurred in Finland in the spring of 1899. The flood got its name from the fact that in February 1899, the Emperor of Russia and Grand Duke of Finland, Nicholas II, issued the February Manifesto, which curtailed Finland's autonomous status and, according to the Finnish perception, broke the ruler's oath he had given to Finland. The causes of the flood were several preceding rainy years, the snowy winter of 1898–1899, and the rainy and warm spring of 1899. The flood particularly affected the water systems of the Kokemäenjoki, Kymijoki, and Vuoksi rivers. For example, the water level of Lake Päijänne was 193 cm higher than normal. The recurrence of such a flood is estimated to be 100–150 years. The Flood of the Oathbreaker gave a decisive impetus to the establishment of the Hydrographic Office, the predecessor of the Finnish Environment Institute. A committee set up by the Finnish Senate in the summer of 1899 to investigate flood damages estimated the flood damages of 1898–1899 to be approximately 10 million marks. The floods did not claim human lives; only one horse with its cart drowned.

The lines called Valapaton lines or Valarikko lines refer to marks on coastal cliffs indicating the record-high water level from the year 1899. Valapaton lines can still be seen in many places, and they still show the water level from that year. Some Valapaton lines were painted red.

Article_Name: Història de les inundacions de Girona - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: History of the floods of Girona
Whole_Text.content: Throughout history, there have been many floods in Girona. This city, the capital of the Gironès region, located between the Gavarres and Guilleries massifs, and where four rivers converge – the Ter, the Onyar, the Galligants, and the Güell, which give it the nickname "the city of four rivers" – has experienced around 150 flood episodes (mostly fluvial) since the first one was documented in 1193. Most of the floods have been caused by the overflow of the rivers (often more than one at the same time), and the period when they are most frequent is during the last part of the year (from September to December). The most significant documented floods occurred in 1843 (with more than a hundred victims), in 1940 (known as the Aiguat de Sant Lluc, which caused between 6 and 15 victims and numerous affected people), and in 1970 (with major material damage). Due to the frequent hydrological catastrophes, the city of Girona has adapted over time to try to mitigate their effects.

Whole_Text.header: Situation and hydrological characteristics of Girona
Whole_Text.content: The city of Girona, capital of the province of Girona and the region of Gironès, is located between the massifs of Les Guilleries and Les Gavarres. Four rivers converge there: the Ter, the Onyar, the Galligants, and the Güell.

Girona is crossed by four watercourses (the Ter, the Onyar, the Galligants, and the Güell), and it has been given the nickname "the city of four rivers." The most important of the four is the Ter, which originates in the town of Ulldeter, in Ripollès, and flows into the beach of Pals, in Baix Empordà. It has a nivo-pluvial regime and reaches its peak flow during the month of May; however, currently, there are several reservoirs along its course (Sau, Susqueda, and Pasteral) that make the river's flow highly regulated. The other three rivers contribute their water: the Onyar and the Güell directly, while the Galligants flows into the Onyar. In fact, the Güell flowed into the Onyar until 1968, when it was channeled and diverted to the Ter due to the numerous floods it caused. Apart from the four rivers, there are or have been other watercourses such as streams, torrents, and irrigation channels, such as the Monar Canal or the Bullidors stream.

Most of the floods in Girona have been a consequence of river overflows, although in more recent times a phenomenon known as diffuse flooding (or sheet flow) has also occurred, which happens when the city's drainage systems reach their capacity limit and cannot process all the incoming water. Since the first recorded floods, around the 12th-13th centuries, approximately 150 flood episodes have occurred. Most of the floods are concentrated in the months of the last third of the year.

The first serious documented floods of the city of Girona occurred in the year 1193 (according to Ribas 2007) or in the years 1377 and 1380, a few years after the Black Death of 1347-48 (according to Pla 1985). In the years 1421, 1425, and 1445 – when Girona was the capital of the Girona-Besalú vegueria – there were also significant floods: the second caused damage to the bridge connecting Pedret with the opposite bank of the Ter, and the third completely destroyed it. It seems that the cause of the floods was the narrowness of the Onyar riverbed and the accumulation of debris on both sides. The official-archivist Francesc Oliver wrote the following report in 1366 (originally in Spanish): "[...] intercepting the course of the Onyar waters with that immense mass they placed within its bed" (referring to the new constructions erected in the Plaça de les Cols and Sant Feliu). As for the Ter, it was a river that easily overflowed; when it did, the Onyar could not discharge its flow, which caused serious problems.

During the 16th century, the floods did not cease either: in 1519, the church of Sant Nicolau suffered severe damage and had to be reinforced; floods also occurred in 1533, 1534, 1552 – known as the Aiguat de Sant Lluc, not to be confused with the flood of 1940; without victims, the municipal archivist Julián de Chía wrote that "all summer of the following year, boats were navigated from the gate of Sant Feliu to the Stone Bridge" – 1575, 1579, and a particularly strong one in 1599 that caused the collapse of about 56 meters of wall and two houses, as well as the death of more than twenty people. These floods were followed by others in 1603, 1617 – popularly known as the Aiguat del Diluvi; it was one of the most catastrophic in the city's history, although it left no victims, and affected much of Catalonia – 1623, 1625, 1626, 1645, 1663 – in which the Ter river brought down part of the Mercadal wall, which had to be rebuilt – 1678 – which collapsed the bridge connecting the Argenteria with Sant Agustí and caused two deaths – and 1669 – in which the Ter also broke the city's protective dike.

The 18th century began with the reconstruction of the Sant Agustí bridge, destroyed by the 1678 flood, which was built with two arches. However, it was demolished by another flood in 1737. During this century, there were also other episodes of flooding in the years 1716, 1726, 1732, 1735, 1763 – Santa Teresa Flood – and 1777. During the 19th century – a period when the city had about 6,000 inhabitants – the floods continued: they occurred in the years 1801, 1802, 1814, 1819, 1826, 1828, 1829 – particularly severe –, 1840, 1843 – caused more than a hundred victims; see below –, 1850, 1853, 1861 – 70 houses collapsed and two victims –, 1872, 1884, 1897, and 1898.

On September 18 and 19, 1843, Girona suffered one of the most catastrophic floods in its history. After several days of rain, on the morning of the 18th, all four rivers overflowed, and although the rain stopped in the afternoon, around midnight there was a strong storm over Sant Daniel that greatly increased the waters of the Galligants River. The Sant Pere neighborhood was destroyed, and the entire lower part of the city was flooded. The waters severely damaged the monastery of Sant Pere de Galligants and swept away the image of the Virgin of Remedy, which was later recovered. The flood caused more than a hundred victims; the exact number is unknown: various sources (such as the city archivist's chronicle or the city council's report) place it between 115 and 160.

On October 7, 1919, the first significant flooding of the city during the 20th century occurred when the Ter River overflowed near Pasteral, and in a short time, the uncontrolled waters reached the city and joined those of the Güell and Onyar rivers. There is no record of any casualties, but it caused significant material damage to the northern orchards of the city (Devesa area and the neighborhoods of Mercadal, Sant Pere de Galligants, and Pedret). Other notable floods include those that occurred in Amer in September 1926, which were immortalized by Valentí Fargnoli Annetta with his camera and significantly affected the Ter downstream of Girona, destroying several bridges and altering the riverbed. In Catalonia, this flood was known as the Sant Ramon flood. The so-called Sant Lluc flood, which began on October 18, 1940, and lasted three to four days, was one of the most devastating ever recorded in the Girona region (although the most affected area in Catalonia was Osona). The overflow of the Ter (which flooded the entire Devesa), the Onyar (which reached two meters in height in the old town), and the Güell (which collapsed the Mart bridge) caused the death of about ten people (including Lieutenant Huarte, who died helping to save people and after whom a current bridge is named) and significant damage to the city, which was just recovering from the Spanish Civil War. The newspaper El Pirineo on the evening of October 18 reported the following: "The waters, bursting through the city, have flooded the lower streets at both ends, reaching streets and squares where they had only rarely reached before. [...] The maximum height reached by the waters of the Ter as they passed through our city was more than seven meters above the ordinary level, spanning a width of three kilometers." The 1960s saw the last three major floods, in 1962, 1963, and 1970. Of the three, the one on October 12, 1970, was the most significant: water levels reached 1.26 meters on Ballesteries Street (Old Town) in the flood that caused the most damage throughout the century. The Onyar River, after breaking a retaining wall, invaded the city's streets, while the Güell and the Massana stream flooded the Sant Narcís neighborhood. There were no fatalities, but 2,000 people were affected, and losses amounted to 500 million pesetas.

In the 14th century, after the floods, the Areny area (or "Areny tables") was used as farmland. At the end of the 15th century, a dam with gates was built in the northern sector of Girona, which was heavily criticized by the residents of the lower part of the city. There was also a dam at the mouth of the Galligants, which was demolished in 1589. In the 18th century, Girona's residents believed that the La Manola dam, located in Pedret, was the cause of the periodic floods that plagued the city. After the flood of 1732, they requested the city council, through the military governor, to demolish the dam, which experts did not approve; however, the dam was later demolished in the year XXX. In 1722, a water defense wall and a railing were built to counter the action of the Ter. At the beginning of the 19th century, a plan was proposed to divert the Ter river through Puig d'en Roca; the project was not carried out due to its high economic cost. During this same century, alert systems (bell tolls, gunshots, etc.) were used to warn of floods, and an evacuation system for people was also studied, using wooden bridges, openings in party walls, etc., which worked quite well in most cases except during the flood of 1843, due to its exceptional magnitude. Due to the floods caused by the Onyar river in 1970, a series of works were carried out between that year and 1972 on the riverbed as it passed through the city to prevent similar future events, giving the basin a prismatic concrete shape. On the other hand, the construction of the Pasteral and Susqueda dams contributed significantly to reducing the flow of the Ter river. The Güell was also channeled between 1965 and 1968.

Whole_Text.content: The Vesleofsen is a flood that hit Eastern Norway in June 1995. One man died, and 7,000 people were evacuated. The damages caused by the flood are estimated at 1.8 billion kroner. In Glomma, the flood peaked on June 2, in Gudbrandsdalslågen on June 3, and in Mjøsa on June 11. 3.5 million sandbags were used in Akershus, Hedmark, and Oppland to contain the water. The flood was the fifth extreme weather event officially recorded in the country and the first to hit Eastern Norway after the Meteorological Institute began issuing extreme weather warnings in 1994. However, the extreme weather did not have an official name, as this type of weather was given later in the year (Agnar in October 1995). The flood was unofficially called "Vesleofsen" since it was the second-largest flood since Storofsen in 1789. However, the flood size in 1995 was larger if adjusted for flood mitigation in the reservoirs in Østerdalen.

The Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate (NVE) had observed larger amounts of snow than usual early in the winter. At the beginning of May, the weather became warmer, and the snowmelt started as normal. On May 8, the Meteorological Institute reported colder weather, and the next day NVE issued a press release stating that delayed snowmelt could lead to major flooding. Until May 22, there were freezing temperatures in the mountains and very little snowmelt. After that, the temperature rose sharply, both in the mountains and in forested areas. The maximum temperature reached 15-20°C, while it also started raining between May 27 and June 2. NVE measured 10-15 mm of rain per day in some places in Eastern Norway. Several water reservoirs were emptied to make room for the expected water volumes.

At Elverum, the Glomma River surpassed its previous highest level of the century (1934) on May 31. When the flood peaked at Stai on June 2, the river was 70 cm above the 1934 flood and 61 cm below the Storofsen flood. A flood marker indicating the maximum water flow has been erected at the Norwegian Forest Museum. The flood wave passed Kongsvinger on June 3, and most of the lower-lying areas along the Glomma were flooded. When the flood wave passed Rånåsfoss on June 5, it had a speed of nearly 1 m/s and a water flow of 4,000 m³/s.
The river surpassed the floods in 1927, 1934, and 1967, reaching its peak on June 1. The river then had a flow rate of 760 m³/s at Nybergsund.
Culminated on June 3rd.

NVE decided to close one of the gates at Svanfossen to hold back water until the flood peak from Glomma had passed the outlet to Vorma and Øyeren. From June 2, Mjøsa rose by about 2 cm per hour. Many flood barriers were built to prevent the flood from reaching the lowest-lying buildings. When the flood peaked on June 11, it was at 7.94 meters in Hamar, lower than the forecasts but 20 cm higher than the 1967 flood. To prevent contaminated floodwater from entering the Vikingskipet, it was filled with freshwater before Mjøsa reached the level of the ship.

Elva Moksa lies near Tretten. On June 2, it broke out of its usual riverbed and found a new path through the center of the town. Several houses and buildings were swept away by the water masses or completely destroyed.

The Gauldal landslide was a sand and gravel slide followed by a flood disaster in Gauldalen in 1345. The slide and flooding are often referred to as Norway's largest natural disaster in history. According to Icelandic sources, the slide occurred on the Feast of the Cross, September 14, 1345. There are not many sources from this time that mention the slide. The first source, the Skålholt Annals, written three years after the slide, and two other sources, the Lawman's Annals and the Flatøy Annals, contain information about the event. Additionally, oral tradition and geological interpretations have contributed to explaining the event. According to the old sources, the slide occurred at Kvasshylla, or the Haga farm, three kilometers north of Støren. The slide dammed the Gaula River and created a lake, sometimes referred to as Hagavatnet, which stretched 14 kilometers up the valley to Bones. Up the valley, 25 farms were flooded and completely destroyed. Eventually, the dam, which must have been between 30 m and 40 m high, collapsed, and large amounts of loose material and water flooded the valley all the way down to Melhus. Over 50 farms and seven churches are said to have been destroyed by the slide and flooding, and over 500 people perished. Recent estimates indicate that a slide likely occurred at Kvasshylla so long ago. The estimates show that the slide must have been at least 45 million cubic meters if it is true that the lake stretched all the way up to Bones. The dam must have been at least 33 m high for the lake to have stretched so far up the valley. The Gauldal landslide was nevertheless not as large as the Verdal landslide, but many more people perished in Gauldalen. Why so many perished may perhaps be related to the fact that it was in the middle of a pilgrimage route. One of the oldest sources actually mentions that about 250 travelers and over 250 residents lost their lives in the slide. The slide in Gauldalen covered a much larger area than the Verdal landslide. The entire valley from Bones far up the valley and all the way down to Melhus was destroyed, mainly due to the flood after the dam burst. It has been claimed that the slide was a clay slide, but a dissertation published in 2001 proves that it was sand and gravel that slid out.

The flood on the Vltava River in September 1890, during which the pillars of Charles Bridge were partially destroyed, had a similar course to the flood of 2002. A frontal wave from northern Italy brought significant rainfall to the Vltava River basin between September 1 and 4, causing the river to overflow its banks. The flood peaked on September 3 in České Budějovice and on September 6 in Děčín on the Elbe River. The peak flow in Prague reached 3975 m³/s. The flood also affected Písek and Plzeň.

The flood in the Kyjov and Břeclav regions occurred on Tuesday, June 9, 1970. It was a summer flash flood on the left tributaries of the Dyje River, especially Trkmanka and Kyjovka, caused by an extraordinary local cloudburst primarily in the Kyjov area in the Ždánice Forest region. Overall, the flood affected 20 municipalities in the Kyjov and Břeclav regions. It claimed 35 lives, severely damaged several roads and railway lines, flooded about 400 houses, seriously damaged 100 houses, and demolished 15 buildings.

The weather forecast for the ČSSR predicted partly cloudy to cloudy skies for this day, with local showers and thunderstorms. In the afternoon, three storm cores formed over southern Moravia, accompanied by intense rainfall, with precipitation totals of 32.7 mm in the Prostějov area and 76.0 mm in the Brno area. However, significantly more water fell in the Kyjov area, where the ČHMÚ rain gauge station in Ždánice recorded a total of 133.6 mm between 16:10 and 19:20. The rainfall thus significantly exceeded the general threshold for a cloudburst (70 mm in 3 hours). The most affected area was approximately 200 to 250 km² northwest and west of Kyjov. The purely local nature of the storms is evidenced by the fact that other stations in the vicinity recorded significantly lower precipitation totals (Kyjov 39.3 mm, Koryčany 34.3 mm, Klobouky u Brna 23.2 mm, and Bučovice 15.2 mm). Small and sometimes temporarily drying streams in this area swelled to multiple times their usual flow rates within minutes.

The most tragic consequences of the flood occurred below Stavěšice. The Šardice stream spread to a width of 150 meters, flooding the undermined area of the Dukla lignite mine in Šardice, which it flowed near. Local terrain depressions immediately filled with water, which then broke into the interior of the mine, and the tunnels were soon flooded with mudflows. At that moment, 110 miners were working in the mine, and 34 of them perished. Several hundred meters away in Šardice, the Church of St. Michael the Archangel was also flooded to a height of 50 cm, although according to the oldest records, it had never been flooded before. Below the confluence with the Kyjovka stream, the flood wave dissipated, causing practically no damage. However, the Kyjovka indirectly caused the last victim of the flood when a three-year-old girl (Lenka Šťastná) fell into a flooded cellar in Kyjov. The floodwaters also heavily affected the village of Lovčice, located on a gentle slope at the southwestern edge of the Ždánice Forest. The water reservoir on the Jordánek stream, situated at the very beginning of the village, could not withstand the influx of water from the terrain. After its dam broke, the flood wave was further amplified by the reservoir's existing supply. The water rushed into the village so quickly that in one house, people had to break through the ceiling to escape the rising water. Often, people fled their homes with only the clothes they were wearing. In the village, 128 houses were flooded, another 49 were slightly damaged, five houses were demolished, and seven were completely destroyed, but there were no casualties. The surge of water from Lovčice then rushed down the Lovčice stream valley into the Trkmanka river. Below its confluence with the Soudný stream, it first flooded the village of Dražůvky, where a pond dam also broke, and where children from a kindergarten had to be rescued at great risk to life. The flood surge also destroyed bridges and practically demolished three houses. The widening valley below the village of Želetice was flooded to a width of up to 300 meters, but other villages downstream experienced almost no damage. In a valley further west, the Zdravá Voda stream flooded part of the village of Žarošice, where the water rose to the steps of the cultural center, but without significant recorded damage. The floods damaged not only local bridges but also more significant transportation structures. Road I/54 between Žarošice and Strážovice had to be closed due to the undermining of part of its structure and two bridges. Road I/51 between Krumvíř and Terezín was passable only for trucks. The Čejč–Ždánice railway line, which follows the Trkmanka river, was completely destroyed over a stretch of approximately 300 meters. Near Bohuslavice, the railway line Brno–Kyjov–Trenčianska Teplá was damaged, with one track adjacent to the Kyjovka river being taken out of service. Near Velké Pavlovice, the embankment of the D2 highway under construction from Brno to Bratislava was partially damaged. Flooding, erosion, mudflows, and deposits also rendered crops on 9,000 hectares of farmland unusable.

During the peak of political normalization, party and state authorities reported on the catastrophic consequences of this flood almost exclusively in connection with the human tragedy at the Dukla mine. The Minister of Labor and Social Affairs of the Czech Socialist Republic, Emilian Hamerník, was sent to the site of the disaster. The nationwide daily Rudé právo, published by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, reported on the natural disaster with an extensive article on the front page of the newspaper on Thursday, June 11, 1970, focusing mainly on the rescue efforts at the Šardice Dukla mine, while information about other damages was significantly more concise. The South Moravian regional daily Rovnost, published by the local Regional Committee of the Communist Party, reported on the event only on Friday, June 12, 1970: "The exceptional scale of Tuesday's cloudburst is evidenced by the fact that within two hours, 195 mm of water fell in a relatively small area. For comparison, this is approximately one-third of the usual annual rainfall in this region." Rudé právo then wrote daily on the front page about efforts to rescue the miners, continued with the publication of a communiqué from the government of the Czech Socialist Republic titled "We bow before the memory of the fallen heroes of labor" on Wednesday, June 17, 1970, followed by expressions of condolences the next day, and concluded with information about the mourning ceremony for the deceased miners held in Dubňany on Monday, June 22, 1970, even though most of the deceased were still inside the partially flooded mine. During those days, the South Moravian region was hit by new cloudbursts, which, however, caused only material damage. The indignant voices of miners and survivors, pointing out, among other things, the low safety of the mining operation, whose operator neglected the remediation of terrain subsidence and thus allowed the accumulation of surface water directly above the mine, received no publicity. The flood was one of the reasons for the construction of the Zápověď reservoir, located several hundred meters from the Dukla mine upstream of the Šardice stream. It is speculated that poor information about natural disasters may have been the cause of the great surprise of the public and rescue services during the major floods of 1997 and 2002.

The flood that inundated a vast area from Mělník to Kralupy nad Vltavou in February 1893 was caused by an accumulation of ice floes. The ice floes, released by thawing north of Prague, got stuck at the confluence of the Vltava and Elbe rivers, creating a natural dam. The water rose by several meters, and the accumulated floes formed two-meter-high barriers. In some places, the flood exceeded the level of the 1890 flood (which had destroyed Charles Bridge). After several days, the deposited floes were removed using explosives. The flood destroyed a large part of the village of Lahovice and caused the departure of its inhabitants, as well as the relocation of the village's center from Lahovice to Lahovičky.

The flood in Bohemia in 1784 was a major flood that affected mainly the basins of the Vltava and Elbe rivers at the turn of February and March.

As a result of the eruptions of the Icelandic volcano Laki (Lakagigar) from the summer of 1783, there were significant climate fluctuations. This included an exceptionally harsh winter in Europe, during which rivers froze and large amounts of snow accumulated in the mountains. This was followed by a sudden warming and melting of large amounts of snow at the end of February and the beginning of March.

This change in weather, accompanied by heavy rains, occurred in Central and Western Europe after February 23, 1784. Four days later, ice began to break simultaneously on both main and secondary streams. In the Vltava River basin, water levels rose very quickly to the level of a hundred-year or two-hundred-year flood. In Prague, the water level peaked on February 28, when it rose by four meters within 12 hours, and its flow rate was calculated at approximately 4580 m³/s. On that day, 114 streets, 785 houses were flooded in the capital, and after an ice floe struck the water-eroded sixth pillar of the Stone Bridge, the flood defense head of the stone structure, along with a military guardhouse and five soldiers, collapsed into the Vltava. On February 29, the eighth pillar of the Stone Bridge, which housed a statue of St. Wenceslas with two angels by Ottavio Most, was also damaged, with one of the angels falling into the Vltava. The torso of the fallen angel was found by divers under the bridge in 2004. On the Elbe and other Czech streams, water level peaks were recorded a day or two later. During the flood, the Prague weirs were also breached, and the lowered Vltava water level revealed the pillars of the Romanesque Judith Bridge and river thresholds, from which Václav Fortunát Durych later derived the name Prague.

Apart from the Vltava and Elbe, the flood also affected the neighboring basins of the Danube and Oder (Lusatian Neisse). In Western Europe, the flood impacted the basins of the Rhine, Neckar, Moselle, Seine, and Loire. In these areas, this flood is ranked among the largest recorded floods in modern history.

The flood on the Vltava River in 1954 was caused by summer torrential rains in the Vltava River basin at the beginning of July. The main part of the rainfall occurred between July 5 and 8, 1954, in the Šumava and South Bohemia regions.

In the Otava river basin, it was a centennial flood, and the river flooded a significant part of the town of Písek. Further downstream on the Vltava, the flood wave was slowed down by the nearly completed Slapy reservoir, which captured about 90 million m3 of water. In Prague, the Vltava peaked on July 10, 1954, with a recorded flow rate of 2275 m3/s.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

The flood in the Czech Republic in 2009 followed a series of persistent rains and storms over Central Europe and became the third worst disaster in the modern history of the Czech Republic. The flood occurred between June 23 and July 4, 2009, claiming 14 lives and causing damages exceeding 5.6 billion crowns. The flood started in South Bohemia and gradually affected most of the Czech Republic's territory. The flood was caused by a low-pressure system centered over the Balkan Peninsula, along the edge of which warm and humid air flowed from the southeast, resulting in high rainfall totals. At the same time, floods caused problems and resulted in material damages and casualties in Poland, Austria, and Slovakia.

On Monday, June 22, meteorologists warned of heavy rain that could raise the levels of smaller rivers in particular. On the morning of Tuesday, June 23, persistent rain raised the levels of South Bohemian rivers. The Černá River in Líčov in the Český Krumlov region rose to the third flood activity level. Later that evening, the levels of South Bohemian rivers gradually peaked. By 5 p.m., the third flood level was declared in five locations in the region. On June 24, persistent rain continued, slowing the decline of river levels. In eastern Czechia, river levels rose throughout June 24, and in the evening, it was announced that the floods in Nový Jičín had claimed the life of one woman. On June 25, meteorologists warned of rain and floods mainly in the south and east of Czechia, and during the day, the police confirmed six fatalities in the Nový Jičín region. On Friday, June 26, Prague's Čertovka was closed due to the high level of the Vltava River. Evening storms and torrential rains caused problems in South Bohemia, where flooding affected 17 municipalities. Overnight, firefighters rescued 64 people and evacuated 150. In the following days, floods mainly troubled South Bohemia but also the Vysočina region. Elevated water levels were also reported on the Vltava River in Prague. At the beginning of July, the floods gradually subsided, and the situation stabilized.

As a result of persistent floods, 14 people died in the Czech Republic. Dozens of houses were damaged, and the damages were estimated at nearly 6 billion crowns. The most affected areas were mainly southern and eastern Bohemia.

Whole_Text.content: In 2006, between March and April, a flood occurred over a large part of the Czech Republic and the broader region of Central Europe. It was caused by a combination of heavy rainfall and rapid warming, which led to the quick melting of a substantial snow cover. The worst situation was on the Dyje and Nové Mlýny, in the basins of the Elbe, Morava, and Lužnice rivers. Several settlements were flooded, including larger parts of cities (Ústí nad Labem, Olomouc, Planá nad Lužnicí, and Znojmo). The Vltava did not cause more serious damage because it was partially regulated using the pre-emptively drained reservoirs of the Vltava Cascade, especially Lipno. The floods began on March 25, 2006, and ended around April 5. The high water affected communities along the Vltava, Lužnice, Elbe, Sázava, and Jizera rivers. Among the most affected towns was Veselí nad Lužnicí and its surroundings on the Lužnice River, where up to 400 homes were flooded. Other significantly affected communities included Planá nad Lužnicí, Soběslav, Křešice, České Kopisty, Litoměřice, and the Posázaví region. Moravia was not spared either. The floods eventually impacted seven regions with several hundred municipalities (e.g., 178 municipalities in South Bohemia). The Czech government initially released 380 million Czech crowns to compensate flood victims and later 5 billion from ČEZ stock dividends. The total flood damages amounted to up to 5 billion Czech crowns.

At the end of March 2006, part of the city of Znojmo was flooded. In connection with this event, on March 31, 2006, the Minister of Agriculture Jan Mládek dismissed Miroslav Konečný, who was in charge of managing the Morava River Basin. According to a statement by Znojmo's mayor Pavel Balík to the newspaper MF Dnes, when the inflow into the Vranov Reservoir was 200 m3/s, only 20 m3/s was being released, which, along with insufficient prior reserves for spring thawing, was the cause of the situation being mishandled. The most significant flood in 2006 occurred at the end of March and the beginning of April, during which some streams reached Q50 to Q100 (the letter Q denotes flow rate, and the number following it indicates the return period of the flow, e.g., Q50 = fifty-year flow). The second flood in 2006 occurred in May. The May flood was caused by rainfall on a wavy cold front, which repeatedly hit western Bohemia. The two-day rainfall total was up to around 120 mm. The result was flow rates of up to around Q50.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

The flood in Eastern Bohemia in 1998 affected over 30 municipalities in the districts of Rychnov nad Kněžnou, Náchod, and Hradec Králové during the night of July 22 to July 23, 1998. Six people died, and a seventh (indirect) victim was a volunteer rescuer.

Massive torrential rains on the night of July 23 caused floods mainly on the Bělá and Dědina (Zlatý potok) rivers. The water levels of these rivers rose by up to three meters. An area of approximately 100 square kilometers was flooded, affecting 30 municipalities, with the worst-hit being the village of Kounov, where about 10 houses were destroyed. Additionally, towns such as Opočno, Dobruška, its local part Pulice, the village of Dobré, Skuhrov nad Bělou, and Přepychy were heavily affected. Around 800 people were evacuated. During the floods, 6 people drowned (5 men and 1 woman) in Deštné in the Orlické Mountains, Skuhrov, Kounov, Dobré, Masty, and Pulice. An indirect victim was a volunteer rescuer from Prague who died in a car accident in Černíkovice. The water also flooded 350 meters of railway track between Opočno and Dobruška, halting operations for a week. On the Opočno–Bohuslavice line, a bridge collapse was imminent, and the railway between Opočno and Bolehošť was also impassable. Damages were estimated at 1.927 billion Czech crowns.

The flood on the Lusatian Neisse in 2010 followed a torrential rain and on August 7th affected northern Bohemia, Saxony, and part of southwestern Poland. Flash floods claimed 5 lives in the Liberec district, and damages were estimated at hundreds of millions of crowns. Poland had 3 fatalities, including one firefighter. The Liberec and Ústí nad Labem regions declared a state of emergency. The most affected settlements were Heřmanice, Raspenava, Chrastava, Hrádek nad Nisou, Frýdlant, Lindava, and in Poland the towns of Bogatynia and Zgorzelec.

On Friday, August 6, 2010, around 8 p.m., heavy rains began over the Liberec region, lasting throughout the night. Watercourses, including small streams, significantly increased their flow and overflowed into the surrounding areas. By noon on August 7, 2010, the level of the Jeřice River in Chrastava rose to 433 cm and, along with other smaller tributaries and water from nearby meadows and fields, flooded almost the entire town. The water caused massive damage to roads, all footbridges, and several bridges over the river were destroyed, and many houses had to be demolished. A similar situation occurred in the Frýdlant area in the Smědá River basin. In the town of Mimoň in the Česká Lípa district, the level of the Ploučnice River reached its historical maximum, climbing to a record 252 cm at 8:00 a.m. on August 8, 2010. In some places, flood waves occurred, with water rising by a meter within minutes. Crisis and flood management teams quickly declared all three levels of flood activity during the night. Firefighting units assisting during the first critical night lost several vehicles to the floods. Numerous villages and entire towns were flooded, and people from endangered areas were evacuated. Panic was further fueled by rumors of the Mlýnice dam breaking. By noon on Saturday, August 7, the first fatalities were confirmed. The army and police fully joined the rescue efforts, and firefighters from neighboring regions began assisting in the most threatened areas around Frýdlant. By Sunday morning, the fifth drowning victim was confirmed, and firefighters from Germany also began helping. The situation was also serious in South Bohemia, where the evacuation of Veselí nad Lužnicí was threatened.

According to data from the non-profit organization People in Need, water flooded 2,586 households (1,157 of them in the Frýdlant region and 517 in the Česká Lípa region). Structural engineers decided to demolish at least 57 houses damaged by the floods. According to additional data from the Liberec Region Council, 79 municipalities were submerged, 7 bridges were completely destroyed, 5 people died, and the total property damage in the region amounted to 5 billion CZK. The Czech government sent the region 40 million CZK as immediate aid, followed by 350 million CZK for the Ústí nad Labem and Liberec regions. Rescue operations involved 1,040 firefighters, 780 soldiers, and over 700 police officers and municipal guards. During looting, 5 foreigners were detained and subsequently convicted. Additionally, 200 prisoners assisted in dealing with the aftermath. The Liberec Region and many cities established flood accounts and flood portals. Damage to second- and third-class roads managed by the Liberec Region was estimated at 2 billion CZK. Damage to roads owned by municipalities and the state was valued at another billion CZK. In Chrastava, as a replacement after the floods, a unique transporter from the Kolonka settlement near Hamrštejn was built and opened on October 10, 2010, along with three new wooden and iron lifting footbridges by October 17, 2011, which can be raised by about 2 meters in case of flooding. The lifting mechanism for each of them cost around 155,000 CZK.

At the end of September 2010, the Liberec Region, especially the Česká Lípa area, was hit by another flood. Although it was not as rapid as the previous one, it still flooded the surroundings of many streams, including dozens of houses that had not yet dried out. In many places, the third level of danger was declared, and it was necessary to evacuate a number of people.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

Whole_Text.content: Ukraine, Zakarpattia Oblast, Lviv Oblast, flood November 1998, 17 people. The flood in Zakarpattia in 1998 was a flood that struck the Zakarpattia Oblast of Ukraine in November 1998. During the disaster, 120 towns and villages were flooded. 2,500 houses were destroyed. 17 people died in the flood. Financial losses amounted to 835 million hryvnias. According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, the flood affected 400,000 residents of Ukraine, and 24,340 people were evacuated.

Intense rains lasting from November 4 to 6, 1998, marked the beginning of a flood in the Zakarpattia region. The water overflowed the banks of the Tisza, Tereblia, Teresva, Borzhava, and Latorica rivers. One-quarter of the region's territory was flooded. According to Ukrainian government data as of November 17, 1998, 120 localities, including two cities in Zakarpattia, were flooded. In addition to the Zakarpattia region, the flood also reached 11 localities in the Lviv region. Floods and landslides damaged roads, railways, and power lines in the region, and several villages in remote areas became inaccessible. On November 21, a landslide caused by the recent flood killed a family of four, raising the total death toll from the flood to 17. Ukrainian geologists worked on mapping landslide-prone zones and took preventive measures. According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, the flood affected 400,000 residents of Ukraine, and 24,340 people were evacuated. A total of 5,893 rescuers deployed by the Ministry of Emergency Situations, the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine, and the State Border Service participated in addressing the disaster's aftermath. They were equipped with 1,197 land vehicles, as well as 13 amphibious vehicles and 7 helicopters. On November 7, 1998, the Ukrainian government appealed to the United Nations for international assistance for the affected population. Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma called on NATO countries to provide aid to residents of the flood-affected areas. The Polish Ministry of Internal Affairs and Administration sent 27 trucks with aid for those in need to Ukraine. The Polish Humanitarian Action sent 24 tons of aid, mainly food and clothing, to the Vynohradiv district. In addition to Poland, Austria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, France, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Germany, Russia, and Slovakia also provided assistance to Ukraine. Yoko Ono donated 70,000 CHF to help the needy residents of Zakarpattia. On November 11, a Hungarian mobile health center was established in the border town of Vary, providing medical assistance to the region's residents. After the flood, as of December 11, 1998, around 50,000 families still required government assistance, and over 5,500 people remained displaced. In many localities, wells were contaminated, and dead animals could be found in the area. According to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), there was a risk of local residents contracting diarrhea and hepatitis A. On January 29, 1999, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, after conducting water tests, declared that the epidemic situation in the region was stable. The ICRC supported the Zakarpattia Red Cross in managing the situation in the region. National associations of the Danish, Hungarian, Polish, and Dutch Red Cross were also involved in providing assistance.

In 1999, the "Flood Protection Program in Transcarpathia for 1999–2000" was adopted, which, although not fully implemented, helped minimize losses to 317 million hryvnias during the next flood in 2001, which exceeded the scale of the 1998 disaster. Since 2002, the "Integrated Flood Protection Program in the Tisza River Basin" has been implemented in the Transcarpathian region. In the first three years of its operation, it was implemented at only 13%. It was not until 2006 that it received full funding of 70.9 million hryvnias, but in subsequent years, funding issues reappeared. During the 2010 flood, financial losses amounted to 61 million hryvnias. In December 2017, the largest recorded flood in Transcarpathia occurred. Due to multiple exceedances of atmospheric precipitation norms and warming, the water levels in mountain rivers rose. Between December 9–17, three flood waves merged into one. The disaster reached its peak on December 16 and 17, and on December 18, the water level began to drop. As a result of the flood, 221 households were flooded, nearly 2,500 hectares of farmland were inundated, 8 sections of roads were damaged, and two bridges were destroyed. The UNIAN agency reported that in the years preceding the December 2017 flood, flood protection funds were cut due to the ongoing war in Donbas.

Whole_Text.content: Jeddah floods 2011 were floods that struck the city of Jeddah in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, 22 Safar 1432 AH, corresponding to January 26, 2011, claiming the lives of more than 100 people, injuring hundreds of others, cutting off electricity, and necessitating the deployment of Saudi army forces and the National Guard to rescue the afflicted in the largest rescue operation witnessed in the history of Saudi Arabia. It is worth mentioning that the water level of these floods reached a record level, double the rate recorded during the Jeddah floods of 2009, which claimed 114 lives. The annual rainfall rate in Jeddah is 52 mm with a fluctuation rate of 88%. The Saudi Civil Defense stated that it managed to rescue 1,451 people through ground teams and 467 people via helicopter operations.

The General Presidency of Meteorology and Environmental Protection (later transformed into an authority) addressed its oversight regarding the previous Jeddah floods and urgently warned Prince Khaled Al-Faisal of the region about the possibility of moderate to heavy rainfall in Mecca, Taif, and Jeddah, passing it on to the Saudi Civil Defense. The warnings had been confirmed four days prior to the floods.

The rainfall reached 111 mm[11], forming torrential floods that carved their way from the mountains east of Jeddah through Wadi Muraikh and the large Wadi Bani Malik to its west, reaching the Red Sea, cutting 13 km through the heart of Jeddah with immense force. The floods inundated 80% of Jeddah's inhabited area, turning its roads and tunnels into alternative flood channels. The rainfall continued for 3 hours over an area of 400 to 600 km², with a rainfall amount of 102 to 120 mm. This means that the total rainfall amounted to 6 to 9 billion cubic meters of water, which is equivalent to half of Saudi Arabia's annual water consumption.[12] These floods flowed from the highlands east of Jeddah towards the Red Sea.

The flood disaster that struck the city of Jeddah this time faced the issue of media blackout imposed by higher authorities to prevent the dissemination of all facts related to damages and fatalities. Severe criticism was directed at local channels, particularly Saudi Channel One and Al-Ekhbariya Channel, as they are affiliated with the Saudi Ministry of Information, for not covering the news.

Whole_Text.header: The collapse of Umm Al-Khair Dam
Whole_Text.content: The torrential floods coming from the east, which gathered in the Umm Al-Khair Dam, led to its collapse and the flooding of nearby neighborhoods with water. It also resulted in the flooding of large areas in eastern and central Jeddah, disrupting the daily life of the residents of Jeddah.

The Ministry of Education ordered the suspension of studies in schools in Jeddah Governorate for a week. It also postponed the final exams for the first semester in schools and at King Abdulaziz University.
The Saudi Civil Defense, in cooperation with the Jeddah Municipality, announced the flooding of more than 40 locations in the city and the suspension of navigation at Jeddah Islamic Port.

The Saudi Telecom Company announced its support for those affected by allowing free phone calls for the residents of Jeddah in recognition of their urgent need for communication at the time, with the number of free phone calls on that day reaching 90 million, with a total value of approximately 210 million SAR.

After the disaster, voices rose calling for protests against the poor infrastructure in Jeddah and class discrimination, as reports mentioned that a rescue helicopter evacuated a student from the royal family and left the rest of the students to face their unknown fate at Dar Al-Hekma College in Jeddah. Subsequently, the Saudi government arrested 30 out of 100 people who started a demonstration on Tahlia Street in Jeddah on the Friday following the floods, demanding improvements to infrastructure and changes to the current political system. On the other hand, the then Saudi King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz (may he rest in peace) ordered an assessment of the damages to compensate those affected.

The floods claimed the lives of more than 150 people and injured 114 others in various areas, and so far no estimated cost of the damages caused by the floods has been announced, but it is certain that the losses are significant given the number of roads, buildings, and cars that were seen completely damaged after the water partially receded.

Whole_Text.content: The floods in southern Tunisia in September 2009 were violent floods and torrents that swept through southern Tunisia on September 23, 2009, lasting two days, caused by heavy rains that hit the region. The official Tunisian news agency reported that the heavy rains exceeded 150 millimeters in a record time, leading to the flooding of Oued Umm Arayes and consequently cutting off the road between Umm Arayes and Redeyef. The floods caused the death of 17 people, injuries to others, destruction of property, and material damages. The floods also extended to the city of Gabes in the south as well as the cities of Sfax, Mahdia, Sousse, and Kairouan in the center without human losses. The wind speed reached 100 km per hour.

The closure of schools, shops, and the near-paralysis of infrastructure in southern Tunisia, with many cars submerged, yet most of those present managed to escape the devastating floods and active thunderstorms.

The regional authorities in the Gafsa governorate have begun compensating citizens whose homes were damaged, totaling 3,775 beneficiaries.  
The damages caused by the exceptional rainfall on September 23 and 24 included vegetable crops, fruit trees, livestock, irrigation equipment, and water and soil conservation structures.
September 24: President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali gives instructions to send a plane loaded with aid for the benefit of flood victims in Redeyef.

The repair of all damages to the drinking water supply and distribution network and deep wells required spending approximately 470,000 dinars.  
A program for intervention covering the years 2009 and 2010 in the field of water and soil conservation was established, valued at 2.8 million dinars, focusing particularly on the development of river outlets over an area of 500 hectares, the creation of 33 water spreading units, and the protection of another 800 hectares of agricultural land through water and soil conservation structures.

Whole_Text.header: The Great Flood of the Year Eulchuk
Whole_Text.content: The Eulchuk Year Great Flood (乙丑年 大洪水) refers to the flood that struck Korea four times from early July to September 1925 during the Japanese colonial period. The damage was particularly severe in the Han River and Nakdong River basins, and the flood is called the Eulchuk Year Great Flood, named after the year 1925, the Eulchuk year. With an average rainfall of 700–970mm, it caused damages amounting to 13 million won, which accounted for 80% of the annual rainfall and 58% of the budget of the Governor-General of Korea at the time. In Seoul alone, 647 people died, and about 6,792 houses were swept away by the strong currents. A total of 17,045 houses collapsed, 46,813 houses were flooded, and 29,229 people were displaced.

On July 7, 1925, a typhoon (2559) formed near Taiwan and passed through central Korea on the 11th and 12th. As a result, rivers in the central and southern regions of the Korean Peninsula, such as the Han River, Geum River, Nakdong River, and Mangyeong River, overflowed. Heavy rainfall of 300-500mm fell in areas south of Hwanghae Province, causing the Han River to reach a water level of 10.57m at Guryongsan, and the Han River, Geum River, Mangyeong River, and Nakdong River overflowed.

On July 14, before the water from the first flood had even receded, a typhoon (2560) formed near Taiwan and passed through the central region, bringing over 650mm of heavy rainfall over four days from July 15 to July 18. Due to consecutive floods, the water level of the Han River reached its peak, causing embankments to collapse and flooding the Yongsan area, with water reaching as far as the front of Sungnyemun. Transportation and communication in downtown Seoul were also paralyzed. At the time, over 400 people drowned, and more than 12,000 houses were lost. It is said that the Jeongot Bridge was also destroyed during this time. However, various relics were discovered due to the flood, including the Baekje Pungnap Earthen Fortress and the prehistoric settlement site in Amsa-dong. On the 18th, the Han River recorded water levels of 13.59m at Ttukseom, 11.66m at Hangang Bridge, and 12.47m at Guryongsan. At that time, the railway office in Yongsan was flooded up to the ceiling of the first floor, and trains at Yongsan Station were submerged. Additionally, a tributary formed at Ttukseom, leading to the creation of the name Sincheon (新川), and water reached the upper branches of the zelkova tree at Pisudae, which has now disappeared. The areas most severely affected were Dongbu Ichon-dong, Ttukseom, Songpa, Jamsilli, Sincheon-ri, and Pungnap-ri, where embankments had not been installed. The damage to the Nakdong River was also severe. Daejeo Island was almost completely destroyed, and 200 bodies were found below the island. On the 12th, embankments collapsed in Miryang and Gimje, leaving 2,000 people missing, and on the 15th, embankments collapsed in Changwon, leaving 6,000 people isolated or missing.

A low-pressure system that developed in the Yangtze River passed through the border between the Empire of Japan and the Republic of China and moved out to Gando, causing heavy rain in the Kansai region in early August, which led to the flooding of the Taedong River, Cheongcheon River, and Yalu River.

A tropical depression developed in the Mariana Islands and moved northward, and on September 6, 1925, it passed through Jeju Island, Mokpo, and Daegu before exiting to the East Sea. Heavy rains in the southern region caused the Nakdong River, Yeongsan River, and Seomjin River to overflow. A total of 63 people were recorded as dead or missing.

Due to four floods, 647 people died nationwide, over 6,000 houses were washed away, 17,000 houses collapsed, and 46,000 houses were submerged. 32,000 danbo of rice paddies and 67,000 danbo of fields were lost. The damage caused by the floods amounted to 10.3 million won, which was equivalent to 58% of the annual budget of the Joseon Governor-General's Office at the time. To recover, the Joseon Governor-General's Office even mobilized the military and carried out large-scale embankment construction on the main stream of the Han River and its tributaries, such as Anyangcheon, Jungnangcheon, and Cheonggyecheon. This flood, which submerged most of the Han River basin, led to the discovery of Pungnap Toseong and the prehistoric residential site in Amsa-dong as the Songpa-dong area was flooded. Meanwhile, a Japanese official named Kajiyama, who worked for the Joseon Governor-General's Office, created the Kajiyama formula, a simple flood volume formula derived from empirical experience, as a result of this flood.

The flood in the Czech Republic in 2002 is one of the largest events of its kind in the history of the Czech Republic. The most affected areas in Bohemia were the Vltava basin, later the lower course of the Elbe, and marginally also the streams in the Ohře basin and the Dyje basin in Moravia. Along with the floods in Moravia and Silesia in 1997, it ranks among the most severe natural disasters in modern Czech history. It was the largest flood since the devastating Great Flood in 1845. Compared to that, the flow of the Vltava through Prague in 2002 was approximately 20% greater.

On August 6, 2002, weather in Bohemia began to be influenced by a low-pressure system, which, with its frontal system, was slowly moving eastward. By August 7 and 8, persistent heavy rainfall had filled most of the rivers in South and West Bohemia. On Thursday, August 8, the flood in some places had already reached the extent of a 50-year flood (especially in South Bohemia). The situation, however, gradually calmed, and on August 9, the rain stopped. The Vltava River in Prague reached a flow rate of 1,500 m³/s and began to recede. On August 11 and 12, it started raining again. Over the southwest of Bohemia, two significant frontal systems collided, which moved only slowly to the northeast. Additionally, the windward effect in South Bohemia brought further intensification of the rain. The soil, saturated with water from previous rainfall, could no longer retain the water, which flowed into the already full rivers. During the week of August 12 to 18, parts of Bohemia were affected by a 500-year to 1,000-year flood. The Vltava River and its basin were the most affected, followed later by the lower Elbe River and, to a lesser extent, rivers in the Ohře and Dyje basins. The cause of the floods was above-average rainfall, which in the first rainfall episode mainly affected South Bohemia and, in the second episode, occurred across most of Bohemia. In addition to the significant saturation of soil and riverbeds from the first rainfall episode, the situation was also influenced by waterworks, particularly the Vltava Cascade. These captured a relatively large portion of the flood wave from the first rainfall episode. However, the reservoirs were unable to handle the second rainfall episode, and the flood advanced into the valleys without major obstacles. A noticeable flattening of the flood wave on the Vltava, and subsequently on the Elbe, occurred only due to overflows in the Polabská lowland. Nevertheless, even this was not enough, and the high water also affected towns further north in Bohemia and later the German section of the Elbe.

Flood plans were developed, based on which flood protection measures were implemented in many parts of the country. Since the 2002 flood, the Q2002 water level has been used for construction and spatial designs. The Integrated Rescue System Act was created based on experiences from the 1997 flood. It is the IZS Act No. 239/2000 Coll. It came into effect on January 1, 2001. There is no law on a state of emergency. There is the so-called Crisis Act (240/2000 Coll., on crisis management and on amendments to certain laws), which defines the powers and responsibilities of the government, regional governors, and other crisis management authorities in the event of a declaration of a state of danger or emergency. The Crisis Act came into effect on January 1, 2001.
