Whole_Text.content: The Jánská flood occurred on May 16, 1889, on St. John's Day in the area of the then Přeštice district. The flash flood affected the area between Červené Poříčí and Přeštice, and more than fifty people lost their lives.

During the night of May 16 to 17, 1889, a severe storm swept over the region, causing the Příchovice stream, including its tributaries and the Vlčí stream, to flood. The streams could not handle the runoff from the surrounding hills, and the rising water levels affected the villages through which both streams flowed. The greatest disaster occurred on the Vlčí stream in the village of Jíno (formerly Jinín), where 24 people died, seven houses were completely destroyed, and twenty were damaged to varying degrees; the height of the mud deposits reached 70 cm (two and a half feet). During the flood, about 40 head of cattle perished. On the Příchovice stream, the water from the Zlatý stream attacked the pond below the Lužský forest, breaking the pond's dam, destroying a sawmill, and killing eight people. Downstream, the water overflowed the dam of the pond in Horšice and surged toward the settlement of Vitouň, where it broke the dam of the Vitouň pond and also the dams of the pond in Radkovice. The surge wave reached up to two meters in height, carrying logs and timber from the sawmill and destroyed houses. In Radkovice, four people died, and in Příchovice, nine. Mills in Liebštejn and Příchovice were destroyed or damaged. Mud deposits, remnants of trees, dwellings, and boulders (up to 150 kg) covered fields and meadows, or topsoil was washed away from the fields. A total of 53 people died. An engineering unit from Plzeň was sent to assist the area. Public collections were organized to help the affected, both financially and in the form of food, clothing, or building materials. Another flood hit the area on August 2, 1890. After these floods, the regulation of streambeds began, and the regulation was completed in 1903.

Article_Name: Povodeň na Vltavě a Labi (1940) – Wikipedie

Whole_Text.header: Flood on the Vltava and Elbe (1940)
Whole_Text.content: The flood of March 1940 is considered the most significant winter flood of the 20th century. In Prague, a fifty-year flow rate of 3245 m³/s was reached. The main reason for the extreme impacts of this flood was a sudden warming that occurred at the beginning of March. Until then, the rivers were covered with a thick layer of ice, which suddenly began to melt and crack. As a result of this phenomenon, around March 15, the water levels of rivers in the Vltava and Elbe basins rose, and remnants of ice floes were carried along the riverbeds. These ice floes, driven by the water, destroyed everything in their path with great force. This phenomenon is called "dřenice." From March 17, the water level began to drop again. However, on March 20, due to a snowstorm, the Vltava's water level rose again by 1 meter.

The flood caused great damage in Štěchovice. The water level rose 9 meters above the normal level. Most cottages were destroyed by floating ice blocks, and almost the entire village was flooded. [5] A total of 24 houses were completely destroyed, and another 170 were flooded up to the roof. [4] Due to its location, the Veltrusy Castle and its surroundings have historically been regularly affected by floods. The year 1940 was no exception, and extensive parts of Kralupy nad Vltavou were flooded. In the immediate vicinity of the castle, the spiral staircase on the Lobeč side of the bridge was destroyed. [4] Modřany was also heavily affected, where it was necessary to use boats for transportation due to the high water level. [6]

During the floods around the Vetrusy castle, a column of Nazi troops passing through was trapped by floodwater and drift ice. This event sparked enthusiasm and joy among the civilian population, especially because it happened exactly one year after the proclamation of the Protectorate.[4] The thawing of accumulated ice on the banks took several more months.[3]

The Tenmei Flood refers to a major flood disaster that occurred in the Tone River system in 1786 (Tenmei 6). In the "Tokugawa Jikki," it is mentioned as "Previously, the flood of Kanpo 2 was called a great flood, but this time it is ten times greater."

In the Tone River system, Mount Asama erupted massively in 1783, causing pyroclastic flows to descend the Agatsuma River. A large amount of sediment flowed further downstream into the main Tone River, leading to a rise in the riverbed. This became a remote cause of the flood three years later [1]. In July 1786, the Kanto region was hit by torrential rains. The Tone River overflowed near Haneno (present-day Tone Town, Ibaraki Prefecture), and a massive muddy stream flowed into the city of Edo. The devastation was described as "south of Kurihashi being like the sea" [2]. Around Honjo, the water depth reached up to approximately 4.5 meters, and on the first day alone, 3,641 people were rescued by boats and other means [3].

Article_Name: Inondation du 3 octobre 1988 de Nîmes — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The Nîmes flood of October 3, 1988, resulted from a Mediterranean episode that caused heavy rainfall in Nîmes, in the Gard. This natural disaster caused about ten deaths and affected 70 municipalities around Nîmes. This flood left a lasting impression on local memory and is regularly commemorated. It is estimated that the return period of the event is approximately centennial (a one in a hundred chance of occurring each year).

During the night of October 2 to 3, 1988, and the morning of October 3, storm bands crossed southeastern France during a Mediterranean episode. Radar echoes from the night show that the storm originated southwest of the Gulf of Aigues-Mortes (south of Montpellier). The storm system initially moved up the lower Vidourle valley, causing significant rainfall in the Sommières area late in the evening of October 2. The phenomenon then gained in size and intensity, heading toward the Nîmes heights, first passing through the Vaunage plain, where 250 to nearly 400 mm of rain were recorded on average over the entire episode, particularly in Calvisson. Significant hailstorms were reported in the commune of Congénies around 4 a.m. The rainfall reached 50 mm or more per hour on average over a period of less than 12 hours, equating to six months of rain. The torrential storm then spread and stalled over the entire garrigue plateaus overlooking Nîmes toward Remoulins. At the Nîmes-Courbessac meteorological station, east of the city, 263 mm fell during the night of October 2 to 3. At Nîmes-Kennedy, 311 mm were recorded by 1 p.m. The most intense rainfall core recorded was 420 mm at Mas-de-Ponge, on the heights northwest of the city. This considerable value is, however, underestimated because the rain gauge stopped transmitting data for about forty minutes during the episode. Locally, 500 mm may have been recorded, equivalent to two-thirds of the annual rainfall. The karst networks quickly became saturated, charging all the cadereaux toward the city center. However, the rainfall was relatively localized, as only 35 mm were recorded at Nîmes-Garons airport, just 6 km southeast of the city. The very tight isohyet curves during the event are typical of stationary storm phenomena. The Nîmes urban area, located at the confluence of cadereaux, at the foot of the limestone plateaus of the garrigues, is particularly prone to flood risks from runoff. The first indications of flooding in Nîmes date back to the 14th century. Historical chronicles notably mention two major disasters equivalent to that of October 3, 1988: August 29, 1399, and September 9, 1557.

There were then counted ten[2] or eleven deaths, including two helicopter pilots who were providing assistance, and 45,000 victims. A total of 70 municipalities around Nîmes were subsequently classified as a natural disaster zone[4]. The damages were estimated at more than 600 million euros[4],[9].
Some of the inhabitants quickly spread a conspiracy theory accusing the authorities of hiding the real number of deaths in order not to panic the population.

Article_Name: Turbión del río Piraí de 1983, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Piraí River in 1983
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Piraí River in 1983, also known as The Great Flood of 1983, was a natural disaster that occurred in the early hours of March 18 of that year, mainly in the city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra and neighboring regions of the Santa Cruz department, in eastern Bolivia. In a study published in 2016, it is mentioned that there were actually two floods in 1983, the first on February 1 and the second on March 18. This event occurred due to the historic rise of the Piraí River, which flows west of the city of Santa Cruz. Due to torrential rain in the river's upper basin, it caused destruction along a stretch of more than 100 kilometers between the valleys and the alluvial plain, and as it advanced over flat terrain, the overflow reached a front about 10 kilometers wide, moving earth in its path. The flood destroyed the Tarumá bridge and wiped out the town of El Chorrito, in the municipality of El Torno, and reached Santa Cruz, flooding the botanical garden, the Ambrosio Villarroel neighborhood, and the entire western area of the city. The flood also caused hundreds of deaths and left 3,000 families homeless.

The families affected by the flood that year were relocated to the east of the city, where the Plan 3000 neighborhood was created. Due to the 1983 flood, defensive structures were built in the western part of the city, in addition to the establishment of a protective forest strip called the ecological belt of the Piraí River, which is a one-kilometer-wide vegetative wall.

The flood in Moravia occurred from May 21 to May 27, 1985. The cause was several days of continuous rain; for example, in the vicinity of Bohumín, it rained almost continuously for nearly 70 hours. During the period of the most intense rainfall, 58 mm fell in Přibyslavice, 38 mm in Telč, and 30 mm in Náměšť nad Oslavou within 8 hours; near Chrudim, 60 mm of rainfall was recorded in 24 hours. The floods caused damages amounting to tens of millions of Czechoslovak korunas, mostly to industrial facilities of the Kablo Velké Meziříčí company and several operations or plants of the dairy company Lacrum Brno, the footwear factories Svit Gottwaldov, and the cosmetics manufacturer Astrid Praha.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the South Moravian Region
Whole_Text.content: In the former South Moravian Region, the districts of Jihlava, Třebíč, Žďár nad Sázavou, Znojmo, Brno-venkov, and Břeclav were particularly affected, with several municipalities evacuated. Intense rains washed away valuable topsoil along with growing crops in many places. The impact of the flood was partially mitigated by the Dalešice, Mostiště, Vranov, and Vír reservoirs, while the under-construction Nové Mlýny Waterworks was slightly damaged. In Velké Meziříčí, the high water surpassed a record that coincidentally occurred on May 21, 1781. The Balinka stream flooded the main square to a height of half a meter, peaking on May 21 at 10:00 a.m.—at that moment, around 110 houses in the city center were flooded up to 1.5 meters, and tires from the local retreading cooperative Obnova's warehouse were scattered throughout the city. The Oslava River then flooded almost the entire area of the second-largest Czech cable factory, Kablo Velké Meziříčí. After the water receded, holes and trenches up to two meters deep appeared in the square. However, most retail establishments managed to resume operations by Saturday, May 25. The Jihlava River reached a historically record height: in Ivančice on May 22, 1985, it recorded the highest water level of 536 cm (31 mm higher than the previous record on March 20, 1947). Its tributary, the Jihlávka, flooded the area of the Jihlava Zoo on the same day, where employees, in cooperation with the army, waded through waist-deep water to rescue endangered animals and faced the threat that the dam of the Staré plovárny, half a kilometer upstream, might break, which would have posed a significantly greater danger. However, the dam held, and the water receded that afternoon. Several dozen kilometers downstream, in Pohořelice, the Jihlava River flooded around 350 houses. The rivers Svratka (for example, the poultry plant area in Modřice was flooded) and Dyje also overflowed their banks, with the Dyje threatening its surroundings as far as Břeclav and being the only river to remain at the third flood stage as late as Monday, May 27.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the North Moravian Region
Whole_Text.content: In the former North Moravian region, the disaster particularly affected the Karviná district, where the Odra River in Bohumín rose from the usual 90 cm to almost 6 meters. For example, 90% of the cadastral area of the Bohumín settlement of Šunychl was flooded (where the water level rose by two meters within a single hour), similarly affected were the Bohumín settlement of Kopytov and Petrovice near Karviná.
The East Bohemian region was also marginally affected, where the Novohradka River and partially the Chrudimka River overflowed locally, but did not cause significant damage.

Whole_Text.content: The February flood of 1946 in Herford was a centennial flood in the Werre river basin, which, as part of the Weser flood of 1946, hit the East Westphalian city of Herford from February 8 to 10, 1946. The flood wave inundated large parts of Herford's city center.

The trigger for the century flood was an unusual weather constellation. Moist, warm oceanic air coming from the west collided with cooler air, resulting in significant rainfall. Between January 28 and February 26, only one rain-free day was recorded in Herford, on February 14, 1946. From February 8 to 9 alone, 130 liters per square meter fell, one-fifth of the annual rainfall. Herford had already been affected by floods in the weeks prior, but these amounts led to the most severe natural disaster known in the region. Due to a shortage of firewood after World War II, the surrounding forests were also cleared, leaving the soil unable to absorb water. As a result, the Werre and Aa rivers overflowed their banks in a very short time. Debris from the railway bridge on the Herford-Altenbeken line, destroyed by air raids and still lying in the Werre, significantly hindered the river's water flow and caused a massive backup above the railway embankment, reaching up to the top of the tracks. Under the pressure of the 1.5 million cubic meters of water that had accumulated, the railway embankment broke in four places on the morning of February 9. With tremendous force, the floodwaters poured into the lower-lying city area, flooding almost the entire city center. In the process, they caused devastating damage to houses and riverbanks.

The areas particularly affected were the Neustadt, the settlement area at the upper Werre course, part of the old town, the Radewig, as well as the densely populated lower course of the Werre. In the streets of the city center, the water was up to 1.50 meters high in some places. The wells and pumping stations for drinking water supply were also endangered by the flooding. Fatally, the flood wave of the Aa – usually occurring four to six hours earlier than that of the Werre – coincided with it. The masses of water also tore away the Hansa Bridge, which stood just behind the confluence of the Aa into the Werre, interrupting the route of the Herford narrow-gauge railway until May 1949.

The full extent of the disaster became apparent when the water had completely receded a few days later. The sand-rich Werre left a thick layer of clay in the buildings, most bridges were damaged, the weirs and dikes in need of repair. The gasometer on Werrestraße had to be dismantled due to undermining. Many houses had suffered significant damage.

Above and below Herford, other places were affected by the floodwaters. Upstream in Bad Salzuflen, the Werre and in Lemgo, the Bega overflowed their banks and flooded almost the entire Neustadt. One cause was that the weir at the Langenbrücker Gate was under ice and could no longer be opened. Due to snowmelt and rain, the water accumulated and found its way through the streets of Lemgo, where the water level reached up to one meter. In some areas, the city could only be navigated by boat. The Bega flows into the Werre in Bad Salzuflen, with the Bega carrying more water there than the Werre. Downstream in Löhne, parts of the river-adjacent districts of Löhne-Ort, Gohfeld, Mennighüffen, and Obernbeck were flooded, with Obernbeck being the most affected. In Bad Oeynhausen, where the Werre flows into the Weser, parts of Dehme and Rehme were submerged in the floods. A day earlier, a dam along the Werre had broken over a length of 40 meters, which was only repaired two years later. In the Sielpark, a large landscaped park north of the spa park between the Hamm–Minden railway line and the Werre, there was a water level of two meters, leaving the area underwater. The lower-lying properties along the Werre and Kaarbach, which flows into the Werre in the Sielpark area, were affected by the flooding. The Werste fire department was on duty day and night, supplying the affected population with essentials using inflatable boats. However, not only the southern parts of Werste were severely hit, but also farms along the Weser. There were also floods along the Weser in Minden.

The devastating flood triggered a discussion. The realization: "In the 1400 square kilometer rainfall area of the Werre, the flood risk can only be reduced by constructing several retention basins." The Werre Water Association, founded in 1972, took care of their construction.
Similarly high under water was the Herford city center in February 1881, in November 1890, and in 1925.

Article_Name: Inundación en Río Negro de 1899, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Río Negro in 1899 was a meteorological event that occurred in the month of July of that year, affecting large regions of the then National Territory of Río Negro due to heavy rainfall that took place in the north of Argentine Patagonia, causing the destruction of the town of General Roca, Fort San Javier, Fort Pringles, and the localities of General Conesa and Viedma.

The rise of the Negro River, as a consequence of intense rains in the upper Limay basin during the months of May and June, advanced from the Alto Valle, sweeping everything in its path. The population of General Roca was flooded between July 16 and 20. The flooding of the Negro River valleys occurred according to the varying altitudes of each depression. By July 20, news of the total destruction of Fort Pringles (now Guardia Mitre) and Fort San Javier reached Viedma. The town of General Conesa was completely submerged on July 23. Governor José Eugenio Tello ordered the construction of defensive embankments along the coastal area of the city of Viedma. However, on July 18, the city began to be attacked by the water. On July 21, at eight in the morning, the embankments ordered by the governor broke, and the waters advanced over the city. The government house was abandoned by employees in boats, and the prisoners from the jail were transferred to the Patagones police station. The residents who had remained in the city were rescued by vessels such as the Limay steamer. On July 25, the only building still standing was the Salesian College, which managed to withstand the waters. That same day, the flood reached parts of Patagones; however, the high areas of the city remained intact. On July 27, the waters reached their highest level, and only three days later, they began to recede. In addition to being flooded by the river, Viedma was primarily inundated by the El Juncal lagoon, a large body of water located behind the city, stretching from the Zanjón de Oyuela to near the mouth of the Negro River. After the flood, the capital of the territory began to rebuild, but the people of Viedma faced the great challenge of drying the lagoon. Its drainage and evaporation took until the 1930s.

Whole_Text.header: Question of the capital of the Territory
Whole_Text.content: The governorship established the government of the Río Negro territory in Carmen de Patagones, but President Julio Argentino Roca decreed on September 4, 1899, the provisional transfer of the capital to Choele Choel, the only settlement in the valley that had been spared from the waters. Subsequently, through another decree dated November 2, Roca appointed a special commission to study the new location of the capital. General Roca, Choele Choel, San Antonio, and Viedma were presented as alternatives. Finally, based on the report prepared by the commission, the president decreed on May 10, 1900, Viedma as the definitive capital of the territory. The reinstatement of the capital in that locality took place on December 2 of that year, when the provincial authorities arrived in Viedma.

The town of General Roca was rebuilt 5 km west of its original location by order of Colonel Jorge Rodhe, considered the refounder of the city. The selected site was officially approved by Decree No. 3619 on September 25, 1899.

Article_Name: 2020年长江洪水 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2020 Yangtze River floods refer to a series of floods caused by continuous heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in China from June to August 2020. During this period, there were five floods that reached the intensity level for classification, named Yangtze River Flood No. 1 to Yangtze River Flood No. 5.
The 2020 Yangtze River No. 1 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in June 2020.

The inflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second as of 10:00 on July 2. The Ministry of Water Resources of the People's Republic of China, in accordance with the "Regulations on the Numbering of Major River Floods Nationwide," named this flood as the 2020 Yangtze River No. 1 Flood.

Starting from June 29, 2020, the outflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir was controlled at an average of 35,000 cubic meters per second daily to intercept upstream floods in an attempt to alleviate downstream flooding. [2] In July 2020, heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in China showed no signs of abating. The inflow from the main stream of the upper Yangtze River, Wujiang River, and the Three Gorges area significantly increased compared to June. On July 2, 2020, the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second. On the same day, the Ministry of Water Resources designated this flood as the "First Yangtze River Flood of 2020." The Yangtze River Water Resources Commission also initiated a Level IV emergency response for flood and drought disaster prevention on this day. [3] Xinhua News Agency reported that there would be three heavy rainfall events in the Yangtze River Basin over the next week, with cumulative rainfall in the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, Qingjiang River, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River's main stream expected to reach 100 to 150 millimeters. Tributaries in the Xiangxi area, the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, the Three Gorges area, Qingjiang River, the middle and lower reaches of the Hanjiang River, the Dongting Lake region, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River's main stream are expected to experience significant water level rises within the next week. Floods exceeding warning levels may occur in areas near Chenglingji on the Yangtze River's main stream, the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, and some small to medium-sized rivers. [4]

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 2 Flood refers to the flood that occurred under the circumstances of continued increase in water flow in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River main stream and the Three Gorges area, with the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir continuing to rise rapidly. The duration was approximately from July 14, 2020, to July 19, 2020.

At 10:00 on July 17, 2020, the inflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir rose significantly, reaching 50,000 cubic meters per second. From 2:00 to 12:00 on July 26, 2020, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir rapidly increased from 36,000 cubic meters per second to 50,000 cubic meters per second. The flow rate at the Cuntan station on the main stream of the upper Yangtze River rose to 50,900 cubic meters per second, meeting the flood numbering standard according to the "National Major Rivers Flood Numbering Regulations." [14]

The Palermo flood of July 15, 2020, was an exceptional inundation caused by an unprecedented heavy downpour, which overwhelmed the city of Palermo on the afternoon of July 15, 2020, the same day as the traditional Feast of Saint Rosalia, reaching a record height of almost one meter.

On the afternoon of July 15, the day of the Feast of Santa Rosalia, the city of Palermo was covered by a cloudy sky, with weather forecasts predicting a significantly smaller amount of rain than what actually occurred. Around 4:00 PM, the city experienced controlled rainfall, which had not yet caused significant damage but was gradually becoming more intense, and just five minutes later, the rain increased in intensity, with the drainage system struggling to handle the substantial amount of water accumulating on the streets. By around 4:30 PM, a violent storm hit the city, and by 5:00 PM, the city was effectively paralyzed, traffic came to a standstill, and police authorities began managing traffic to prevent emergency vehicles from getting stuck. During this time, many main roads were closed to traffic after about an hour of relentless rain, which allowed water to accumulate in underpasses and tunnels, reaching up to 4 meters in depth at the deepest point. In the outskirts of the city at the foot of the Palermo Mountains (such as the area of Baida), mud and stone flows rushed furiously downhill toward the city center. Numerous local police officers worked to redirect traffic on the Ring Road (the city's main artery connecting the A19 to the A29) and on parallel streets, forcing drivers to reverse their direction of travel. Meanwhile, firefighters used their amphibious vehicle to navigate the deepest areas. By 6:00 PM that same day, the rain gave way to a clear sky, allowing the people of Palermo to observe the extensive damage.

On the same day, numerous firefighters and civil protection volunteers began working to clear all the roads of the mass of mud obstructing passage. This operation continued day and night in the following days. On July 16, 2020, the mayor of Palermo requested that a state of natural disaster be declared, and the following day, the intervention of the army was necessary to speed up the work.

Some Palermo residents and Italian media immediately blamed the municipal administration, which should have carried out regular maintenance on the entire city’s sewer system.  
The causes of this flood are still to be determined; currently, an investigation for negligent disaster has been opened by the Palermo Prosecutor's Office.  
The response from the municipal administration was not long in coming: they immediately apologized to the citizens, stating that they will do everything possible to restore full traffic flow.

The calculated damages amount to approximately one million euros. Numerous cars were stuck in the mud or even submerged and will need to be compensated by various insurance companies.  
In the more secondary streets, many vehicles were destroyed by the force of the water that carried them for many meters. Damage was also reported in various cemeteries of the capital. In fact, at the city's largest cemetery, the Santa Maria dei Rotoli cemetery, the water did not spare the coffins awaiting burial, which were violently carried through the cemetery's streets; many of them suffered significant damage. Some damage was also observed in certain buildings: numerous cracks, in fact, were noticed after the flood due to water infiltration.

After the event, many people from all over Italy expressed solidarity with the affected city and its inhabitants, including numerous Ministers, Parliamentarians, and news outlets. Criticism was not lacking either, directed mainly at the local administration. On Twitter, many people, including Matteo Salvini, placed the entire blame on Palermo's mayor Leoluca Orlando, who also received solidarity from many others. After scenes filmed by the phones of some employees at the Rotoli cemetery, where coffins were seen floating in the mud, the councilor for Budget, Heritage, and Cemeteries, Roberto D’Agostino, resigned, acknowledging the problem.

Thanks to social networks, many videos recorded by passersby on adjacent streets or by citizens from their balconies have been shared, providing a 360° view of what was happening at that moment. There was no shortage of fear, anger, and bitterness for an event that has been recurring for years, albeit to a significantly lesser extent compared to this event. Some videos are going around the world showing scenes of motorists with their families forced to abandon their cars and swim to safety; numerous brave officers diving into the sludge and mud to help people in distress and save children (later hospitalized for hypothermia). This last image has become the symbol of this flood: a police officer, with a pickaxe, trying to break the glass and help people trapped in a partially submerged vehicle.

Article_Name: 1870年长江洪水 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 1870 Yangtze River flood was a catastrophic flood that occurred in the Yangtze River basin during June of the ninth year of the Tongzhi era (Gengwu year) in the Qing Dynasty. The provinces of Sichuan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangxi, and Anhui were affected, with the disaster being unprecedented in several hundred years. As it occurred in the Gengwu year, it was called the Gengwu Disaster.

In July 1870, as heavy rain entered the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, the Jialing River experienced a rare major flood. Based on water marks, the peak flow at Beibei Station was estimated to reach 57,300 cubic meters per second (the 1981 flood flow was 44,700 cubic meters per second). The major flood of the Jialing River and the flood of the Jinsha River converged in Chongqing, forming an extraordinary flood in the main stream of the Yangtze River. The water level at Cuntan Station reached 196.15 meters, with a peak flow of 100,000 cubic meters per second (the 1981 peak water level was 191.42 meters, with a flow of 85,700 cubic meters per second). According to records from Wanxian, the estimated 30-day flood volume was approximately 165 billion cubic meters. The flow at Yichang was about 105,000 cubic meters per second. After the Qing River joined, the peak flow at Zhicheng Station reached 110,000 cubic meters per second. 

In the northern Jingjiang area, multiple breaches occurred below Jianli, turning the Jianghan Plain into a vast expanse of water. On the southern bank of the Yangtze River, a breach at Songzi created the Songzi River, which directly discharged into Dongting Lake, leaving houses and farmland along the way completely destroyed. Modern scholars, based on stone inscriptions in places like Baxian, determined that the flood occurred from the 13th to the 21st of June [Reference 1]. After the flood, Sichuan Governor Wu Tang reported the disaster situation in eastern Sichuan. On the Renchen day in July, the Qing court responded, instructing Wu Tang to handle the disaster together with the provincial administration and dismissing Xu Junyong, the magistrate of Fengdu County, from his position [Reference 2]. 

In 1952, the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission conducted an investigation into this flood and concluded that it was the largest flood among the eight major historical floods of the Yangtze River from 1153 to the end of the 20th century, as well as among the five major floods measured in the 20th century [References 3, 4, 5].

During the early hours of August 9, 2020, a severe storm struck Evia, causing the death of 8 people and extensive damage in the municipalities of Dirfys-Messapia and Chalkida, specifically in Politika, Lefkanti, Vasiliko, and Psachna.

The region of central Euboea mainly drains into two rivers, the Messapios, which passes through Psachna, and the Lilandas, which flows out near Lefkanti. Additionally, a part of the Messapios drainage basin, covering an area of 44 square kilometers, was burned by a fire in 2019. Michalis Dakakis, a member of the Laboratory for the Study and Management of Natural Disasters at the University of Athens, described human interventions along the riverbeds as limited, but there are settlements in the floodplain of their estuaries.

In early August 2020, a cut-off atmospheric disturbance with a cold core approached Greece from the northwest and was named "Thalia" by the National Observatory of Athens. From August 4, 2020, the Hellenic National Meteorological Service (HNMS) had issued an emergency weather deterioration bulletin, which was updated two days later, warning of heavy rainfall in the region of Evia, among other areas. Starting on the evening of August 8, heavy rainfall and intense lightning activity were recorded in Evia, particularly between Nea Artaki, Psachna, and Steni. The severe weather formed clouds reaching a height of 12 kilometers, surpassing the boundary of the troposphere, and maintained its intensity for five hours. At the meteorological station in Steni, Evia, 300 millimeters of rain were recorded in eight hours, while at the Psachna station, the rainfall reached 226 millimeters. The rainfall resulted in the overflow of the Lilandas, Messapios, and Politika streams. The water level in various areas reached 1.5 meters, while in the center of Psachna, the water level reached one meter.

The floods caused the death of 8 people. In Politika, two adults and an 8-month-old infant lost their lives, in Amphithea two other adults, while in the Bourtsi area, near Lefkanti, two adults lost their lives, and in Lefkanti two people, a 73-year-old woman and a 72-year-old man, were swept away by the waters. While the woman was rescued from the sea, the man was found dead in Agioi Apostoloi Kalamos in Attica, on the opposite coast of South Evia.[7] He was identified as the close associate of Glafkos Clerides and Nicos Anastasiades, Giorgos Liveras, 72 years old.[8] The floods caused damage to 2,500 houses, as well as extensive damage to businesses and crops.[9] The floods caused damage to the bridges of Vasiliko, Afrati, and Fyllon, along the Lilandas River, resulting in part of the island being cut off from mainland Greece.[10] Specifically, the Fyllon bridge was destroyed and had to be replaced. The Vasiliko bridge was reopened to traffic on August 11.[11] The road network also suffered damage in other areas, such as the beach in Lefkanti, and in many places was covered with mud. Extensive damage was caused to the water supply and electricity networks of the villages, due to their proximity to streams, resulting in Psachna, Mistros, and Politika being left without water.[12]

The Saar flood was a centennial flood in Saarland from the end of 1947 to the beginning of 1948. Due to heavy rainfall and snowmelt in the Vosges, the Saar rose to up to 10.62 meters at the end of December, the highest level since the flood of 1784. The city centers of Saarbrücken, Saarlouis, Merzig, and Völklingen were affected. In Saarbrücken, Bahnhofstraße was about one meter underwater for a week. Several towboats broke loose from their moorings and came to rest on the meadow of Saarbrücken-St. Arnual Airport.

On October 12, 1948, special postage stamps with a surcharge for flood relief were issued. In Saarbrücken, two flood markers commemorate the high water level: on the building at Saarstraße 11, corner of Fröschengasse, and at the St. Johann Town Hall, back side of Gerberstraße.

Article_Name: Riuada del riu Francolí del 22 d'octubre del 2019 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Francolí River on October 22, 2019
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Francolí River on October 22, 2019, was a sudden rise in the flow of the Francolí River on the evening and night of October 22, 2019. The river's flow exceeded 1,200 m³/s when it is usually a water stream that does not reach 1 m³/s. The cause was a strong easterly storm that caused a large accumulation of water in the Prades mountains and a significant rise in the river.

Months later, the Catalan Water Agency (ACA) commissioned a study from the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the Polytechnic University of Catalonia - BarcelonaTech (UPC). The results linked a series of conditions that occurred during the night of October 22, 2019: Data from the Meteoprades weather stations added to the UPC study show that the highest rainfall values were recorded in Vilanova de Prades with 299 l/m²; Prades, with 293 l/m²; Tossal de la Baltasana with 240.6 l/m²; Alforja, with 264 l/m²; La Pobla de Cérvoles, with 254 l/m²; l'Aleixar, with 240 l/m²; Capafonts with 232 l/m²; Ulldemolins, with 220 l/m² and Les Masies (l'Espluga de Francolí) with 174 l/m². With these conditions, the rise in flow in the mentioned rivers and ravines was very rapid. In the counties of Pla de Lleida, Garrigues, Pla d'Urgell, and Urgell, the heavy downpours left roads and train tracks cut off and caused flooding of basements. It was the worst storm in the last fifty years in Pla de Lleida. However, in Conca de Barberà, the wave was deadly, as the waters descending from the Prades mountains, the Vilobí range, and the Vinaixa valley, which flow into Conca de Barberà at the height of Vimbodí and Poblet, were joined by water from torrents and streams on both sides of the Francolí river. This significant water flow was accompanied by a large amount of trees and material it had dragged along, known as solid flow. Between Vimbodí and Poblet, l'Espluga de Francolí, Montblanc, and Vilaverd, it resulted in a flood that uprooted all vegetation and trees in its path. The water flowed at high speed while trees and reeds created blockages, either by entangling with the vegetation of the riverbed or by clogging bridges. The peak flow, caused by water retention at some point upstream, reached unprecedented levels according to estimates made by the UPC. For example, the Milans river, which flows into l'Espluga de Francolí, recorded flows far above usual: 351 m³/s as it passed through Vimbodí and Poblet when it usually does not exceed 0.5 m³/s. At l'Espluga, flows reached up to 1,200 m³/s at the Palanca bridge when the usual flow is between 0.5 and 1 m³/s. Downstream, in Montblanc, before the first rains, only a trickle of water flowed, with just 0.2 m³/s. But in just 5 minutes, between 10:10 and 10:15 p.m., it went from 2 to 185 m³/s. In summary, a giant unstoppable wave occurred in Conca de Barberà. The magnitude of the rise was so large that the wave reached Tarragona city two hours later. If days earlier the flow was 1 m³/s, the wave was so extraordinary and exceptional that at 12:15 a.m., the river was already carrying 63 m³/s and suddenly rose to 1,238 m³/s at 12:30 a.m. The UPF study estimated that the Francolí river had carried away about 43,000 trees (14,000 m³ of wood) and had devastated a forested area of 160 hectares. Days later, pebbles and gravel came to dominate the riverbed, and many areas were left with bare rock. In the Lleida plain, in another hydraulic basin, the impacts were smaller and corresponded to the riverbeds of the Set river, the Corb river, the Ondara river, the Femosa torrent, and the Canals clamor.

Beyond the loss of trees and desolation, the flood caused four deaths and two more people who, a year later, remain missing. In Espluga de Francolí, one of the most affected towns, the flood swept away the Rendé Masdéu Winery, the El Celler restaurant located above it, and a playground. The active tourism company Drac Actiu S.L., located at the confluence of the Milans and Francolí rivers, the Fonda Les Disset Fonts, and the Funeconca funeral home also suffered severe damage. Downstream, in Montblanc, the medieval bridge withstood the force of the waters but was seriously damaged and obstructed, and the water carried away everything in its path, mainly orchards, irrigation channels, and small constructions. From the following day, firefighters, civil protection, and security forces began cleaning and protection tasks. At the same time, there was a significant citizen response: many volunteers helped with cleaning and reconstruction tasks and organized themselves. Civil society created "Riuada solidària al Francolí," an entity that organized a flood of activities to raise funds so that those affected could revive local businesses and restore the damaged areas. The citizen platform collected 152,396 euros as direct aid for those affected in the municipalities of Espluga de Francolí and Montblanc. State aid was slower. Until the summer of 2020, on August 27, the Official State Gazette (BOE) published a Royal Decree that launched a regime of aid to local entities for the recovery of areas affected by the October 2019 storm and the Gloria storm at the beginning of 2020. Various municipalities in Conca de Barberà stated that the measure came late. For example, according to the mayor of Espluga de Francolí, Josep M. Vidal, they had certified the damages, but in no case did they receive the aid they had been waiting for over ten months. In Conca de Barberà, at the beginning of 2021, many buildings and heritage assets were still pending repair. A similar situation occurred in nine towns in Les Garrigues, with Arbeca and Vinaixa being the most affected municipalities, still waiting for subsidies to repair roads and facilities valued at around five million euros.

Article_Name: Baah wan Rumbih Nusa Tenggara Timur 2021 - Wikipidia Banjar, kindai pangatahuan

Whole_Text.header: Baah won Rumbih East Nusa Tenggara 2021
Whole_Text.content: The flood and landslide in East Nusa Tenggara 2021 was a disaster of floods and landslides that occurred in parts of the East Nusa Tenggara province, Indonesia, on April 4-5, 2021. This flood and landslide disaster was caused by Cyclone Seroja, which triggered heavy rainfall and thunderstorms in NTT, NTB, and Timor Leste.

Eighteen villages in East Flores were hit by floods due to the overflow of water and materials from Mount Lewotolo. As of April 5, the disaster has claimed at least 62 lives, injured 9, left 27 missing, and affected 49 households. The floods also caused 17 houses to be swept away, 60 houses to be submerged in mud, and five bridges to be broken or severely damaged. At least 256 residents are temporarily taking refuge at the Nelemawangi Village Hall. The high number of fatalities is suspected to be due to many people sleeping during the time Cyclone Seroja made landfall. Four Pertamina fuel trucks were also reported damaged. In Nelelamadike Village, Ile Boleng Subdistrict, 35 people died, 5 were injured, 19 went missing, and 9 households or 20 people were affected. In Waiburak Village, East Adonara Subdistrict, 3 people died, 4 were injured, and 7 are still missing. In Oyang Barang Village, Wotan Ulumado Subdistrict, 3 residents died, and one other is missing, while 40 households were affected.

A total of 18 people died and 37 people went missing in Lembata Regency due to the disaster. The Lembata BPBD recorded that the areas affected by the flood were Waowala Village, Tanjung Batu Village, and Amakaka Village located in Ile Ape District. In addition, the flood also affected Jontona Village, Lamawolo Village, and Waimatan Village located in East Ile Ape District.
The areas affected by floods in Malaka Regency include;[12] the Benenai Bridge located in Weliman District, Malaka Regency, NTT changed shape and parts of the road were damaged by the flood.
The East Sumba Regency BPBD reported that 54 families or 165 people were temporarily displaced, while 109 families or 475 people were affected.

Head of BPBD Kota Kupang, Jemmy Didok, stated that at least 2,190 people were affected and 734 houses were damaged due to floods, landslides, and strong winds. [14] The Transtimor road in Kota Kupang was flooded and disrupted inter-district routes. [14] A bridge connecting Kota Kupang and Malaka Regency was also destroyed. [15] A motorized ferry (KMP) Jatra 1, which was docked at Bolok Port, Kupang, sank. [16]

The rescue efforts in East Flores Regency were hampered by a lack of heavy equipment, poor access due to sea conditions, and insufficient temporary shelters. The State Electricity Company (PLN) managed to repair 82% of the damaged electrical infrastructure, while the rest remained unrepaired due to bad weather. Kupang City declared a disaster emergency, but the government still faced a shortage of funds and personnel to handle the disaster. A temporary bridge was built to assist rescue efforts in East Flores. The Head of the National Disaster Management Agency, Doni Monardo, visited East Flores on April 5, 2021. In addition to boats, temporary shelters, and personnel, the Indonesian government also sent food aid, blankets, masks, and rapid antigen test kits for COVID-19. The distribution of aid was still hindered by weather conditions and damaged infrastructure. The House of Representatives urged the government to expedite aid distribution and requested assistance from TNI soldiers.

The response of the regional government was criticized by several parties. The hashtag #PrayforNTT went viral in Indonesia through the social media platform Twitter. WALHI urged the East Nusa Tenggara Provincial Government to declare a disaster emergency and criticized the lack of response from Governor Viktor Laiskodat. The Prosperous Justice Party criticized President Joko Widodo for attending the wedding of Atta Halilintar and Aurel Hermansyah instead of addressing the disaster caused by Cyclone Seroja.

The flood in Leningrad on September 23, 1924, became the second highest in the history of St. Petersburg after the flood of 1824, with the water level rising 369–380 centimeters above the normal level.

As with other floods in Saint Petersburg, the cause was cyclones with strong winds coming from the Gulf of Finland, which pushed Baltic waves against the Neva River's currents. A contributing factor was the abnormally high level of precipitation in the region in 1923 and 1924, which oversaturated the soil and raised the levels of the Gulf of Finland and Lake Ladoga. On the morning of September 23, there were no signs of the impending flood, but by noon, a strong westerly wind began to blow, and the water level in the Neva started to rise rapidly. At 1:20 PM, five cannon shots from the Peter and Paul Fortress signaled a water rise of 5 feet, followed by shots every half hour, and later every 15 minutes. Around 3 PM, water began flooding Vasilyevsky Island from both the west and east. Other parts of the city soon followed, primarily Admiralty Island and the Petrograd Side. Streets were submerged, basements used as storage, engine rooms, and housing for the poorest residents were flooded. In some areas, the first floors of buildings were underwater. The city's widespread wooden block pavements were destroyed; their wooden blocks, along with floating firewood, clogged the streets and obstructed movement even after the water receded. After 7 PM, the flood reached its peak, with the water level exceeding the ordinary mark by up to 380 centimeters, second only to the flood of a century earlier, which reached 369.4 cm. Fires broke out in various parts of the city, including at an explosives factory on Vatny Island. Soon, the water level began to drop rapidly, and after 10 PM, residents who had taken refuge on the upper floors of buildings were able to return home. By midnight, the water had receded to 1 meter above the ordinary mark. Martial law was declared in Leningrad, and in the following days, the city began recovery efforts with local and external assistance. Official data estimated the death toll at 16 people, a figure that eyewitnesses found highly questionable. In a 1986 study, hydrologist Alexei Sokolov estimated the death toll at 600. Over 15,000 families were left homeless. In the Petrogradsky District, 2,040 buildings were flooded, 1,460 in the Central District, 912 on Vasilyevsky Island, 660 in the Moskovsko-Narvsky District, 80 in the Vyborgsky District, and 67 in the Volodarsky District. The flood destroyed 19 city bridges, including the Sampsonievsky and Grenadersky bridges, and damaged dozens more. Two million square meters of pavement and 120 tram cars were damaged, 550 trees in the Summer Garden and on the spit of Yelagin Island were destroyed. The port and many factories were damaged, telephone communication was disrupted, and the most severely affected were the Krasny Putilovets and Russian Diesel plants. Forty ships sank or were washed ashore. The railway line to Sestroretsk was particularly damaged. The material damage from the flood was estimated at 130 million rubles. The Main Geophysical Observatory faced criticism for its forecast of a water level rise on September 23 of no more than 4 feet. The floods in Leningrad and the fight against them received significant attention from the press and leading scientists. In 1925, at the request of the provincial executive committee, a book titled "Leningrad in the Fight Against the Flood" was published, describing both the scientific aspects of the floods and the efforts to combat them and their consequences. The construction of a dam in the Harbor was announced. A few years later, a project for hydraulic structures to protect the city was presented, but the construction of such a complex only began in the late 1970s. On November 20, 1924, a postal-charity issue of postage stamps titled "To Aid Flood-Stricken Leningrad" was released.
In Tamara Petkevich's book "Life is an Odd Boot," the 1924 flood in Leningrad is mentioned.

Article_Name: Hochwasser der Ahr am 13. Juni 1910 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Ahr on June 13, 1910
Whole_Text.content:
The flood on the Ahr on June 13, 1910, was one of the largest historically documented flood disasters in the Ahr Valley.  
The Ahr is a left tributary of the Rhine.

There are high-water marks in Altenahr, Dernau, and Walporzheim, as well as photos of the flood in Bad Neuenahr, from which the following peak discharges can be reconstructed: in Altenahr 496 m³/s, Dernau 549 m³/s, Walporzheim 541 m³/s, and Bad Neuenahr 585 m³/s. For comparison, the average discharge of the Ahr at its mouth is about 8 m³/s, and the highest value measured at the Altenahr gauge before the 2021 flood was 236 m³/s (flood on June 2, 2016). The flood delayed the expansion of the Ahr Valley Railway and destroyed scaffolding, canteens, and almost all road bridges. The damage to private households and municipalities in the districts of Adenau and Ahrweiler amounted to about 2.7 million marks (equivalent to about 19.1 million EUR today). In addition, there were destructions during railway construction and damages to state buildings. The damage was distributed with 1.5 million to the Adenau district and 1.2 million to the Ahrweiler district. In the 1920s, concrete plans for flood protection were developed due to the 1910 flood disaster. These included flood retention basins that could have held a total of 11.3 million cubic meters of water. However, these plans were postponed in favor of the construction of the Nürburgring and have not been realized to this day.

Article_Name: Hochwasser der Ahr am 21. Juli 1804 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Ahr on July 21, 1804
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Ahr on July 21, 1804, claimed 63 lives and caused severe devastation. Many houses were swept away by the flood. The Ahr is a left tributary of the Rhine.

The high water levels are marked on buildings in Pützgasse in Walporzheim and Burgstraße in Dernau. From this, a probable peak discharge of 1208 m³/s can be reconstructed for Dernau, while the average discharge of the Ahr at the Altenahr gauge is about 8 m³/s, and the highest value measured there so far was 236 m³/s (flood of 2016). The damages were immense: reports to the (then French) government mentioned 129 residential houses, 162 barns or stables, 18 mills, and 8 forges as completely destroyed. 469 residential houses, 234 barns or stables, two mills, and one forge were heavily damaged. 78 horses and draft cattle were reported drowned, and much other livestock must have drowned. The vineyards and fruit trees in the Ahr Valley were largely destroyed. Nearly all bridges collapsed, with almost 30 bridges mentioned. This also applied to the stone bridges, including the Ahr Bridge in Rech. In Altenburg, the chapel was swept away, and a new one was built afterward. In Mayschoß, a bridge, eight residential houses, as well as an equal number of barns or stables, and one forge were destroyed. 55 residential buildings and 55 barns or stables suffered very severe damage. However, all residents were able to save themselves.

The floods in Turkey in 2021 occurred in mid-July and mid-August 2021 at the Black Sea.

In the northeast of Turkey, in the province of Rize on the Black Sea, heavy torrential rain triggered floods and landslides. Late on Wednesday, July 14, 2021, several cars were swept away, and several houses collapsed. Rescue teams recovered three bodies after mudslides. Dozens of villages were cut off by the heavy rainfall, power supply was interrupted in many households, and several hundred people had to be evacuated from their homes.  
The region on the Black Sea is frequently affected by heavy rain and flash floods. Media reported six fatalities, two in the municipality of Muradiye, one in Güneysu, and three in the village of Ballıdere.  
On Thursday, July 15, 2021, the Minister of Environment and Urban Planning, Murat Kurum, and the Minister of Transport and Infrastructure, Adil Karaismailoğlu, visited the disaster area and promised assistance to the affected locals.

On Tuesday, August 10, and Wednesday, August 11, 2021, there were again floods and landslides in the regions along the Black Sea. The province of Bartın was most affected by the rainfall. Floods were also reported in the provinces of Karabük and Kastamonu. By Saturday, August 14, 2021, at least 58 people had lost their lives and nearly 80 people were reported missing.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1741, also known as the flood of 1740 and 1741, was a flooding event in which large areas of the Dutch river region were inundated. On December 24, 1740, the dikes near Bemmel and Elden broke. Although there were few human casualties during the breaches, the material damage was significant. Livestock drowned en masse. The dikes could only be repaired in April. Due to the prolonged duration, the wind, and the drifting ice, many homes were damaged. For example, in Bleskensgraaf, only three houses remained undamaged, and in Ottoland, not a single house was spared. In the eyes of many, the dike breaches and floods were instruments of God to punish the people of the Netherlands for their sins. Reverend Wilhelmus Themmen, a minister in Arnhem, dedicated a book to it in 1741 titled: "God's Righteous Judgment with the Inhabitants of the Netherlands through the Violence of Winds and Waters." He also provided the motives: "To sensibly punish the flood of their escalating sins through the flood of overflowing rivers, and to warn the careless crowd against the roaring of enemy nations; so that the land and church are not suddenly overrun and devoured with all their splendor by their military might." Reverend Themmen likely referred to the threats to the Republic from the War of the Austrian Succession. He was not alone in his view that the flood was a chastisement from God for the sins of the people. In the Over-Betuwe region, five deaths were reported. In the Alblasserwaard region, there is mention of "a few." The low number of casualties can be explained by eyewitness accounts stating that the water rose slowly, providing sufficient opportunity to flee to attics and often higher-located churches. The rescue work and emergency relief in 1741 were primarily the responsibility of surrounding cities and private aid committees.

Whole_Text.content:
The flood of 1726 was a deluge in which large areas of the Dutch river region were inundated. On January 14, frost set in, and eventually, the rivers froze. After two weeks of frost, the thaw began. This caused the river water to rise, while much of the ice had not yet disappeared. This was feared by the residents due to the danger of flooding caused by accumulating ice.  
On January 21, the water in Ameide reached the crest of the dike. Throughout the river region, dikes were hastily reinforced. However, from Streefkerk to Krimpen, the ice formed a dam, causing the water to back up. The pressure on the dikes became so great that the dike of the Krimpenerwaard broke. Additionally, an ice dam had formed, stretching from Gorinchem to Hardinxveld-Giessendam. On February 1, 1726, the dike between Ochten and Dodewaard broke. The Haaften preacher Rev. Thiele wrote the following about it in his book "Schouwburg der Oordelen en Gerigten Gods": "The high water broke the dike/ which collapsed with a terrible crash/ devastated the nearby orchards and arable lands/ covered them with water and sand/ and within a few hours flooded the Nederbetuwe from the Waal dike to the Lek dike/ so that in the morning, at daybreak, one could see the rushing water foaming past the city of Thiel/ with a terrible noise/ and from there over the Linge dike/ which from the Thiel sluice (draining into the Linge opposite Teedingsweerd) took away the entire crest of the Linge dike up to Wadenoyen." In the Bommelerwaard as well, the dikes broke in several places. On February 7, the Linge dike near Kedichem broke. Large areas were now underwater. The combination of the long duration and persistent westerly winds caused extensive damage. One writer says: "Everywhere one saw goods, chests, cabinets, and other household items floating; heartbreaking was the lamentation of the women, the crying of the children, the shouting and complaints of the men, and the bellowing of the animals; many had to leave their homes and seek refuge on the dikes with their offspring and livestock; others, whose houses were in danger of being swept away by the water, had to be rescued with small boats, and so everyone parted from their homes, not knowing if they would ever find them again."

Whole_Text.header: Heavy rain in August of Reiwa 3 (2021)
Whole_Text.content: In the heavy rain of August 2021 (Reiwa 3), it describes the heavy rain that occurred mainly in western Japan from August 11, 2021 (Reiwa 3), and the resulting damage.

In August 2021, due to a pressure pattern close to the end of the rainy season, and the influence of an active front, record-breaking heavy rain occurred over a wide area across the country. In northern Kyushu, rainfall exceeded 1,000 millimeters from the 11th, with some areas reaching 50% of their annual rainfall in less than a week. This led to frequent occurrences of river flooding, landslides, and road collapses. Additionally, many buses, railways, and other transportation systems were suspended, and highway and national road closures occurred one after another. In Yaotsu Town, Kamo District, Gifu Prefecture, damage from a tornado was also reported. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued "Emergency Heavy Rain Warnings" and "General Meteorological Information on Significant Heavy Rain" due to the formation of linear precipitation bands in various areas. The total accumulated rainfall for mid-August (11th to 20th), calculated from 1,029 AMeDAS points nationwide since 1982, was 235,788.5 millimeters (229.1 millimeters per point), surpassing the record set during the July 2018 heavy rain (Western Japan Heavy Rain). On August 13, the government upgraded the Information Liaison Office at the Prime Minister's Office Crisis Management Center to the Prime Minister's Office Liaison Office. On the same morning, the government held a "Meeting of Relevant Cabinet Ministers on Heavy Rain Centered in Western Japan" at the Prime Minister's Office. Then-Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga instructed the establishment of a Specific Disaster Response Headquarters to prepare for disasters caused by the record-breaking heavy rain. That afternoon, a Specific Disaster Response Headquarters was established, headed by then-Minister for Disaster Management Yasufumi Tanahashi. As of 7:00 p.m. on the 14th, "Emergency Safety Measures" were issued for seven prefectures (Nagano, Gifu, Shimane, Hiroshima, Fukuoka, Saga, and Nagasaki) covering 820,000 households and 1.81 million people. By the morning of the 15th, the measures were issued for six prefectures (Chiba, Nagano, Shimane, Hiroshima, Fukuoka, and Saga) covering 260,000 households and 580,000 people. Additionally, in Yamakita Town and Matsuda Town in Ashigarakami District, Kanagawa Prefecture, and Himi City in Toyama Prefecture, torrential rain exceeding 100 millimeters per hour was recorded, prompting the issuance of "Record-Breaking Short-Term Heavy Rain Information." According to the Fire and Disaster Management Agency of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, 13 deaths were confirmed nationwide due to the series of heavy rains. The Disaster Relief Act was applied to 21 municipalities in Nagano, Shimane, Hiroshima, Fukuoka, Saga, and Nagasaki Prefectures.
