Article_Name: 1990년 한강 대홍수 - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: The 1990 Han River Great Flood was a flood and disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the Han River basin of South Korea over four days from September 9 to 12, 1990. It was the largest heavy rainfall in the Han River basin since the Great Flood of 1925, with an average rainfall of 452mm in the central region and a record-high water level of 13.63m above sea level and a height of 13.70m at the Jamsu Bridge observation point. The Han River basin also recorded its highest water level of 11.27m at around 6:30 PM on September 11, issuing the sixth flood warning in history. The disaster resulted in 126 deaths, 37 missing persons, a total of 163 casualties, and 187,265 flood victims. The northern embankment near Haengju Bridge in the lower Han River collapsed, flooding the Goyang County area in Gyeonggi Province and causing massive damage. Despite the discharge from Chungju Dam, heavy rain caused flooding in the upper Namhan River, including the Danyang area in North Chungcheong Province, leading to flood damage in various parts of the central region.

Typhoon Dot, the 17th typhoon of 1990, made landfall in southern China between September 7-8, connecting with a mid-latitude low-pressure system in central Seoul, forming a powerful low-pressure system. This low-pressure system created a pressure trough due to the collision between the cold and dry continental high-pressure system and the hot and humid maritime high-pressure system over the southern seas of Japan, forming a strong rain cloud band that remained stationary. The stationary rain cloud band produced heavy concentrated rainfall centered around the Han River basin in the central region between the 10th and 12th.

The heavy rain that began in the early hours of September 9 concentrated on Seoul and the Gyeonggi region. Over four days, rainfall amounts were recorded as follows: 581.2 mm in Icheon, Gyeonggi Province; 529.6 mm in Suwon; 512.5 mm in Ganghwa; 508.9 mm in Hongcheon; 491.7 mm in Yangpyeong; and 486.2 mm in Seoul. At that time, Icheon and Suwon in Gyeonggi Province experienced continuous rainfall of 59 mm per hour. In particular, Suwon recorded a daily rainfall of 296.3 mm. On the 9th, heavy rain of 80-120 mm fell in the upper regions of the Bukhan River, including Toegyewon and Paldang in northern Gyeonggi Province. On the 10th, 100-150 mm of rain fell in most areas of the Han River's main stream and the Bukhan River basin, with some areas of the Namhan River recording up to 150 mm of rainfall. On the same day, at 10 a.m., the Central Meteorological Office issued a heavy rain advisory for Seoul and the Gyeonggi region, which was upgraded to a heavy rain warning at 2 p.m. with expected rainfall of 150-200 mm. Additionally, a heavy rain advisory was issued for Gangwon Province. As of the 9th, over 100 mm of heavy rain had already fallen in Seoul and the Gyeonggi region, resulting in two deaths and flooding of roads and houses in various locations. At around 8 p.m. on the 10th, a heavy rain warning was issued across the entire metropolitan area, and due to continued heavy rain, a flood advisory was issued for the Han River at 2 a.m. on the 11th, which was upgraded to a flood warning at 8 a.m. On the 11th, rainfall exceeded 200 mm across the entire Han River basin, with the Shinpung area near the Soyang River Dam recording a maximum rainfall of 620 mm. By the 12th, heavy rain had ceased in most areas, with light rain of around 10 mm continuing in the upper regions of the Chungju Dam. Overall, the concentrated heavy rain in the central region from the 9th to the 12th recorded an average rainfall of 452 mm over three days, marking the heaviest rainfall in 200 years.

By September 9, two people had died. In Beon 2-dong, Dobong-gu, Seoul, a 6-month-old baby boy died as his house was submerged due to heavy rain, and in the construction site behind Daejin High School in Hagye-dong, Nowon-gu, a 10-year-old boy fell into a 3-meter-deep pit and died. From the first day of heavy rain on the 9th, Tongil-ro was submerged, restricting traffic. The damage from the heavy rain in Seoul was mainly concentrated on the 11th. At around 4:40 PM on the 11th, a cruise ship belonging to Wonkwang Co., anchored at Yeouido dock, broke free due to the fast current and collided with a barge and another cruise ship belonging to Semo Co. Shortly after the collision, all three vessels were swept away by the strong current, and the barge "Nodeul Naruho" and two cruise ships, "Wonkwangho" and "Nodeulho," were swept away or collided up to Mapo Bridge, causing damage to the bridge. The "Wonkwangho" avoided collision by starting its engine just before hitting Mapo Bridge, but the "Nodeulho" sank after colliding with the bridge, leaving three crew members missing and injuring about 30 crew members from the "Nodeulho" and the barge. Additionally, Mapo Bridge, damaged by the collision with the barge, was temporarily closed to traffic. At that time, a flood from the upper reaches of the Han River flowed entirely into the river, significantly raising its water level. The water level at Hangang In-dogyo reached a peak of 11.27 meters on September 11, far exceeding the danger level of 10.5 meters. Several bridges on the Han River, including Jamsil Railway Bridge, were submerged up to their piers on the 11th, and the Noryangjin area, including the fish market, was completely flooded. The tributary of Anyangcheon, Gaebongcheon, overflowed, submerging Gaebong-dong, and the area around Gaebong Station was entirely underwater. The area around Noryangjin Station was also submerged up to the chest level of an adult male, leading to a complete suspension of the Gyeongin Line from the morning of the 11th. In addition, in Gahoe-dong, Jongno-gu, the roof of a hanok village collapsed due to heavy rain early on the 11th, killing a family of three. At that time, 152 companies in the Guro Industrial Complex area were submerged, causing industrial damage. The embankments of the Han River collapsed in several places, completely submerging areas such as Pungnap-dong, Cheonho-dong, and Seongnae-dong in Gangdong-gu to a height of 1-1.5 meters, including the Gangdong-gu Office building. Over 150 people were rescued by helicopter and about 600 by boat from the flooded areas. Seongnae-dong and Pungnap-dong suffered the worst flooding in six years since the 1984 Han River flood. In Gangnam-gu, areas such as Suseo-dong, Segok-dong, around Yangjae Pumping Station, and Yangjae-dong were flooded, forcing 500 households to evacuate. Low-lying areas like Samseong-dong and Daechi-dong were also completely submerged. In Yongsan-gu, areas such as Yongsan 5-ga, Cheongpa 1-ga, Hangang 1-ga, Wonhyo 3-ga, and parts of Bogwang-dong were also flooded. Many schools in Seoul were affected, with 15 schools, including Gaebong Elementary School, Pungnap Middle School, and Sudong Middle School, being flooded on the 11th, and six schools, including Daeseong High School and Seocho Middle School, suffering damage such as retaining wall collapses due to the heavy rain.

In Incheon, on the 12th at 12:40 PM, a landslide occurred in Songnim 5-dong, Dong-gu, due to heavy rainfall in 1990, resulting in the simultaneous death of 23 residents in broad daylight. Additionally, due to the possibility of further collapses caused by the retaining wall collapse from this landslide accident, around 1,000 residents in the area evacuated on September 15.

In Gyeonggi Province alone, 47 roads were washed away, including the collapse of Bisan Bridge in Anyang City, and approximately 50,000 hectares of farmland were submerged. During the heavy rainfall, the highest amount of rain fell nationwide, and in Goyang County, the collapse of the Han River embankment caused the most significant damage. Additionally, three water purification plants, including the Gyeongan purification plant in Gwangju County, were submerged, resulting in water supply disruptions for over 50,000 households and power outages for 12,000 households. On the 11th, the overflow of Anyangcheon and Mokgamcheon rivers caused flooding in most areas of low-lying districts in Gwangmyeong City, such as Gwangmyeong 1, 2, 3, and 7-dong, Cheolsan 1-dong, Haan 1-dong, and Soa 1-dong, displacing over 11,000 people from 3,000 households. In Uiwang City, over 620 mm of heavy rain fell in a single day on the 11th, leaving more than 2,600 residents from 635 households in six districts displaced. In Gunpo City, 280 households and 900 people were displaced on the 11th. Northern Gyeonggi Province also suffered damage. On the 11th, a landslide occurred on the hillside of Bullori in Gimpo County due to heavy rain, burying the dormitory of Geumgang Industry, resulting in six deaths and nine rescues. Two people went missing at an aggregate extraction site in Gimpo County, and one person was swept away in Sangnongcheon, Goyang County. The overflow of Wangsukcheon displaced over 2,000 people from 510 households in Donong-ri, Migeum City, and caused flooding in most areas of Gyomun-ri, Supyeong-dong, and Sutaek-dong in Guri City, displacing 8,600 people from 2,200 households. Over 10,000 people were displaced in five cities and counties along Wangsukcheon. The overflow of the Imjin River also flooded the Gyoha Plain in Paju County. In Yangju County, 100 meters of the Jungnangcheon embankment in Namban-ri, Junae-myeon, was washed away, as well as the Chukseok Pass road in Ja-il-dong, Uijeongbu City. Additionally, 80 meters of the embankment near Obokgyo in Songsan-dong, Uijeongbu City, three water facilities in Sudong-myeon, Namyangju County, and 25 meters of embankments in five rivers were washed away. By the 11th, a total of 45 people had died in Gyeonggi Province alone. In addition to the aforementioned fatalities, five members of a family in Hwaseo-dong, Suwon City, were among the seven deaths in Suwon City, with two deaths each in Gwangju County and Seongnam County, and one death each in Yeoju County, Uiwang City, Gapyeong County, and five deaths in Yongin County.

Whole_Text.header: Collapse of the Han River embankment
Whole_Text.content: After the night of the 11th, the flood situation of the Han River was improving, but around 3 a.m. on September 12, the northern embankment near Haengju Bridge in the lower Han River collapsed over a length of 334 meters, submerging 70% of the total area of Goyang County, including 38 villages in Ilsan-eup, 29 villages in Jido-eup, and 16 villages in Songpo-myeon, resulting in a total of 83 villages being flooded. The lower Han River embankment in Sinpyeong-ri, Jido-eup, Goyang County, collapsed, causing water to pour in, covering homes and farmland, spreading toward Neunggok and Ilsan, and flooding up to the vicinity of Sumaksan. At the time, the sudden flooding of the Han River in Goyang County submerged 5,000 hectares of farmland, and more than 50,000 displaced residents evacuated to high ground such as Haengju Fortress. The collapsed embankment was in an area with a narrow river width and weak ground, and demands for reinforcement and reconstruction had been continuously raised. It was pointed out during the 1984 flood as well, but it was left unattended, and the embankment, which had been leaking water since dawn, eventually collapsed. Due to the flooding in Goyang County, the Christian Broadcasting System (CBS) transmission station in Neunggok, Haengjunae-ri, Jido-eup, was flooded, causing a broadcasting interruption. Additionally, around 11 p.m. on the 12th, the Han River embankment in front of Sumaksan in Samyang-ri, Gyohwa-myeon, Paju County, also collapsed under water pressure, with a width of 5 meters and a length of 80 meters, but as it was an uninhabited area, there were no casualties. The flood situation near the collapsed Haengju Bridge embankment subsided from the 13th, as the Han River water receded and the ebb tide returned, and at the same time, restoration work on the Han River embankment was carried out to prevent further flood damage. The damaged Haengju Bridge Han River embankment was temporarily restored on September 18, six days after the flood, with the completion of water-blocking construction.

In Gangwon Province, heavy rains caused 5 deaths, 7 missing persons, and 2 injuries by the 11th. In Jungdo, located in the middle of Uiam Lake in Chuncheon City, 112 residents were isolated, and more than 150 people were also stranded in Hajungdo due to the heavy rain. Additionally, nearly 3,700 hectares of farmland were flooded, over 20 national and local roads in Gangwon Province were submerged and cut off, and 514 buildings were flooded, leaving over 400 households displaced. On the morning of the 11th, at Yongpyong Resort in Daegwallyeong-myeon (formerly Doam-myeon), Pyeongchang County, two employees went missing while opening the floodgates as the lake within the resort overflowed, resulting in a total of 4 casualties in Pyeongchang County. Furthermore, in Yeongwol County, record-breaking rainfall of over 350 mm in a single day completely submerged Yeongwol-eup, displacing about 5,000 residents. Farmland spanning 500 hectares and two poultry farms were also flooded, causing property damage exceeding 930 million won in just one day.

In Chungcheongbuk-do, due to heavy rainfall, 3 people died, and 25 households with over 600 residents were displaced by the 11th. As the discharge rate of Chungju Dam continued to increase, the water from Palcheon River and Yodo River, flowing through Jungwon County (now Chungju City), overflowed, putting houses in Hagyeomdan-ri, Irimyeon, at risk of flooding. Forty-five buildings collapsed, and 600 hectares of farmland were submerged. Additionally, 14 roads were washed away, 1,500 meters of embankments at 18 locations were destroyed, and the Jungang Line railway was damaged, cutting off transportation between Jecheon City and Wonju City. At 5 a.m. on the 12th, Chungju Dam overflowed, flooding five districts, including the urban area of Danyang County. Furthermore, the Ssangyong Cement factory in Danyang was submerged, and the section of National Route 3 near Chungju Dam was also flooded, disrupting traffic.

Due to the heavy rainfall on the 11th, all lines of the Yeongdong Line, Jungang Line, Taebaek Line, Gyeongui Line, and Suin Line were suspended. The Gyeongin Line was also fully suspended, but the sections between Seoul Station and Guro Station, and Oryudong Station and Incheon Station were restored on the afternoon of September 11. For the Suin Line, the sections between Suwon Station and Ansan Station, and Namdong Station and Songdo Station were flooded, leading to a complete suspension of operations. The Jungang Line experienced landslides, with Gujeon-ri Station and Paldang Station being swept away, and the tracks between Yeongyu Station and Guhak Station, Sinlim Station and Changgyo Station, Neungnae Station and Yangsu Station, Deokso Station and Paldang Station, and Donong Station and Deokso Station being buried or washed away. The Taebaek Line also saw sections between Jeungsan Station and Doro Station, and Yeongwol Station and Cheongnyeongpo Station being washed away due to river flooding, while the sections between Hambak Station and Jodong Station, and Eungok Station and Baeksan Station were fully suspended due to landslides and flooding. The Gyeongchun Line was temporarily single-tracked due to landslides caused by the heavy rain but was restored around 6:15 PM on the 11th. On the 12th, a levee collapse in Goyang County caused large-scale flooding on the Gyeongui Line, with the old Neunggok Station also being flooded at the time. The Jungang Line was fully restored around 5 PM on the 12th.

On the 11th, 66 locations nationwide, including highways, national roads, and local roads, were cut off and controlled due to landslides and flooding. A 30-meter section of the road in Gisawol-ri, Hongcheon-gun, Gangwon-do, was washed away, cutting off traffic between Chuncheon and Hongcheon, and the road in Chapyung 3-ri, Yangpyeong-gun, Gyeonggi-do, was also severed by a landslide. Five bridges connecting Munsan and Jeonggok in Paju-gun and Wangjin-myeon in Yeoncheon-gun were submerged, and the No. 6 National Road (Gyeonggang National Road) passing through Paldang-gun, Namyangju-gun, and the bridge in Sinbok-myeon, Pocheon-gun, collapsed, temporarily halting traffic. Mapo Bridge was closed on the 11th due to a barge collision accident but reopened around 8 p.m. on the 12th. This caused severe congestion on nearby bridges such as Wonhyo Bridge. As of the 12th, three Han River bridges—Jamsu Bridge, Gwangjin Bridge, and Haengju Bridge—remained closed to traffic, and the entire section of Olympic Boulevard from east to west was flooded, halting traffic. On Gangbyeonbuk-ro, the northern ends of the Hangang Railway Bridge and Jamsil Bridge were also closed to traffic. Additionally, several sections within Seoul were flooded, causing inconvenience due to blocked traffic.
On the 11th, parts of the runway and access road at Gangneung Airport were flooded, and all flights were suspended in the afternoon.

On the 11th alone, operations on 109 routes nationwide were suspended. In the case of Incheon Port, 21 passenger ships on the Incheon-Baengnyeongdo route were suspended, and 63 routes at Mokpo Port were also suspended.

The heavy rain caused concerns about flood damage, leading to a surge in phone calls, which resulted in a sharp increase in phone usage. The call volume at major telephone exchanges more than doubled, causing delays in phone connections, and many areas experienced phone outages due to submerged relay cables and telephone lines. The water level of the Han River rose rapidly, leading to water supply cuts in some areas. The intake volume at the Paldang water source decreased, and part of the Noryangjin water source was flooded, resulting in water supply cuts in 16 districts of Seoul from 1:30 PM on the 11th, with an additional 18 districts affected from 3 PM. As of 5 PM on the 12th, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries of South Korea reported that 57,000 hectares of farmland were damaged, with 54,000 hectares submerged, of which 2,600 hectares were either washed away or buried, making farming impossible and significantly impacting rice harvests on the Korean Peninsula. This flood led to the promotion of the Donggang Dam construction.

President Roh Tae-woo visited the Han River Flood Control Office on September 11 to inspect the flood damage situation. On September 12, he toured the flood-affected areas in Goyang County and then presided over a meeting at the Blue House to discuss countermeasures. Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon held a meeting with relevant ministers on September 11 to address flood countermeasures, deciding to allocate 140 billion won from the budget reserve and 180 billion won from the disaster countermeasure reserve fund as recovery support funds. He instructed all public officials to be fully prepared for emergency duty and prioritized the rescue of isolated individuals and emergency relief for flood victims. After the meeting, he issued Directive No. 7 to strengthen emergency duty nationwide, sending an urgent telecommunication to central administrative agencies, affiliated organizations, and subordinate entities.

On September 11, the Ministry of Education instructed schools in flooded or potentially flooded areas to take measures such as temporary closures. Consequently, the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education announced a temporary closure of all kindergartens, elementary, middle, and high schools in Seoul on September 12. Similarly, Gyeonggi Province temporarily closed all elementary, middle, and high schools in the region, Gangwon Province closed 157 schools mainly in the Yeongseo area, and North Chungcheong Province closed six schools. Additionally, Chung-Ang University and Kyung Hee University's Suwon campus also temporarily closed.

The Ministry of National Defense resolved to deploy helicopters, key military equipment, and personnel to support rescue operations and recovery efforts in affected areas. The Ministry of Health and Social Affairs established the Central Disaster Relief Joint Headquarters on September 11 and organized 280 quarantine teams. On September 12, when the levee at Haengju Dike collapsed, the Ministry of National Defense mobilized 1,500 soldiers, including the 30th Mechanized Infantry Division and the 1175th Engineer Battalion of the Capital Corps, to carry out recovery operations.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries decided to provide 70% of recovery costs for farms with less than 2 hectares of damaged or buried farmland and 20% for farms with more than 2 hectares. They also decided to reduce farmland taxes for affected farmers, defer repayment of farming loans by two years, and reduce the interest on those loans.

The National Assembly of South Korea decided to reconvene the plenary session on September 12 due to the major flood in the Han River, take an eight-day recess until September 20, and postpone the national audit.[48] Kim Young-sam, the leader and senior member of the Democratic Liberal Party, visited the Goyang County area in Gyeonggi Province, which suffered significant damage from the levee collapse, early on September 12. Kim Dae-jung, the president of the Peace Democratic Party, also visited the Central Disaster Countermeasures Headquarters and the Seoul Disaster Countermeasures Headquarters.[49] On September 13, Kim Young-sam visited the landslide site in Songnim-dong, Dong-gu, Incheon, and paid respects at the joint memorial altar. Additionally, Park Tae-joon, a senior member of the Democratic Liberal Party, visited Dunchon Elementary School and Joongdong High School, where residents from Pungnap-dong and Ilwon-dong in Seoul had evacuated. Kim Dae-jung of the Peace Democratic Party visited KBS on the morning of the 13th to deliver flood relief donations and encourage broadcasting officials, and in the afternoon, he visited Ilsan. Lee Ki-taek, the president of the Democratic Party (Little Democratic Party), visited the Gangwon Provincial Office in Chuncheon.[50]

The Gyeonggi Province Disaster Countermeasures Headquarters provided consolation money of 3 million won per person to the families of the deceased or missing and took measures to designate the injured as medical insurance beneficiaries so they could receive treatment.

Article_Name: Aiguats del 20 de setembre de 1971 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: On September 20, 1971, heavy rains occurred in Catalonia. One of the most affected areas was the Llobregat River between the regions of Bages and Baix Llobregat. There were also heavy rains in Alt Empordà. The most intense rainfall was recorded in Figueres with 223 mm and Esparreguera with 308 mm. The Llobregat River overflowed, with an estimated flow of 3,080 m3 per second, which is about 300 times higher than its usual flow of between 9 and 12 m3/s. The most affected municipalities were Castellbell i el Vilar, Esparreguera, Figueres, Martorell, Monistrol de Montserrat, and Olesa de Montserrat. Up to 21 people died as a result, especially in the lower course of the river, and more than 300 companies (with a total of about 40,000 workers) had to halt activity for several weeks. Given the magnitude of the events, on the 50th anniversary of the disaster, municipalities such as Castellbell i el Vilar, Esparreguera, Cornellà de Llobregat, or Olesa de Montserrat organized various commemorative events. In the case of Olesa de Montserrat, a documentary was made to remember that day.

Article_Name: 2021年8月河南暴雨 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The heavy rainstorm in Henan in August 2021 refers to the large-scale, persistent, and intense rainfall process dominated by the Huanghuai cyclone, which occurred from August 21, 2021, in Henan Province of the People's Republic of China and surrounding areas in North China. Since it occurred after the severe disaster of the Henan floods in July 2021, and multiple meteorological agencies and numerical models indicated an extreme trend in this round of rainfall, it received high attention and vigilance from all sectors in Henan. Before the arrival of the heavy rain, the Zhengzhou municipal government preemptively conducted preventive reservoir discharges, and several public transportation services were suspended due to the impact of this event.

According to China Weather Network, starting from the afternoon of August 22, the rainfall intensity in Henan Province of the People's Republic of China significantly increased, and Zhengzhou issued the highest-level red alert for heavy rain. Between 12:00 and 15:00, torrential rain poured in local areas such as Pingdingshan, Jiaozuo, and Zhengzhou. The maximum three-hour rainfall occurred in Ligou Village, Lushan County, Pingdingshan City, at 138.1 mm, while the maximum hourly rainfall intensity was 80.4 mm in the same location. China Weather Network warned that all regions should also be alert to gusts with expected intensities reaching levels 7-9 accompanying the rainfall.

Chen Tao, chief forecaster of the National Meteorological Center, explained that from the system configuration perspective, this heavy rainfall process is a typical monsoon rainfall. The westward extension of the subtropical high allowed warm and moist airflows from the Indian Ocean, South China Sea, and Western Pacific to move smoothly northward along the western edge of the subtropical high, confronting cold air from the north, resulting in a large-scale rainfall process. "Simply put, the northern cold air and the southwestern monsoon airflow clashed, collided, and interacted in the southwestern region and the Huanghuai area, forming a 'temperamental' low vortex and cyclone weather system." Zhang Tao believed that this heavy rain process in Henan was different from the "7.20" event. This rainfall process was mobile and would not replicate the "stagnation" of the July Henan floods, so the cumulative rainfall would not be particularly extreme.

Before the heavy rain occurred, the Central Meteorological Observatory once issued a forecast indicating that an extreme heavy rainstorm with a daily rainfall of 400mm would occur near the urban area of Zhengzhou. According to the Global Times, the Henan Expressway Management Brigade stated in a notice that from the night of August 21 to the 22nd, due to the complex road conditions on the Gongyi section of the Lianhuo Expressway, the northbound lanes from k621 to k632 would be reduced from four lanes to two lanes. At the same time, drivers were reminded to avoid traveling on this section unless necessary, and control measures would be implemented promptly based on weather conditions.

According to CCTV news reports, on the evening of August 21, many citizens in Zhengzhou parked their private cars on elevated bridges to cope with potential extreme heavy rainfall. In response, the Zhengzhou traffic police stated: "The traffic police department will not treat vehicles temporarily parked on roads, elevated bridges, etc., for emergency flood prevention as violations. Citizens are reminded to park their vehicles in a way that does not affect road traffic as much as possible and to move their vehicles to locations that do not obstruct traffic promptly after the heavy rain."  

At noon on August 22, the Zhengzhou City Flood Control Office issued a notice requiring the implementation of traffic control measures, including sealing and prohibiting passage at 67 urban bridge and tunnel crossings and 23 small railway bridge crossings. Article_Name: 2020年长江洪水 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2020 Yangtze River floods refer to a series of floods caused by continuous heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in China from June to August 2020. During this period, there were five floods that reached the intensity level for classification, named Yangtze River Flood No. 1 to Yangtze River Flood No. 5.
The 2020 Yangtze River No. 1 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in June 2020.

The inflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second as of 10:00 on July 2. The Ministry of Water Resources of the People's Republic of China, in accordance with the "Regulations on the Numbering of Major Floods in National Rivers," named this flood as the 2020 Yangtze River No. 1 Flood.

Starting from June 29, 2020, the outflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir was controlled at an average of 35,000 cubic meters per second daily to intercept upstream floods in an attempt to alleviate downstream flooding. [2] In July 2020, heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in China showed no signs of abating. The inflow from the main stream of the upper Yangtze River, Wujiang River, and the Three Gorges area significantly increased compared to June. On July 2, 2020, the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second. On the same day, the Ministry of Water Resources designated this flood as the "First Yangtze River Flood of 2020." The Yangtze River Water Resources Commission also initiated a Level IV emergency response for flood and drought disaster prevention on this day. [3] Xinhua News Agency reported that there would be three heavy rainfall events in the Yangtze River Basin in the coming week, with cumulative rainfall in the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, Qingjiang River, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River's main stream expected to reach 100 to 150 millimeters. Tributaries in the Xiangxi area, the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, the Three Gorges area, Qingjiang River, the middle and lower reaches of the Hanjiang River, the Dongting Lake region, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River's main stream are expected to experience significant water level rises in the coming week. Floods exceeding warning levels may occur in areas near Chenglingji on the Yangtze River's main stream, the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, and some small and medium-sized rivers. [4]

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 2 Flood refers to the flood that occurred under the circumstances of continued increase in water flow in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River main stream and the Three Gorges area, with the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir continuing to rise rapidly. The duration was approximately from July 14, 2020, to July 19, 2020.

At 10:00 on July 17, 2020, the inflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir rose significantly, reaching 50,000 cubic meters per second. According to the flood numbering regulations for major rivers in the People's Republic of China, this inflow met the standard for flood numbering and was designated as the 2020 Yangtze River No. 2 Flood.

Since July 14, 2020, heavy rain or torrential rain has occurred in Sichuan, Chongqing, and other areas. The Three Gorges Reservoir has been retaining floodwaters, and the water level has been continuously rising. At 8:00 PM on July 15, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir was 28,100 cubic meters per second. On July 17 at 10:00 AM, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second, the outflow rate was 32,200 cubic meters per second, and the reservoir water level reached 157.11 meters, exceeding the flood control limit by 12 meters. By 11:00 AM on July 17, the Three Gorges Reservoir had utilized approximately 7 billion cubic meters of flood storage capacity, with about 15 billion cubic meters remaining. At 8:00 AM on July 18, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir peaked at 61,000 cubic meters per second, lasting for about 18 hours. The outflow rate was 33,000 cubic meters per second, with a flood retention rate exceeding 45%. By 8:00 PM on July 19, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir had decreased to 46,000 cubic meters per second, a drop of 15,000 cubic meters per second compared to the peak. According to official reports, the second flood of the Yangtze River in 2020 had successfully passed through the Three Gorges Dam.

At 12:00 on July 19, 2020, the Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission issued a blue flood warning for the Shashi section of the Yangtze River's middle reaches, upgraded to an orange flood warning for the Chuhe River, and continued to issue orange flood warnings for the main stream of the Yangtze River below Chenglingji, the Dongting Lake area, the Poyang Lake area, and the Shuiyang River. A yellow flood warning was issued for the Shigu section of the Jinsha River, urging relevant units and the public to take precautions.

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 3 Flood refers to the flood that occurred under the circumstances of continued increases in water inflow from the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, including the Min River, Jialing River, and the section from Xiangjiaba to Cuntan, as well as the Three Gorges section, and the rapid rise in inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir.

On July 26, 2020, according to the Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources, due to heavy rainfall, the inflow from the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, including the Min River, Jialing River, and the section from Xiangjiaba to Cuntan, as well as the Three Gorges section, significantly increased. The inflow rate into the Three Gorges Reservoir rapidly rose, reaching 50,000 cubic meters per second at 2:00 PM on July 26. According to the "National Major Rivers Flood Numbering Regulations," it met the criteria for flood numbering. This flood was named the "2020 Yangtze River No. 3 Flood." [11]

On July 23, 2020, the Hubei Provincial Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters stated that the third flood of the Yangtze River in 2020 was forming. From 2:00 to 12:00 on July 26, 2020, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir rapidly increased from 36,000 cubic meters per second to 50,000 cubic meters per second. At 14:00 on July 27, 2020, the peak flood flow reached 60,000 cubic meters per second, and the Three Gorges Dam reduced the flood peak by 36.7%.

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 4 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the tributaries of the upper Yangtze River, including the Tuojiang, Fujiang, Minjiang, and the main stream section from Luzhou to Cuntan.

On August 14, 2020, at 5:00, due to heavy rainfall, the tributaries of the upper Yangtze River, Tuojiang and Fujiang, experienced floods exceeding the safety level, while the Minjiang River and the main stream sections from Luzhou to Cuntan experienced floods exceeding the warning level. The flow rate at the Cuntan station on the main stream of the upper Yangtze River rose to 50,900 cubic meters per second, meeting the flood numbering standard according to the "National Major Rivers Flood Numbering Regulations." [14]

At 5:00 on August 14, the Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources officially announced: "The 4th flood of the Yangtze River in 2020" has formed in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River. The peak flow at Cuntan Hydrological Station is expected to be around 58,000 cubic meters per second on the evening of the 14th. The maximum inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir is expected to reach about 59,000 cubic meters per second at 8:00 on the 15th.

The relevant person in charge of the Ministry of Water Resources stated on August 14 that the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources and related provinces (cities) should strengthen monitoring, forecasting, and early warning, ensure flood control scheduling of key reservoirs such as the Three Gorges, and carry out dike inspections and defense work to ensure flood control safety.

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 5 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the tributaries of the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, including the Min River, Tuo River, Jialing River, and Fu River.

At 2:00 PM on August 17, the flow rate at the Cuntan Hydrological Station rose to 20,100 cubic meters per second. According to the "National Major Rivers Flood Numbering Regulations," it reached the standard for flood numbering. The Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources announced the formation of the fifth flood of the Yangtze River in 2020. The maximum inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir is expected to reach about 70,000 cubic meters per second on August 19. On August 20, the fifth flood of the Yangtze River in 2020 passed through the central urban area of Chongqing. At 12:00 PM on the 19th, the inflow rate rose to 72,000 cubic meters per second, setting a new record since the construction of the Three Gorges Reservoir. The previous record was 71,200 cubic meters per second on July 24, 2012. On the 20th, the flood peak is expected to reach 75,000 cubic meters per second.

The Ministry of Water Resources recently intensified consultations and assessments, requiring the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission and relevant provinces (cities) to strengthen monitoring, forecasting, and early warning, ensure flood control scheduling of key reservoirs such as the Three Gorges, and conduct dike inspections and defenses to ensure flood control safety.

At 12:00 PM on the 19th, the inflow rate rose to 72,000 cubic meters per second, setting a new record since the construction of the Three Gorges Reservoir. The previous record was 71,200 cubic meters per second on July 24, 2012. On the 20th, the flood peak is expected to reach 75,000 cubic meters per second.

The Ministry of Water Resources recently intensified consultations and assessments, requiring the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission and relevant provinces (cities) to strengthen monitoring, forecasting, and early warning, ensure flood control scheduling of key reservoirs such as the Three Gorges, and conduct dike inspections and defenses to ensure flood control safety.

Article_Name: Enchentes e deslizamentos no estado de São Paulo em 2022 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Floods and landslides in the state of São Paulo in 2022
Whole_Text.content: The floods and landslides in the state of São Paulo in 2022 consisted of a series of impacts resulting from a meteorological event associated with the occurrence of intense rains that caused high accumulated precipitation values in several municipalities of the state of São Paulo. The rains spread across most of the São Paulo territory, lasting from January 28 to February 2, 2022. The event caused the death of 34 people, in addition to leaving approximately 2,900 families homeless.

A cold front advanced along the coast of the state coming from the Southern Region on January 29, 2022, and, together with the South Atlantic Convergence Zone (SACZ), caused torrential rains in practically the entire state of São Paulo. The high accumulated rainfall caused intense damage in the cities of Franco da Rocha (255 mm), Várzea Paulista (238 mm), Francisco Morato (253 mm), and Embu das Artes (175 mm) within a 72-hour interval. According to meteorological institutions, a phenomenon known as an "atmospheric river" was recorded in satellite images, spanning from the central portion of South America to the far west of the Indian Ocean. This phenomenon is known to occur mainly during the summer months, potentially causing precipitation over a long sequence of days, especially in the southeastern states of Brazil.

The heavy rains caused floods and landslides in various locations across the state, leaving injured and homeless people in several cities. A total of 28 deaths were recorded, among which nine were minors, including eight children and one teenager. Among the most affected municipalities that reported fatalities are Várzea Paulista, Embu das Artes, Jaú, Arujá, Franco da Rocha, Francisco Morato, Ribeirão Preto, and Itapevi.

Whole_Text.header: Government of the state of São Paulo
Whole_Text.content: Governor João Dória flew over the affected areas and promised to allocate 11 million reais in resources to 11 cities affected by the storms. Dória used the press conference to criticize President Jair Bolsonaro's lack of response to the tragedy, although the president had already announced his intention to visit the affected area. Ministers Tarcísio Gomes de Freitas and Rogério Marinho stated in social media posts that they would allocate resources to the state but did not specify amounts.

President Jair Bolsonaro flew over the affected region to observe the damage [13] and made the national civil defense available to the state to assist in post-disaster actions. [14] After the flyover, the president met with representatives from the cities of Caieiras, Cajamar, Franco da Rocha, Mairiporã, Várzea Paulista, and Francisco Morato, all in the metropolitan region of São Paulo, where he expressed regret for the deaths and discussed actions to assist the homeless and rebuild the affected homes. [15]

Article_Name: Hochwasser in West- und Mitteleuropa 2021 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.header: Floods in Western and Central Europe 2021
Whole_Text.content: The flood in Western and Central Europe in 2021, also known as the 2021 flood disaster, was a natural disaster involving severe flash floods and flooding in several river basins in Central Europe during the summer of 2021. Particularly affected were parts of Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Austria, Switzerland, Germany, and other neighboring countries. The most severe flooding was caused by the low-pressure system Bernd. Since early July 2021, warm stormy winds from France and over Piedmont, followed by a cool wind flow from the north with the upper low, reached Central Europe. This resulted in a large, relatively stationary low-pressure system due to a trough weather pattern. A very large amount of rainfall fell on the regions of eastern Belgium, North Rhine-Westphalia, and Rhineland-Palatinate, and later on the Jura-Central Alps area and subsequently in regions of the Eastern Alps and the Balkans. Continuous rain, severe thunderstorms, and heavy hailstorms hit the French regions of Grand Est and Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes, northwestern Switzerland, Ticino, Bavaria, and Saxony, as well as other areas. In many places, rivers, streams, and lakes overflowed, causing very high property damage and numerous fatalities. The water levels of some bodies of water reached similar heights as during the Alpine floods of 2005 and the floods in Switzerland in 2007 or even exceeded them. After about a week, the low-pressure system was over the Eastern Alps, where it slowly dissipated, still causing severe flooding in Bavaria and Austria. The course of the flooding varied in the different affected regions. While the heavy rainfall in some mountainous regions quickly caused rivers to swell enormously, leading to a rapidly rising but short-lived flooding downstream, the water accumulated elsewhere, such as in the Alpine foothill lakes in Switzerland and in flat areas downstream of large rivers like the Meuse, slowly and steadily, reaching peak levels only after days. The flood waves in some valley landscapes subsided after just a few hours, while flooding persisted for weeks in other areas. The flood had particularly devastating effects in the northeast of the Eifel, where towns along the Ahr, the upper part of the Erft, the Nette (Middle Rhine), and Nitzbach, the Rur, and its tributaries Inde, Merzbach, Vichtbach, and Wurm were severely affected. Many houses were undermined, swept away, and damaged by the floods; roads, railways, bridges, and other critical infrastructure were destroyed. Over 220 people died in the flood disaster, including at least 188 in Germany (see the enumeration in the article section on Germany) and 41 in Belgium. Measured by the number of victims, the flood is the deadliest natural disaster in Germany since the storm surge of 1962. In some affected countries, the enormous damage necessitated massive aid and rescue efforts. Munich Re estimated the damage at 46 billion euros, of which 33 billion euros were in Germany alone. This makes it, in terms of damage costs, the second most expensive natural disaster worldwide in 2021, after Hurricane Ida.

While heat and drought prevailed in the years 2018 to 2020 (drought and heat in Europe 2018 and heatwaves in Europe 2019), some affected areas already experienced the first floods at the beginning of 2021. In May and June, a low-pressure weather pattern along the northern edge of the Alps repeatedly led to continuous rain. Several times, especially in the Rhine catchment area, there were severe weather events with strong thunderstorms and large hailstorms. On June 22, a debris flow caused significant damage in the center of the municipality of Cressier in the canton of Neuchâtel. At the beginning of July, there was a risk of flooding in some bodies of water in Switzerland.

The low-pressure system Bernd was the starting point for the severe weather situation over Belgium and Germany between July 12 and 19. Initially, it caused flooding in Great Britain before moving over the Netherlands and Belgium into western Germany. The low-pressure system was enclosed between two high-pressure areas to the west and east. This combination brought warm and moist air from the Mediterranean region to Central Europe, leading to widespread precipitation. The main cause of the locally large amounts of rainfall was the slow movement of the low-pressure system. Warm and moist air masses from the east were brought together with milder air in the west by the low-pressure system. As a result, the warm, more humid air moved over the cooler air. The moisture contained in the warm air layer then precipitated. Due to the subsequent high-pressure system, which shifted from the British Isles to Central Europe, the precipitation moved toward southern Germany and Austria. On July 24, thunderstorms moved from northern to central Belgium, causing further heavy rainfall there.

The occurrence of flooding and the intensity of heavy rainfall can be significantly classified as a consequence of global warming. Although in the affected region of Western Europe, similar precipitation events were expected approximately every 400 years in the past, their probability of occurrence has recently increased significantly. Additionally, similar heavy rainfall events could occur in the future even at lower temperatures than previously observed. Extreme weather events such as heat extremes, droughts, extreme precipitation, and severe tropical storms are increasingly occurring globally due to human-induced global warming. Numerous climate researchers and IPCC authors such as Stefan Rahmstorf, Friederike Otto, Sonia Seneviratne, Reto Knutti, and Ed Hawkins, as well as meteorologists like Özden Terli, Karsten Schwanke, and Andreas Friedrich, therefore cite climate change as a significant contributing and amplifying factor for severe weather events. The hydrologist Bruno Merz added that due to the previously unfamiliar intensification of the water cycle, such events are likely to become more frequent, longer-lasting, and more extreme in the future. The German Weather Service published a report on the weather event, which also provides a climatological assessment. For the occurrence of flooding, it is particularly important that warmer air can hold more water; this eventually precipitates as rain. According to Özden Terli, global warming also temporarily weakens the jet stream, causing weather patterns such as high or low-pressure systems to remain largely stationary in one location for extended periods instead of moving on. This exacerbates their regional impacts, such as heavy rainfall events or the heatwave in late June in North America. According to a study published in 2021 in the journal Geophysical Research Letters, severe weather events with serious consequences are expected to become several times more frequent in Europe with ongoing climate change due to the slow movement and high saturation of low-pressure systems. Hayley Fowler, a climatologist at Newcastle University, stated: "We assume that polar amplification is the reason for the slow movement and prolonged duration of weather systems in summer and autumn." As early as the late 1980s, the first, albeit relatively simple, climate models predicted an increase in heavy precipitation events and a simultaneous decrease in light precipitation events with advancing global warming. According to Stefan Rahmstorf, this development is now also evident in measurement data. Carl-Friedrich Schleussner, research group leader at the Geographical Institute of Humboldt University in Berlin, explained that in 2021, "the question is no longer whether climate change contributed to it." The only question is "how much" it contributed. Such connections are being studied in attribution research. Regarding the question of whether a change in the persistence of individual weather patterns can be observed in the context of climate change, the German Weather Service points out that studies currently do not present a consistent picture and that natural variability will obscure the signal in the coming decades. The same applies to studies linking the reduced temperature gradient between high and mid-latitudes, due to the increased temperature rise in the Arctic, and the persistence of the jet stream. In August 2021, the World Weather Attribution team published an attribution study on the events between July 15 and 17. They also found that there are significant uncertainties regarding the individual event. Therefore, they analyzed to what extent climate change made a similar event in Western Europe more likely and more intense. For the heavy rainfall event in the Ahr and Erft regions as well as in the Belgian Meuse, they determined, assuming the climate remains as it is now, a return period of 400 years. Based on climate simulations, they concluded that the one-day precipitation event increased by 3 to 19% and became 1.2 to 9 times more likely compared to a planet that was 1.2°C cooler and not warmed by humans. Similar findings applied to the two-day precipitation event. They also found that with a 2-degree warming compared to pre-industrial times, a further increase of 0.8 to 6% and a further increase in probability by a factor of 1.2 to 1.4 is to be expected. According to the 2021 annual report of the Copernicus Earth Observation Program, the summer months of 2021 were about one degree Celsius warmer than the average of the years 1991 to 2020.

In the heavily affected Ahr Valley (Ahrweiler district), there were already severe floods in 1601, 1804, and 1910, some with higher flood peaks. In response to the 1910 flood, extensive flood retention basins with a capacity of 11.5 million cubic meters were planned in the 1920s in the upper reaches of the Ahr, at Trierbach, in the Wirftbach Valley, and at Adenauer Bach. Due to a lack of funds, the plans were not implemented, and instead, the Nürburgring was built. The situation was exacerbated in the 1970s when streams were straightened during land consolidation, and drainage channels were created in the vineyards, which directed rainfall vertically down the slopes, causing water levels in the valley to rise rapidly. Additionally, the typical slate rock is almost impermeable to water, causing heavy rain to simply run off. The side streams are also very steep, giving the water high velocity and causing water levels in the valley to rise quickly. According to geographers Thomas Roggenkamp and Jürgen Herget, the flood hazard map for the Ahr Valley is based on measurement data collected since 1947. Although the uncertainties of extreme value statistics with small sample sizes are known, the severe flood events of past centuries were not considered in the hazard assessment. In their view, the July 2021 flood is a recurrence of the July 1804 flood. Despite comparable flow rates (water volumes in cubic meters per second), the July 2021 flood reached higher water levels than the 1804 flood. The reason is that today's denser development of the floodplain reduced the flow area, causing water levels to rise disproportionately in certain areas. Local flood forecasts are under development. In recent years, the federal government and the state of Rhineland-Palatinate have promoted renaturation measures in the Ahr Valley. According to Wolfgang Büchs, these were sensible measures, but flood retention basins and other rainwater retention facilities – also in the side valleys – are the only effective measures against extreme rainfall events. Karsten Schwanke describes how the rainfall in the Eifel caused severe damage: The water was channeled through the low mountain range terrain there, leading to rapidly rising water levels in smaller streams, which in turn contributed to the flooding. The initial situation involved saturated soils due to a very wet spring and the low-pressure system "Bernd," whose cloud masses released over the low mountain ranges in the region, resulting in "intense rainfall of 150 to 200 liters per square meter within 48 hours." At several stations, such as in Rheinbach-Todenfeld or Cologne-Stammheim, more than 150 millimeters/liters per m² of precipitation were measured within 24 hours – between July 14 and 15, 2021, at 8 a.m. each day – with up to 148 millimeters in northern Rhineland-Palatinate, significantly more than the average rainfall for the entire month of July. The 154 millimeters in Stammheim were the highest value ever measured in Cologne within 24 hours and far exceeded the previous record of the last 75 years (95 millimeters). It was also an unusual event in that more than 100 millimeters of rain fell over such a large area – from Sauerland through the Bergisches Land and Cologne to the Eifel – something that had not been observed in previous decades. The Rhine region was most affected by the flood. Never before had there been such large amounts of rainfall here since the beginning of weather records. In Belgium, too, there were several record measurements, ranging from 190 to 270 liters per square meter of precipitation within 48 hours. Other factors that can exacerbate the situation during heavy rainfall include soil sealing, deforestation, dried-out soils, and missing or improperly dimensioned flood protection measures, including in low mountain streams that had previously rarely been considered a risk. The exact water levels in some cases can no longer be determined, as measuring devices stopped reporting data. Either they were not designed for the water levels reached or were destroyed by the water.

In Belgium, the Walloon Region, the French-speaking and German-speaking parts of the country, were primarily affected (including areas along the Meuse River and its tributaries). On July 15, the state infrastructure operator Infrabel announced the suspension of rail traffic throughout the region. There was a risk of flooding across the entire province of Liège as well as parts of the provinces of Luxembourg, Namur, and Walloon Brabant. In Liège, the Royal Meteorological Institute (KMI) measured 271.5 millimeters (271.5 liters per square meter) of rain in the municipality of Jalhay within 48 hours. During the same period, 217.1 millimeters (mm) of rain fell in the municipality of Spa and 192.4 mm in Mont Rigi. Interior Minister Annelies Verlinden activated the EU disaster relief procedure. Neighboring France announced the deployment of aid workers to the province of Liège. In the area of the German-speaking Community, the Our River overflowed its banks and flooded the village of Ouren, part of Burg-Reuland. In Belgium, at least 41 people died in total. As of July 27, 2021, two people were still reported missing. Several houses collapsed, including at least twelve in Pepinster – at the confluence of the Vesdre and Hoëgne rivers. At times, approximately 20,000 people were without electricity, and there was also contamination of drinking water. In Eupen, TNT explosives were washed ashore; an area was evacuated before they were defused. To manage the large amounts of destroyed belongings, the decommissioned Highway 601 was used as a storage site. North of Liège, debris and bulky waste were piled up along a 10-kilometer stretch. Large portions of the waste can also be recycled here. For the Flemish Region, damages were estimated at a total of 90 to 123 million euros. In contrast, the final assessment in January 2023 determined damages in the Walloon Region amounted to 1.993 billion euros. On July 24, severe storms occurred again in the province of Namur. These moved from the north from the province of Antwerp, causing heavy rainfall and flooding, especially in Dinant. Additionally, landslides occurred in the province of Walloon Brabant.

In mid-July 2021, the low-pressure system Bernd caused heavy rainfall in several regions of Germany between July 12 and 19. Within 24 hours, particularly on July 14, 2021, more than 150 mm of rain fell in some areas, including 154 mm in Cologne-Stammheim. The German Weather Service estimated the recurrence interval of such an event to be more than 100 years and possibly 1,000 years. These volumes of rain caused severe flooding. North Rhine-Westphalia and Rhineland-Palatinate were particularly affected. On July 16, 2021, Defense Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer declared a military disaster alert for the two federal states to enhance the Bundeswehr's ability to provide disaster relief. Due to the severe storms, at least 180 people died in the two federal states, including five firefighters on duty. Even after initial assessments, the death toll was significantly higher than during the 2002 "century flood," when 21 people died in Germany. As the floodwaters reached several substations, power supply companies shut off electricity in those areas. 200,000 people in North Rhine-Westphalia and Rhineland-Palatinate were affected by power outages. For more than 100,000 people, this lasted at least until the afternoon of July 16. Mobile networks and drinking water supplies also collapsed in some affected areas. To ensure emergency civilian communication via the internet, Starlink (satellite internet from SpaceX, which was in the testing phase at the time) set up several satellite dishes in the affected regions in coordination with government authorities. The railway infrastructure also suffered severe damage: railway lines in the Eifel region, such as the Cologne–Gerolstein–Trier connection and the Ahr Valley Railway, were particularly affected. Deutsche Bahn initially estimated damages at around 1.3 billion euros. Among other things, 180 level crossings, nearly 40 signal boxes, over 1,000 overhead line and signal masts, and 600 kilometers of tracks were destroyed, as well as power supply systems, elevators, and lighting systems. According to Deutsche Bahn, about 80 percent of the affected technology was expected to be operational again by the end of 2021, but in severely affected regions, restoration could take years. As heating oil tanks and pipelines from oil heating systems were damaged and gasoline and diesel leaked from car wrecks, heating oil and fuels entered water bodies. Chemicals from industrial and commercial areas also entered the environment, threatening water quality locally and in downstream regions. In response, Wasserwerke Westfalen shut down one of its plants. Additionally, large amounts of water contaminated with heating oil accumulated in basements and underground garages, posing a significant disposal problem as it needed to be pumped out and cleaned by specialized companies. Destroyed buildings, homes, and vehicles also generated large amounts of scrap, bulky waste, and other debris. By early November, more than 300,000 tons of bulky waste had been registered in the Ahrweiler district alone, equivalent to the waste volume of 40 normal years. In the weeks following the destruction, public health officials identified a risk of epidemics in the affected areas due to the ongoing decomposition of human and animal corpses as well as sewage leaks. Additionally, the destruction of infrastructure, including hospitals and medical practices, severely threatened basic medical care in the affected areas. The population lacked urgently needed medications. Looting occurred in the affected areas after the natural disaster, prompting police to remain deployed in the devastated regions. On August 28, 2021, six weeks after the flood disaster, a memorial service was held at Aachen Cathedral to honor the victims. The ceremony was attended by Chancellor Angela Merkel, the entire federal leadership, and the heads of government of the two particularly affected federal states, Rhineland-Palatinate (Minister-President Malu Dreyer) and North Rhine-Westphalia (Minister-President Armin Laschet), as well as the leaders of the Bundesrat (Reiner Haseloff), Bundestag (Wolfgang Schäuble), and Federal Constitutional Court (Stephan Harbarth). Following the service, Federal President Frank-Walter Steinmeier delivered a speech in which he, among other things, called for determination in combating climate change. The memorial service was held at the invitation of the Chairman of the Council of the Evangelical Church in Germany (EKD), Regional Bishop Heinrich Bedford-Strohm, the Chairman of the Catholic German Bishops' Conference, Georg Bätzing, and the Chairman of the Working Group of Christian Churches in Germany, Archpriest Radu Constantin Miron. Representatives of the Jewish and Muslim faiths, as well as other Christian leaders, also participated, while Cardinal Jean-Claude Hollerich traveled from Luxembourg.

In addition to at least 141 deaths, 766 injuries were recorded in Rhineland-Palatinate. By early September 2021, all the deceased had been clearly identified, but there were still three missing persons, which did not change by the end of the month. Furthermore, it was determined that eight recovered victims had died before the flood, reducing the number of people actually killed by the flood in Rhineland-Palatinate to 133. In October 2021, the death of another person, who had been missing after the flood, was confirmed. This brought the number of people killed by the flood in Rhineland-Palatinate to 134. An initial larger assessment of property damage, conducted ten days after the flood in Rhineland-Palatinate, estimated that at least 17,000 people had directly lost property due to the flood. Of the more than 3,000 damaged buildings, at least 467 were destroyed, including nearly 200 residential houses. Several kilometers of roads were completely destroyed, and over 73.9 kilometers of roads, paths, and bridges along the Ahr were damaged. A carriageway of the under-construction Ahr crossing of Federal Highway 9 near Sinzig had subsided due to an undermined pillar and was therefore demolished. On the Ahr Valley Railway, at least seven railway bridges and around 20 kilometers of track were destroyed by overflows and undercutting. The 1,600 businesses registered with the Chamber of Crafts and the Chamber of Industry and Commerce in the Ahr Valley suffered estimated property damage totaling 560 million euros. The Ahrweiler district was particularly hard hit, where the Ahr flood left a trail of destruction. In the local municipality of Schuld, six houses collapsed, and numerous others were severely damaged. In the district, 62 bridges were destroyed, and another 13 were severely damaged; 19 daycare centers and 14 schools also suffered damage. More than 330 people were rescued from rooftops and trees with up to 36 helicopters. Of the 112 bridges in the affected area, only 35 were fully usable as of August 20, 2021—more than a month later. In the city of Sinzig, twelve residents of the "Lebenshilfe-Haus" facility for people with disabilities died. The floods came faster than the people could be brought to safety. Weather experts argue, however, that the disaster had been foreseeable long before the actual event. Days before the floods, the European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) warned that so-called flash floods could occur in the affected areas. According to the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action, model calculations show that the flood was made 1.2 to 9 times more likely by climate change. In the districts of Bitburg-Prüm, Vulkaneifel, and Trier-Saarburg, a state of emergency was declared. The local municipality of Kordel was particularly affected. Here, the Kyll River reached a record water level of 7.85 meters. On the evening of July 14, 2021, the Prüm River in Prüm reached 3.27 meters, the Lieser River in Wittlich reached 3.63 meters, and the Nims River in Alsdorf and Bitburg-Stahl reached record levels of 3.49 meters the following morning. At the Irrel Waterfalls, the covered pedestrian bridge and part of the slope were washed away and destroyed by the flood, as was the camping site in Oberweis. The flood in Rhineland-Palatinate also unearthed about 350 kilograms of unexploded ordnance and a non-detonable bomb from World War II. At the beginning of 2022, the state authority for supervision and services estimated the total damage caused by the flood in Rhineland-Palatinate at 15 billion euros.

Many volunteers came especially to the Ahr Valley to provide assistance. On the second weekend after the disaster, the local road network was so overloaded as a result that professional helpers, the military, and garbage trucks could no longer pass. Consequently, the situation center temporarily called on the helpers to leave. Meanwhile, private initiatives emerged that contributed little to the traffic congestion. Two entrepreneurs from the Ahr Valley organized a so-called helper shuttle (shuttle service), through which thousands of volunteers were systematically brought to the affected areas by bus from the Rheinland Grafschaft Innovation Park. Since September 27, 2021, private households have been able to submit funding applications for reconstruction. Applications were accepted until June 30, 2023. Of the special fund "Reconstruction Aid 2021," originally equipped with 30 billion euros from federal funds, about 3.3 billion euros had been used by the end of 2023. In early October 2021, the North Structure and Approval Directorate published revised flood hazard maps for the Ahr. According to these, all houses—except for 34 in so-called "hazard areas"—may be (partially) rebuilt under certain conditions. For buildings in designated flood zones that can be renovated, a flood-adapted construction method is only recommended. Prime Minister Malu Dreyer stated that the vast majority of homeowners received "the certainty that they can renovate on-site." The state government (Dreyer III Cabinet) thereby ignores numerous urgent recommendations from scientists. Opposition to stricter restrictions on reconstruction came from mayors in the Ahr Valley, who see wine tourism at risk. This already leads to above-average land sealing in the towns. The civil society alliance Aus Ahrtal wird SolAHRtal, together with representatives from local politics, science, and business, demands reconstruction as a model region for complete supply through renewable energies. The conservation organizations BUND and NABU criticize that side arms and gravel banks created by the Ahr were removed and a trapezoidal riverbed was restored, which is detrimental to both species and flood protection. Anja Käfer-Rohrbach, CEO of the German Insurance Association (GDV), described the near-original reconstruction of the settlement structure in the Ahr Valley in 2024 as a "disaster on repeat."

The district administrator of the Ahrweiler district, Jürgen Pföhler, was accused of not adequately preparing measures for a disaster situation, declaring the alarm far too late, and only ordering a partial evacuation. Pföhler denied responsibility for possible failures in warning the population in the Ahr Valley. He stated that the technical operations management was responsible for alerting the population. He told the Bonner General-Anzeiger that mutual accusations were "completely misplaced and tasteless." On August 2, 2021, the Koblenz public prosecutor's office announced that it was examining the initiation of an investigation against Jürgen Pföhler following the flood disaster in the Ahr Valley. There was an initial suspicion of negligent homicide and negligent bodily harm due to possibly omitted or delayed warnings or evacuations. On August 6, 2021, the public prosecutor's office launched investigations against him and another person to whom the district administrator had delegated operational management. Since August 11, Pföhler has not been performing his duties due to illness. On August 17, 2021, the CDU district council faction announced that it had become apparent that there had been omissions and mistakes in the past and on the day of the disaster; a personnel fresh start was necessary. At the end of October 2021, Pföhler was retired after applying for permanent incapacity for service. In April 2024, the Koblenz public prosecutor's office announced that no charges would be brought against Pföhler. The final report of the "Flood Disaster" investigation committee, comprising more than 2,100 pages, was published on August 2, 2024.

In North Rhine-Westphalia, almost all tributaries of the Rhine and many of their tributaries and streams overflowed their banks. Some reported historic high levels and caused damage on an unprecedented scale. Therefore, small streams are also to be included in a warning system in the future. The Rhine itself was only marginally affected by the flooding due to its comparatively large discharge capacity.  

By July 16, 25 cities and districts in North Rhine-Westphalia were particularly affected by the flooding. By that day, according to the Interior Minister of North Rhine-Westphalia, Herbert Reul, 19,000 emergency personnel from aid organizations had handled 30,000 flood-related operations, and the North Rhine-Westphalia police had handled another 3,200 operations. In the Bergisches Land region, the flooding caused days-long power outages and large-scale evacuations (such as in Hückeswagen and Leichlingen). The drastic consequences of the weather disaster in western Germany were also strongly felt in Euskirchen, Rheinbach, Swisttal, Stolberg, Eschweiler, and Erftstadt. Due to the flooding and the endangered Steinbach dam, several thousand residents in several localities had to leave their homes.  

The overflowing Erft and Swist rivers flooded large parts of the Erftstadt city area, and several localities were partially or completely evacuated. Major roads such as the federal highways 1 (Eifelautobahn) and 61, as well as federal road 265, were closed due to flooding and road damage. In the Erftstadt district of Blessem, the water from the Erft flowed through a residential and commercial area and carved a new path into the gravel pit of the Blessem quarry; several houses near Blessem Castle were undermined and damaged in the process. However, no fatalities were reported in the Rhein-Erft district.  

The Cologne public prosecutor's office is investigating the owner of the open-pit mine, the operating company from Bergheim, as well as the responsible supervisory authority in Arnsberg, "on suspicion of negligent causing of a flood by omission, endangering construction, and violation of the Federal Mining Act." It is suspected that a flood protection wall was missing in the old area of the pit and that the slopes were excessively steep. According to Westdeutscher Rundfunk, warnings had been ignored since 2011.  

The St. Antonius Hospital in Eschweiler was completely evacuated on July 15; over 300 patients were transferred to other hospitals. On July 17, the Euskirchen correctional facility was largely evacuated. Looters were arrested in the neighboring cities of Eschweiler and Stolberg. In affected towns such as Bad Münstereifel, there were fatalities, and numerous historic houses were destroyed or damaged.  

As the Inde river overflowed, the Inden open-pit mine was partially flooded; one person was reported missing as a result and was eventually found dead on July 22 and identified a week later. The town of Inden was also largely flooded. Damage occurred not only to major roads but also to many railway lines: at times, train traffic in the southern half of North Rhine-Westphalia was barely possible. Long-distance trains from the north terminated in Münster, among other places, and several regional train lines were canceled. Particularly affected were the main train stations in Hagen and Wuppertal, as well as the railway lines running through them (including the Hagen–Dieringhausen railway, the Ruhr-Sieg railway, and the Elberfeld–Dortmund railway).  

On July 14, the Eicherscheid flood retention basin in the Eifel and other retention basins near Horchheim, Weilerswist, and Kerpen-Mödrath were opened to reduce the flow into the Erft. The Rheinische Post reported a dam breach on the Rur river in Wassenberg-Ophoven on July 16, 2021. On July 20, a settlement in Bergisches Leichlingen was evacuated due to a potential dam breach.  

Additionally, on July 14, a small tornado formed in Castrop-Rauxel, causing several property damages. After all cases were clarified, the search for missing persons was concluded on July 28, 2021. By that time, 47 people had died in North Rhine-Westphalia due to the flood. In August 2021, two more people died in hospitals from injuries sustained.  

Starting September 17, 2021, private households and housing industry companies could apply for reconstruction funding. Applications were accepted until June 30, 2023.

In Baden-Württemberg, there were widespread floods due to heavy rain. In Tübingen and Reutlingen, there were multiple severe hail damages and floods in June, with the COVID-19 vaccination center in Tübingen being flooded. The Rhine also overflowed its banks. In Karlsbad and Remchingen, there were repeated floods, including the federal motorway 8 being flooded by about one meter. On the evening of Friday, July 9, several roads in Distelhausen in the Tauber Valley, such as the access road to Lauda, were under water, with the flood level in Tauberbischofsheim already showing 3.17 meters by the following Saturday. On July 13, there were further operations due to local heavy rain, for example in Eppingen and Heilbronn. Additionally, Rhine shipping between Iffezheim and Germersheim was suspended on the night of Wednesday. This closure was extended to Mannheim a day later. Due to the rainfall, the federal motorway 6 between Viernheimer Dreieck and Mannheim-Sandhofen was undermined and closed on July 14 due to the damage. On the early evening of July 15, 2021, there was repeated local heavy rain. The southern part of Heilbronn and the municipality of Flein were partially flooded. In Bretten-Ruit, the rain, but not the Salzach, caused the flooding of the town. In Inzlingen, a 17-year-old was rescued after being sucked into an open manhole by the floodwaters. In the Radolfzell area on Lake Constance, several towns experienced a power outage lasting several hours on the following Friday morning due to a landslide. A person in the Heilbronn district was found dead after falling into the Jagst River. Additionally, on the evening of July 16, 2021, the Danube railway between Ehingen and Munderkingen was suspended after the tracks were undermined and flooded. At the same time, the Götzenbach in Lorch in the Ostalb district flooded several houses. On the morning of July 17, 2021, the water level at the Maxau gauge of the Upper Rhine in Karlsruhe had already risen to 8.62 meters, which also led to the flooding of retention areas in Kehl and Altenheim in the Ortenau district. Part of the route during the reactivation celebration of the Biberbahn between Stockach and Mengen was also closed on the same day because the railway embankment was damaged.

In several cities and districts in northern Bavaria, especially in the Hofer Land, a state of emergency was declared on July 10, 2021. In Wilhermsdorf, a power outage occurred after a transformer station was flooded. The railway line from Neustadt an der Aisch to Bad Windsheim was closed due to track flooding. Numerous roads were underwater. In Altmannshausen (Markt Bibart), a listed bridge was partially torn away and was therefore impassable. From July 14, drinking water in parts of the districts of Ansbach, Roth, and Weißenburg-Gunzenhausen was contaminated with fecal bacteria after heavy rainfall and was therefore boiled. Reichenberg near Würzburg was even flooded twice within seven days, on July 9 and July 15. In Ansbach, the Rezat rose to a level of 4.29 meters. Additionally, this disaster coincided with the discovery of a bomb at Ansbach station, which further challenged emergency services. After the low-pressure system Bernd moved south, places in the Berchtesgadener Land region were flooded on the evening of July 17 following heavy rainfall, prompting the district to declare a state of emergency. The Berchtesgadener Ache rose to 3.50 meters, surpassing the previous high of 3.12 meters in 2012. As a landslide was feared in Schönau am Königssee, evacuations took place there and in other locations. The Bischofswiesen station was flooded, the Königssee artificial ice track was severely damaged, and several roads were temporarily closed due to flooding. The Partnach Gorge in Garmisch-Partenkirchen was also severely damaged.

In northern Hesse, there were primarily floods of buildings and traffic disruptions. On state road 3215 between Naumburg and Waldeck, a slope below the road was washed away on July 14, 2021, causing the damaged road to be closed. On the Rhine, in the southwest of the state, federal road 42 between Assmannshausen and Lorch was closed after cracks caused by the floodwaters were discovered, as it was feared that the road might be washed away.

In Saarland, too, bodies of water overflowed their banks on the night of July 15, with only 13 incidents of street flooding and flooded basements reported by Thursday morning, according to the police operations center in Saarbrücken, compared to other federal states.

On July 13, 2021, there were severe floods in the Vogtland, particularly in Plauen and Oelsnitz. In Steinbach (Jöhstadt) in the Erzgebirgskreis, a man died after being swept away by a flash flood; in Freiberg, there were road subsidence and a landslide. On July 17, there were severe floods in the Saxon Switzerland region; the towns of Krippen and Bad Schandau were especially affected. The historic Kirnitzschtalbahn was partially flooded. International rail traffic between Dresden and Prague was also interrupted due to mudslides.

As early as the beginning of June, a local heavy rain event had caused severe flooding in the town of Mosbach near Eisenach in the Wartburg district, resulting in significant property damage. On July 13, the Ilm district, the Saale-Orla district, and the Saalfeld-Rudolstadt district were particularly affected by severe storms and flooded basements. Landslides blocked several roads, and train services were locally suspended due to storm damage. The Federal Motorway 71 was temporarily closed due to flooding.

In eastern France, during the flood event, the flood danger level "Orange" was initially declared in the twelve departments of Nord, Aisne, Ardennes, Marne, Meuse, Meurthe-et-Moselle, Moselle, Bas-Rhin, Haut-Rhin, Doubs, Jura, and Ain.
