As events unfolded, a warning level was in effect in additional departments. In the Moselle region, the area from Metz and Thionville to the Luxembourg border was heavily affected. The flood particularly impacted the municipalities of Fixem, Beyren-lès-Sierck, Puttelange-lès-Thionville, and Longuyon. Some localities were evacuated due to the flooding, and there were numerous road closures. The railway line from Thionville to Luxembourg was disrupted. In Bar-le-Duc, the Ornain River and the Canal de la Marne au Rhin overflowed. In the Upper Rhine, the Erstein polder, a flood retention basin south of Strasbourg, was flooded to reduce the significantly increased flow of the Rhine following intense rainfall in Switzerland. Heavy rainfall occurred over the Jura and Doubs departments as well as in southern Alsace. In the Jura department, part of the locality of Bletterans was flooded. Additionally, due to the flooding of the Orain, a tributary of the Doubs, the locality of Chaussain had to be evacuated, as well as the campsite near Parcey due to the flooding of the Loue. Departmental road 332 was disrupted. In Montmorot, there were only minor floods because the flood retention basins were able to significantly mitigate the flood. In Besançon, the Doubs overflowed its banks. On July 17, 2021, the Seille in the Saône-et-Loire department overflowed its banks and flooded the town center of Louhans-Châteaurenaud. At the confluence of the Saône and the Rhône, both of which were experiencing high water levels, some riverside streets in the major city of Lyon were underwater. In the Alpine departments of Isère and Haute-Savoie, several roads were disrupted due to the storm. The Arve, originating from the Savoy Prealps and flowing into the Rhône in Geneva, Switzerland, was in flood.

First, storms associated with the low-pressure system Bernd hit parts of Great Britain. After heavy rainfall, London's streets were turned into raging streams on July 12, 2021. Basements, cars, toilets, and shops were flooded. Further flooding occurred on July 25 when storms, following very warm weather caused by a low-pressure system in northern France, led to slow-moving storms. This resulted in significant disruptions to the transportation infrastructure.

On July 13, storms occurred in eastern Northern Italy, causing damage to agricultural crops. In the autonomous region of Trentino-South Tyrol, a fallen tree damaged a cable car, several roads were disrupted, and in the Veneto region, one person lost their life.

In Croatia, the region of Western Slavonia struggled with flooded houses due to heavy rainfall of around 170 liters per square meter during the night of July 16 to 17. Among other places, the town of Nova Gradiška was affected. The following afternoon, a storm swept through the region around Osijek, tearing off the roof of a building, uprooting trees, and flooding streets. On July 19, heavy rainfall occurred again, flooding farmland near Našice as well as basements and streets in Osijek. In the vicinity of Šipvac, power outages were reported. The following night, numerous streets in the city of Županja were flooded during a severe storm, with up to 183 liters per square meter falling at times.

In the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, heavy rain caused by the low-pressure system Bernd moving south on July 14 and 15 caused numerous rivers to overflow and flood adjacent towns. This affected, among others, Hesperange, Mamer, Vianden, and Bettembourg. Parts of the city of Echternach had to be evacuated on July 15, as did residents of several other locations (Vianden, Rosport, Steinheim, Born, Bour). Near Bollendorf, the water level of the Sauer River reached 608 centimeters, the second-highest value since records began. According to MeteoLux, an average of 60 to 80 liters per square meter had fallen in the country in the previous 24 hours. Severe damage occurred in the lower city of the capital due to the Alzette River. A power outage at the pumps of a pipeline in Germany temporarily interrupted the kerosene supply to the airport. Additionally, on July 16, the municipalities of Beaufort, Bissen, and Lintgen were contaminated with undrinkable tap water. On July 17, the N10 had to be closed due to flooding in Schengen. Train traffic from Metz in France to Luxembourg was severely disrupted and completely halted from Thionville. The reason was the flooding of the train tunnel near Hagondange. The French National Railway Company (SNCF) assumed that no trains would run before Monday, July 19, 2021. Many railway lines and roads in Luxembourg were also closed due to landslides and flooding. Over the course of the afternoon of July 15, 2021, water levels slowly began to recede in many places. Luxembourg's Prime Minister Xavier Bettel announced aid amounting to 50 million euros.

The southern part of the Dutch province of Limburg was particularly affected. In the Heuvelland region, heavy rain on July 13 and 14 caused streams and small rivers to overflow their banks. According to the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI), 86 to 98 liters of rain per square meter fell in some areas within 24 hours. The resulting floods caused severe damage. Due to the masses of water, parts of the A2, A79, and A76 highways were closed. On July 15, parts of the city of Roermond, the provincial capital Maastricht, the Maas municipalities of Stein and Eijsden-Margraten, and the small town of Valkenburg were evacuated. In mid-July, the Maas River reached its highest water level in some places since measurements began in 1911. Near Maastricht, a canal dike broke; in Venlo and the surrounding municipalities, more than 10,000 people were evacuated on the evening of July 16. A hospital was also evacuated there as a precaution, while some of those evacuated the previous day were able to return home.

After the low-pressure area Bernd shifted eastward, the town of Hallein near Berchtesgaden was flooded on the evening of July 17. Residents had to be evacuated. The city of Salzburg was also hit by heavy rain and flooding. In Vienna, basements and underpasses were flooded. In Kufstein (Tyrol), part of the city was also underwater, and a mudslide occurred north of Seefeld in Tyrol, leading to the closure of federal road 177. Along the Salzach River and its tributary valleys, there were mudslides and subsequent flooding, which required the evacuation of entire settlements and villages. Railway lines had to be closed as tracks were submerged. In Kuchl (Salzburg region), drinking water was contaminated on July 18. In many places, after continuous rain of up to 170 millimeters, the flooding was considered the worst in decades. On July 18, there were also numerous firefighting operations, with around 600 incidents in Lower Austria alone at the peak. After the collapse of a bridge, Ferschnitz was temporarily inaccessible. In Neuhofen an der Ybbs, the cemetery was flooded, and in Ernsthofen, the Ennstal railway line of the Austrian Federal Railways (ÖBB) had to be closed after a rockfall.

Romania was also affected by severe weather. On July 17, the Alba County in the Apuseni Mountains, including the municipality of Roșia Montană in the west of the country, was hit by heavy rain, landslides, and floods. Additionally, numerous people had to be evacuated in four municipalities. However, no fatalities were reported. The following day, Romanian Prime Minister Florin Cîțu visited the affected area and promised swift assistance. On the evening of July 19, the region around Cluj-Napoca was struck by a severe hailstorm, which uprooted trees and caused power outages in several houses. In the city of Craiova, in the southwest of the country, the roof of a residential block was torn off. The following night, numerous counties were again affected by heavy rain, leaving many households in the Mureș and Neamț counties without electricity. Nationwide, several people were rescued from vehicles and evacuated from flooded houses. The next morning, National Road DN1 in Bușteni was blocked by a landslide. According to a video conference held by Interior Minister Lucian Bode on July 20, around 80 locations in 20 counties were affected by the heavy rain in recent days, with two fatalities reported in Satu Mare and Iași.

A cold front and subsequently the moist winds directed by the upper-level low "Bernd" over Belgium and western Germany reached Switzerland and the central Alpine region via eastern France. Frequent precipitation in May and June 2021 had caused many soils to become saturated when the severe storm occurred, leaving them unable to absorb much more water. In the high Alps, snowmelt was still ongoing until mid-July, which had already caused some rivers to have elevated water levels. After heavy, prolonged rainfall in the Alps, the Jura, and the Swiss Plateau, numerous streams, rivers, and lakes overflowed their banks in several cantons starting on July 11, 2021, and landslides and debris flows occurred in some areas. Various towns were flooded, and some transportation routes were disrupted. On July 14, authorities declared the highest danger level for several bodies of water, especially the large pre-Alpine lakes. Strong storm gusts caused significant property damage, including in the city of Zurich, and disruptions to the transportation network from July 12 to 13. Flooding and local inundations particularly affected the river systems of the Aare, Reuss, Limmat, and Rhone, as well as the Ticino south of the main Alpine ridge. A significant amount of water flowed from the Swiss Jura into France via the Doubs and into the Rhone via the Saône. The Reuss overflowed its banks in the cantons of Uri and Aargau on July 13. In Brugg and Gebenstorf, where the Reuss and Limmat flow into the Aare, the Schachenland and Stroppelinsel areas were underwater. On July 16, 2021, the Aare also flooded in Bern. In some municipalities, riverside roads and bridges were closed. The canton of Uri preemptively closed the A2 motorway near Altdorf, which runs alongside the Reuss. In Hünenberg, the Reuss dam was monitored due to the risk of rupture. Transportation routes to Engelberg were interrupted due to debris flows. A landslide disrupted the Wengernalp Railway route between Lauterbrunnen and Wengen in the Bernese Oberland on July 18. In the canton of Ticino, the main road between Bellinzona and Airolo was closed on July 14 due to a rockfall triggered by the storm. In Lucerne, Thun, Bern, Bremgarten, Mellingen, Windisch, Wallbach, and other towns along the Reuss, Aare, and Rhine, municipalities deployed mobile flood protection elements and barriers, which had been prepared as a precaution since the last major flood events. This prevented widespread flooding in some areas. However, damage occurred in many places due to rising groundwater. In Brunnen, Stansstad, and Küssnacht, parts of town centers were flooded. The water level of Lake Lucerne reached its peak of 434.94 meters above sea level on the night of July 16 to 17, 2021, and began to slightly recede in the following days. At the Badbrücke in Wolhusen, two cars were swept into the Kleine Emme on July 25, 2021. The outflow of water from the Alps and the Swiss Plateau caused the Rhine's water flow to increase significantly below the Aare's confluence near Koblenz AG. The Birs, flowing out of the Jura, flooded areas near Basel and further intensified the Rhine flooding. Due to the Rhine flooding, the city of Basel had to close its riverfront promenades, and Rhine shipping below Birsfelden and on the Upper Rhine was suspended on July 13. This led to delivery failures at Basel's Rhine ports and delays in freight transport. Shipping was also halted on Lake Lucerne, Lake Thun, and Lake Biel. Lake Biel rose above the damage threshold after several days due to inflows from the Aare, Zihl, and Schüss, as well as the Jura water regulation at the Port regulating weir, and overflowed its banks at Nidau and Biel/Bienne. The lake reached an unprecedented high level. Consequently, water from Lake Biel began to flow backward into Lake Neuchâtel through the Zihl Canal in the west, as planned under the second Jura water correction concept, even though Lake Neuchâtel had not yet experienced flooding. With the inflow from Lake Biel, the water level in Lake Neuchâtel also rose, eventually flooding the lakeshore area in Yverdon-les-Bains, including various sports facilities and a campsite. The water level in Lake Biel also reached its highest point of 430.94 meters above sea level on the night of July 16 to 17 and quickly dropped by about 30 centimeters the following day due to outflows through the Nidau-Büren Canal and the Zihl Canal. When Lake Biel and Lake Neuchâtel reached the same water level, the flooding remained stable for an extended period, and the inundated lakeshore areas remained underwater. Lake Neuchâtel reached its record-high water level of 430.72 meters above sea level on July 19, 2021, nearly a week after the heavy rain began in Switzerland. From Lake Neuchâtel, the floodwaters continued to flow into Lake Murten, where several sections of the lakeshore and the Salavaux campsite were flooded. As of July 19, the highest warning level and a ban on water sports were still in effect for Lake Biel. By July 24, the lake level had dropped to 430.34 meters above sea level thanks to the outflow into the Aare, remaining within the upper range of danger level 3. Many building basements around the lake were still underwater due to the significantly elevated groundwater level and could not yet be pumped out by the fire department. The lake police and the Office for Water and Waste removed large amounts of driftwood from the lake. To reduce the lake flooding, the Port regulating weir continued to allow a higher outflow into the Aare under a special agreement between the affected cantons and the federal government, exceeding the limits set by the inter-cantonal regulation. It was not until July 29, 2021, that the water level at Ligerz on Lake Biel, and on August 2 for Lake Neuchâtel and Lake Murten, dropped below danger level 2. In the Schaffhausen municipalities of Schleitheim and Beggingen in the Randental valley, the Schleitheimer Bach, which flows through both towns, overflowed its banks on July 15 due to heavy rain, causing significant damage. In the Rhone catchment area, the first severe storm damage occurred in Upper Valais. Debris flows affected the village of Oberwald in Goms, burying roads and part of the settlement. The Matterhorn-Gotthard Railway route and the pass roads over the Grimsel, Furka, and Nufenen passes were temporarily closed. In Lower Valais, local flooding occurred due to the Rhone flooding. The cantonal road between Lausanne and Vevey on Lake Geneva was interrupted by a landslide. Lake Geneva experienced flooding, which was exacerbated when the outflow at the Seujet dam was temporarily reduced to protect downstream areas from flooding. Below the Rhone's outflow from the lake in Geneva, the floods of the Rhone and its tributary, the Arve from Savoy, caused flooding in the Jonction district of the city.

Due to the heavy rainfall in Germany and Austria, as well as storms on July 18 in the country itself, water levels of the Danube and Morava rivers also rose in Slovakia. On the morning of July 19, the Danube in the capital Bratislava had a water level of 7.03 meters, and the Morava in Devínska Nová Ves had a level of about 5.28 meters. The southern districts of the capital and an underpass near the University of Economics in Bratislava were particularly affected by flooding.

The Czech Republic was hit by heavy rainfall on the evening of July 18, predominantly in North Bohemia. Residents of the Liberec and Ústí nad Labem regions were promised financial support from the state through emergency aid of up to 57,900 crowns. Particularly affected were the municipalities of Dolní Poustevna and Lobendava, located directly on the border with Saxony. Numerous residents in the municipalities near Česká Lípa had to be evacuated. In the southwest of Bohemia, flood warning level 3 was issued due to the Otava River.

In Hungary, heavy rain also caused flooding in several locations nationwide, including Győr, Mohács, and Kecskemét. In several districts of the capital Budapest, up to 100 millimeters of rain fell in some places within a few hours. The third warning level was declared on the Danube near Nagybajcs.

After Belgium requested assistance, the EU Civil Protection Mechanism was activated on July 14, 2021, leading to the deployment of a helicopter and a flood rescue team from France to Belgium. Additionally, Austria and Italy also offered flood rescue teams. On July 15 and 16, 2021, 120 firefighters from Lower Austria, with 16 vehicles and 26 rescue boats, were deployed in Belgium, particularly assisting in Theux with the inspection of flooded houses, until Belgium declared the international operation concluded. In Liège, 40 personnel from the French military were deployed. The EU's Copernicus Emergency Management Service provided detailed satellite maps with situational images and forecasts for emergency responders in all affected areas of Central Europe. The service delivered timely, precise, and spatially-referenced digital maps to delineate affected areas and plan relief efforts. In Germany, the data was sent to the Joint Reporting and Situation Center of the Federal and State Governments (GMLZ). Through the NINA warning app ("Emergency Information and News App") provided by the Federal Office of Civil Protection and Disaster Assistance (BBK), various warnings were sent to the population by districts and independent cities. On the night of the flood, only a few mobile phones were turned on in the Ahr Valley, and the mobile network quickly failed. Alarm ringing with bells and the use of alarm sirens were not pre-planned and did not occur. The SWR did not alert listeners. The city of Wuppertal independently activated its sirens, warned with loudspeaker vehicles, and arranged a special broadcast on the local radio station Radio Wuppertal. In addition to local fire departments, many fire departments from neighboring districts supported the affected areas. The Technical Relief Agency (THW) was alerted and, as of July 16, 2021, had nearly 2,100 personnel from about 165 local units deployed in North Rhine-Westphalia and Rhineland-Palatinate. THW units from all eight THW regional associations were mobilized. A week and a half after the disaster, about 4,000 THW personnel from across Germany were deployed in the flood-affected areas. In total, more than 14,000 emergency personnel with over 2,000,000 hours of operation were involved. Units of disaster relief from Bavaria, Hesse, Lower Saxony, and Hamburg were also deployed in the flood areas. On July 14, 2021, the first requests for administrative assistance were received by the Bundeswehr's Territorial Tasks Command. Up to 900 soldiers were deployed in Rhineland-Palatinate and North Rhine-Westphalia. The units also provided support with recovery tanks, transport tanks, bridge-laying tanks, trucks, boats, ambulances, and helicopters. Many farmers, contractors, and thousands of volunteers from all federal states helped with tractors, excavators, wheel loaders, and other equipment in the affected areas. They worked complementarily and independently of the rescue forces, removing debris from the areas. Even months after the flood, hundreds of people (thousands on some weekends) traveled daily to the affected areas to help. Various emergency responders from the so-called "Blue Light Family" were subsequently awarded the 2021 Flood Relief Medal.
The President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, promised aid to the affected member states, namely Belgium, Germany, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands.

In Belgium, Prime Minister Alexander De Croo declared a national day of mourning for July 20, 2021 (one day before Belgium's National Day) on July 16, 2021. He said these were probably the "most catastrophic floods" Belgium had ever experienced. A minute of silence was observed from 12:01 to 12:02 PM.

The Minister President of North Rhine-Westphalia, Armin Laschet (CDU), Vice Chancellor Olaf Scholz (SPD), and the Minister President of Rhineland-Palatinate, Malu Dreyer (SPD), personally assessed the situation in the disaster areas. Federal Chancellor Angela Merkel (CDU), who was on a state visit to Washington, D.C. at the time, thanked the many helpers for their efforts and expressed her sympathy to the relatives of the deceased and missing. After her return from the United States, she visited the Ahr Valley and the local community of Schuld accompanied by Malu Dreyer. There, she stated that the federal government would investigate the course of the flood disaster and provide financial aid for the affected regions; furthermore, politics must take greater account of nature and climate in the future. Bavaria's Minister President Markus Söder (CSU) also promised aid for the affected states. The Deputy Minister President of Rhineland-Palatinate, Anne Spiegel (Greens), traveled to the flood events in Trier and Kordel. The example of Trier-Ehrang, Spiegel said, showed that the flood protection measures of the state and municipalities were insufficient. Chancellor candidate Annalena Baerbock (Greens) traveled to the affected areas on July 16. However, she refrained from being accompanied by press representatives to avoid the impression that she was campaigning. The situation there was too serious for that, party circles said. The so-called "Laschet laugh" on July 17, 2021, during the speech of Federal President Frank-Walter Steinmeier in the flood area in North Rhine-Westphalia significantly influenced the campaign for the 2021 federal election. Subsequently, the CDU/CSU's poll numbers plummeted. The AfD's climate policy spokesperson, Karsten Hilse, described the heavy rainfall that led to the floods as a "natural phenomenon." Human-made emissions played no role in it. There had always been "devastating disasters" in historical times, and he condemned other parties for exploiting people's suffering to pursue their own political goals. The German Association of Towns and Municipalities called for quick aid from the federal and state governments on July 16, 2021. Shortened planning procedures for climate and disaster protection projects were also necessary. The German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation (BUND) called for a consistent expansion of ecological flood protection in light of the disaster to prevent such magnitudes in the future. Floodplains must be consistently designated for this purpose and must not be built on, used for agriculture, or sealed by road construction. Intact river meadows should be protected from human intervention to function as natural retention areas in the event of flooding. For effective protection, extensive renaturation would be necessary, including both flowing waters and moors. For these measures, BUND suggested that the federal government should immediately provide funds for ecologically sustainable renaturation measures through the state governments. Ecological flood protection should not be limited to large rivers but should also include smaller watercourses to significantly reduce flood damage in the future. Various associations and organizations called for donations for those affected. Aktion Deutschland Hilft, the alliance of all major German aid organizations, launched a donation campaign for the flood victims. According to the German Hotel and Restaurant Association (DEHOGA), some tourists canceled bookings in unaffected parts of the country because, for example, the entire Rhineland-Palatinate was considered a disaster area. However, some businesses in the affected areas, such as in the Moselle Valley, had already reopened. DEHOGA President Gereon Haumann, however, assumed that in the severely affected district of Ahrweiler, almost no guests could be served or accommodated within the next twelve months. To address the damage caused by the July floods, particularly in Rhineland-Palatinate and North Rhine-Westphalia, a special fund "Reconstruction Aid 2021" was established with the Reconstruction Aid Fund Establishment Act 2021 of September 10, 2021 (BGBl. I p. 4147). In addition, the obligation to file for insolvency in the affected areas was suspended by the Act on the Temporary Suspension of the Obligation to File for Insolvency Due to Heavy Rainfall and Floods in July 2021 (BGBl. I p. 4147, 4149). The reconstruction fund is established as a special fund of the federal government and is equipped with up to 30 billion euros by the federal government. The states will then share in the repayment by transferring shares of VAT revenue to the federal government until 2050. The money is intended to benefit affected private households, businesses, and other institutions, as well as to restore infrastructure. The reconstruction of federal infrastructure, such as federal highways, will be separately financed by the federal government.

On July 16, Grand Duke Henri, together with Interior Minister Taina Bofferding and the head of the Grand Ducal Fire and Rescue Corps, Paul Schroeder, visited the areas affected by the flooding in Vianden and Echternach and spoke with both the local mayors and residents of the communities. Companies affected by the storms on July 14 and 15 can, according to the Ministry and the Ministry of Labor and Economy, apply for short-time work online from July 27 to 31. According to the Luxembourg Sport Fishing Federation (FLPS), there have been fish die-offs in many places after the flooding, as aquatic animals could no longer find their way to streams and rivers.

Whole_Text.header: Other countries of the European Union
Whole_Text.content: France, Italy, and Austria offered Belgium help through rescue teams. France sent support to Belgium. Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki offered help to Germany and Belgium on July 17, while President Andrzej Duda had already expressed his condolences the day before. Hungarian President János Áder and Prime Minister Viktor Orbán also offered support and help to Germany. The castle in Bratislava, Slovakia, was illuminated in the colors of the German flag as a sign of solidarity.

Federal President Guy Parmelin (SVP) visited Biel/Bienne and Lucerne and got an impression of the situation. Federal Councillor Simonetta Sommaruga (SP) got an impression of the Aare in Bern, specifically in the Matte district.

Minister Fidelis Leite Magalhães expressed East Timor's solidarity with Germany and Belgium on behalf of the government and extended his condolences to those affected. East Timor itself was hit by a flood disaster in April. Further expressions of condolences and sympathy came, among others, from Norwegian King Harald V, the President of the United States, Joe Biden, Russian President Vladimir Putin, British Prince William and his wife Duchess Kate, as well as from the Presidential Office and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Taiwan. The Tel Aviv-Jaffa City Hall was illuminated in German colors as a sign of solidarity. The chairman of the Turkish Red Crescent, Kerem Kınık, called on citizens of Turkish descent to support the German Red Cross.

Various associations and organizations called for donations for the victims. Aktion Deutschland Hilft, the alliance of all major German aid organizations, launched a donation campaign for the flood victims. Following the disaster, private donations amounting to 631 million euros were received from Germany alone. The DGB and its member unions called for donations. ver.di set up an emergency aid program for members. The United Evangelical Mission (VEM) provided 45,000 euros as immediate aid. The money supports the emergency programs of the Evangelical Church in the Rhineland and the Evangelical Church of Westphalia. A share of 20,000 euros comes from 14 African VEM member churches in Botswana, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Cameroon, Rwanda, South Africa, and Tanzania. The Social Association of Germany is collecting donations to benefit nursing homes in the affected areas.

The European Flood Awareness System EFAS had early warnings of extreme flooding. The quality of weather forecasts has improved significantly over the past decades; thirty European countries collaborate on this within the organization EUMETSAT. In Germany, Switzerland, and Austria, there is a comprehensive network of precipitation radar stations. International experts criticized the high death toll despite the warnings. The emergency plans of some municipalities proved inadequate in the face of the severity of floods and flash floods; some were caught unprepared. EFAS issued an "extreme flood warning" at the beginning of calendar week 28. Four days before the most devastating floods, the governments of the Federal Republic of Germany and Belgium officially warned of flooding on the Rhine and Meuse. On July 14, 2021, precise forecasts and maps were sent to German authorities, indicating which districts would be affected by flooding. These included areas along the Ahr, where 133 people died due to the flooding. The German Weather Service (DWD) stated that it had forwarded the warnings to the responsible local authorities, which are in charge of any evacuations. In some municipalities, sirens were activated as a result; however, most districts no longer have sirens. In the Rheinisch-Bergischer Kreis, sirens were reportedly deliberately not activated due to concerns that the emergency number 112 would be overwhelmed with inquiries. Additionally, in Germany, DWD and BBK issued their own notifications—particularly as push messages via warning apps like NINA—including warnings of the highest danger category for the Eifel and Moselle regions. However, these notifications only reached smartphone owners who had actively installed a warning app. IT experts criticized that in Germany, the sending of text messages to all mobile phones registered in a cell (Cell Broadcast) has not yet been used to warn the population in disaster situations, even though Directive (EU) 2018/1972 (EECC Directive) has recommended the use of such "digital sirens" since 2018. Many other European countries use Cell Broadcast. In response, the Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building, and Community (BMI) commissioned the introduction of Cell Broadcast in July 2021.

Experts criticized major gaps in disaster protection and inadequate civil protection in Germany. Hydrologist Hannah Cloke from the British University of Reading made serious accusations against disaster management in Germany. The warning from the European Flood Awareness System had been in the "extreme category," which meant a danger to life. It was therefore the responsibility of the national authority to respond accordingly. With such clear information, authorities would normally prepare for evacuation. "That's how disaster risk management works," she told the Belgian weekly newspaper Politico. Cloke sees failures in Germany on several levels: there is a lack of a nationwide uniform approach to flood risks, and different flood plans are needed for various scenarios. Cloke told Politico: "I would have expected people to be evacuated – and not for so many people to die in a flood in 2021." Criticism was raised that evacuations in Germany, if at all, were carried out very late. In contrast, authorities in Belgian Liège and several at-risk locations in Luxembourg implemented precautionary evacuations. In the Ahrweiler district, District Administrator Jürgen Pföhler (CDU) was criticized for declaring the flood disaster and ordering partial evacuations far too late. The district had been repeatedly and precisely warned of the flood disaster by the responsible State Office for the Environment in Rhineland-Palatinate. For instance, the State Office for the Environment reported an expected water level of almost seven meters on July 14 at around 9:30 p.m. When Pföhler declared the disaster situation at around 11:15 p.m., houses were already being swept away by the floodwaters. In the Ahrweiler district, there were more than 130 fatalities in the flood disaster. Uwe Kirsche from the German Weather Service (DWD) told the New York Times that the warnings had reached local authorities, but the question was why they had not evacuated earlier. The cross-border flood portal (a service providing information to the public about flood situations in Germany and Switzerland) warned both online and via app about rising water levels. However, there was at least one case where the water levels predicted by the portal, which were significantly higher than the so-called 2016 centennial flood, were beyond the imagination of a responsible mayor, who believed no evacuation was necessary. This was also due to the fact that in his local community of Mayschoß, after the 2016 flood, a report on heavy rainfall and flood protection had been prepared, which assumed lower peak water levels, and the community had based its protective measures on this. The mayor of the heavily affected Trier-Land municipality, Michael Holstein (Free Voters), criticized the inadequate equipment of disaster management. The flood disaster had shown that emergency services were underfunded, he told Südwestrundfunk. In Kordel, emergency forces were only able to reach the site in sufficient numbers with the help of the Bundeswehr. Heavy equipment to clear the numerous landslides was not available in the region and only arrived in Kordel after a two-hour drive from northern Rhineland-Palatinate. Since more flood disasters are to be expected in the future, he called for more personnel and equipment for local civil protection. The evaluation of daily situation reports during the week of the flood disaster shows that the Federal Office for Civil Protection and Disaster Assistance was "apparently surprised" by the extent of the flood disaster. Westdeutscher Rundfunk applied to the Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building, and Community (BMI) for access to the documents under the Freedom of Information Act.

Criticism was also directed at the flood reporting of Westdeutscher Rundfunk (WDR). While the disaster occurred in North Rhine-Westphalia during the night, WDR broadcast a documentary about the Summer Olympics and only sporadically provided information about the flood situation for about three hours. A ticker tape was not displayed until around 1:20 a.m. Thomas Lückerath criticized this in the online magazine DWDL.de in the widely noted commentary article "Failure to Provide Assistance: WDR Abandons the West." Later, the broadcaster explained that it had been unable to broadcast from the studio in Wuppertal because it had itself been affected by the storm. At the same time, WDR admitted that the reporting had not been sufficient. RTL reporter Susanna Ohlen faced criticism because she smeared her face with mud before a live report in Bad Münstereifel. This was filmed by someone and published online.

In the NRW state parliament, the Green and SPD parliamentary groups requested a committee of inquiry to clarify whether and why the state authorities did not pass on warnings earlier and whether they provided sufficient support to the municipalities. In March 2022, text messages exchanged between Anne Spiegel, then Rhineland-Palatinate's Minister of the Environment, and her press spokesman were made public and submitted to the state parliament's 18/1 committee of inquiry on the flood disaster in Rhineland-Palatinate. They suggest that the state government did not respond in time to the flood and that the then Minister of the Environment, Spiegel, was primarily concerned with her image the morning after the flood wave. According to research by the Kölner Stadtanzeiger, it became known that the then North Rhine-Westphalian Minister of the Environment, Ursula Heinen-Esser, had mostly worked from her home office in Mallorca during the flood disaster instead of being on-site in the affected areas. Additionally, she reportedly celebrated a party there with other cabinet members, including Municipal Minister Ina Scharrenbach, for her husband's birthday. After initially rejecting calls for personal consequences following the incident, known as the "Mallorca Affair," Heinen-Esser resigned from her ministerial office on April 7, 2022, a few weeks before the state election on May 15. On October 12, 2022, Roger Lewentz announced his resignation as Rhineland-Palatinate's Minister of the Interior. The reason for his resignation was ongoing criticism related to his role during the flood disaster. Lewentz preempted a planned debate on the same topic in the state parliament plenary, which had been scheduled at the request of the opposition factions of the CDU and Free Voters. He also faced criticism due to recently revealed police videos from the night of the disaster, showing people in extreme distress. The Ministry of the Interior stated that a situation report on the situation in the Ahr Valley was sent to the situation center by email at 12:53 a.m. on July 15. However, Lewentz himself did not have the report that night. Since October 2021, a Rhineland-Palatinate committee of inquiry has been investigating the events surrounding the disaster.

In the insufficient warning of the population, the Koblenz public prosecutor's office saw the initial suspicion of negligent homicide and negligent bodily harm by omission as given and initiated investigations against the district administrator of the Ahrweiler district and a member of the crisis team who had "at least temporarily" led the operation. In a press release, it explicitly emphasized "the presumption of innocence regarding the accused in a special way."

Also influenced by the problems in alerting the population during this flood disaster, the federal government launched a siren funding program in 2021. The dismantling of numerous sirens and other civil protection facilities after the end of the Cold War proved disadvantageous for comprehensive alerting of the population to dangers. Therefore, municipalities and districts are granted support of up to 10,850 euros per new siren built on a building or per upgrade of an existing siren on a building, and even more for sirens mounted on specially constructed masts. By April 2022, the federal government had already invested 88 million euros in replacing dismantled sirens from recent decades or modernizing still existing ones. However, this campaign only supports electronic sirens, not motor sirens. According to a report by WDR, the Cologne district government has designated a new area for the Erft where flooding is to be expected. This is based on observations from the flood event and computer simulations. It has been significantly expanded compared to the previous area, which proved necessary as the actual flow of the Erft at the Bliesheim gauge was approximately 520 m³/s, about five times the previously assumed worst-case scenario of 100 m³/s.

Whole_Text.header: Failure of the promised quick and unbureaucratic assistance
Whole_Text.content: After the flood, federal and state politicians promised quick and unbureaucratic financial aid, but since there was a lack of experts who could properly justify the applications for such financial aid, the flood victims had to deal with the complicated applications on their own without professional support.

As of 2023, it was criticized that in many places the protection against future flood events was once again being neglected. Instead, due to financial and legislative obstacles, reconstruction was primarily taking place at the same vulnerable locations, rather than better considering the risk situation. Overall, the focus was mainly on damage repair, not on forward-looking and climate-resilient construction that could mitigate future disasters.

After the floods, concerns arose about an increase in the number of COVID-19 infections in the affected regions, not least against the backdrop of the collapsed medical infrastructure; for example, numerous general practitioner practices have been destroyed. Furthermore, the risk of infection also increases in connection with relief efforts and accommodations in emergency shelters, as many people are brought together in close proximity. To reduce the risk, the Ministry of Health of Rhineland-Palatinate initiated a special vaccination campaign in the affected districts.

In Germany, during the floods, actors from the "Querdenker" groups as well as neo-Nazis presenting themselves as bourgeois attempted to win over those affected by the floods for their goals and to establish structures outside the democratic constitutional order. One documented method was disinformation about state aid measures combined with their own aid offers for flood victims. Through social media, attempts were made to sow doubt about health preventive measures, aid offers from state authorities, and aid organizations. Conspiracy theorist Bodo Schiffmann and other individuals from the "Querdenker" scene called for donations to their own bank accounts. It is unclear to what extent the money collected by Schiffmann was actually paid out to flood victims. Schiffmann allegedly collected 600,000 euros but then devised conditions for disbursement, such as ending the alleged discrimination against opponents of masks and vaccinations. He also stated that he would only pay funds to construction companies that advertised for a "Querdenker" demonstration in Berlin or cooperated with the "Querdenker" in other ways. Donations collected by him were rejected by both the mayors and the first responders in the public eye. Reiner Fuellmich (Bundestag candidate for dieBasis), Attila Hildmann, and Michael Wendler considered or claimed that a weather weapon (including the HAARP conspiracy theory) or geoengineering had been used to deliberately create an emergency and gain political profit from it. Nikolai Nerling broadcast videos from the affected Bad Neuenahr-Ahrweiler and stated that it was "great" that emergency services like THW and the fire department had not yet been able to reach all affected areas, as this would "finally lead to self-responsibility" and show that the "BRD organizations" were not needed at all. Together with a retired colonel under observation by the Office for the Protection of the Constitution and other activists, Nerling set up a relief center in Ahrweiler, used police-like vehicles, and called on reservists via the internet with an official-looking deployment order to come to the affected areas. Due to suspicion of impersonation of authority, the Koblenz police initiated proceedings against the colonel and warned against vehicles with loudspeakers resembling police vehicles. The police-like vehicles, also used at several "Querdenker" demonstrations, spread false information via loudspeakers that police and rescue forces were withdrawing from the flood regions. The flood crisis team in Rhineland-Palatinate also warned against Nerling's donation appeal. In the Ahrweiler district, the association "Eltern stehen auf" set up a so-called "family center" to relieve victims of the flood disaster. The association opposes protective masks, corona tests in schools, and vaccinations. The activists claimed that 50 therapists and counselors were supposed to take care of the children. The Rhineland-Palatinate State Youth Office closed the facility. The Ahrweiler district also tried to stop the activities and pointed out that the association's claim that it had been officially commissioned to care for the youth was false. According to the vice president of the THW, Sabine Lackner, emergency workers were partially insulted, and vehicles were pelted with garbage. The vice president further stated that the incidents had not been reported. Since many helpers were filmed by "Querdenker," the THW allowed its helpers to remove their name tags during operations.

After the total damage amount of the flood disaster across Germany was estimated at approximately 7 billion euros for insurance companies by the German Insurance Association (GDV) in August 2021, according to GDV data from May 2022, insurance damages of 5.5 billion euros were caused in North Rhine-Westphalia alone by the 2021 storms. This value has never been reached before and is also the highest compared to other federal states. As a consequence of the damages, the GDV is calling for a construction ban in areas at risk of flooding. According to the association, a mandatory natural hazard insurance does not provide an incentive for private individuals or municipalities to focus on specific flood protection for buildings and climate protection. This view was supported by environmental protection organizations. According to Munich Re in January 2022, the flood in Germany, with a total damage of approximately 46 billion euros, was the second most expensive natural disaster ever. Munich Re also sees a connection with climate change and calls for better protective measures.

Article_Name: Desastres naturais no Rio de Janeiro em março–abril de 2022 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Natural disasters in Rio de Janeiro in March–April 2022
Whole_Text.content: The natural disasters in Rio de Janeiro in March–April 2022 refer to the various climatic events that occurred in the state of Rio de Janeiro, which began on Thursday, March 31.

A cold front that collided with warmer air was the cause of the intense storms. The rains began in the early evening of March 31. In the Guaratiba neighborhood, located in the west zone of Rio de Janeiro, 256 mm of rain was recorded in the 24 hours between March 31 and April 1, the highest level since 2019. The heavy rains put the city on alert, which is the fourth level on a five-level scale. There were several floods throughout the city, including in historically susceptible areas such as Praça da Bandeira, Avenida Maracanã in the North Zone; the neighborhoods of Catete and Laranjeiras in the South Zone, and the Rio das Pedras region in the West Zone. The floods were also exacerbated by the excess of garbage on the streets and sidewalks. Comlurb employees had gone on strike days before the storm. Due to the event, the strike was temporarily suspended so that the capital could be cleaned again, but as soon as the rains stopped, they resumed the strike. In the Costa Verde region, the heaviest rains occurred during the night of April 1 and the early hours of April 2, causing floods and several landslides. In 48 hours, between March 31 and April 2, Paraty recorded 300 mm of rain. The city was isolated due to landslides on the Rio-Santos Highway and RJ-155, the only access routes to the municipality, but they were partially or fully cleared after the arrival of Brazilian Army officials. Meanwhile, the city of Angra dos Reis recorded 655 mm on the mainland and 592 mm on Ilha Grande, the highest levels ever recorded in history. The cities are collecting donations for the areas affected by the storm, and the Federal Government announced a minimum contribution of R$ 2.7 million to the two locations. In Baixada Fluminense, there was also a high rainfall index, with records above 200 mm in the city of Belford Roxo and 156 mm in Nova Iguaçu. The high volume of rain caused many floods in the cities.

The heavy storms left at least 21 people dead and 3 missing. In Paraty, eight people from the same family were victims of landslides, while in Angra dos Reis, eleven people died. In Mesquita, in Baixada Fluminense, a man died after being struck by an electric discharge, and in Cachoeiras de Macacu, a woman died after being swept away by a current.
The 2022 Ankara flood — A flood that began on June 7, 2022, in Ankara, the capital of Turkey. A total of 5 people lost their lives in the flood that occurred after heavy rainfall.

After the heavy rain and hail that started on June 7, 2022, floods occurred in Ankara. Many homes and workplaces were submerged, and cars were stranded on the roads. For this reason, Ankara Governor Vasip Şahin announced that the education process in Ankara was suspended for one day. On June 13, 2022, the Minister of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Turkey, Süleyman Soylu, and the Mayor of Ankara Metropolitan Municipality, Mansur Yavaş, held a meeting regarding the natural disaster. The floods became a topic of discussion in the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality council. On July 1, 2022, the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality announced that they received an average of 20 kg of precipitation per hour, conducted 15 rescue operations, and intervened in 1,024 incidents. A total of 5 people lost their lives as a result of the floods that occurred from June 7 to July 2.

It has been claimed that the floods stem from the density of landscaping works and the unplanned covering of valleys. It has been noted that the valleys opened for landscaping works cause floods during every heavy rain.

Whole_Text.content: Italy Floods 2022 On the nights of September 15-16, 2022, Marche in Italy experienced a storm that caused one of the worst flash floods in the region's history. A series of heavy rains led to more than 420 mm (20 inches) of rainfall within two hours. The flood resulted in the death of 10 people, while 4 remain missing.

The spokesperson for the head of the Civil Defense Department said, "According to the local administration, we have an initial toll indicating 7 dead." Meanwhile, the Italian news agency ANSA reported that the Civil Protection stated the victims died in three towns in the Ancona province in the Marche region in central Italy, and that three other people are missing. Italian authorities stated that three people, including a six-year-old child who was with his mother in the car, are unaccounted for. Firefighters rescued the mother, but the strong water current swept the child away, according to the Italian Press Agency.

Whole_Text.content: In October and November 1840, major floods occurred in the Rhône basin. These, along with those of May 1856, were the worst floods in the Rhône basin of the 19th century. More than two thousand houses were destroyed along the Rhône and its tributaries, including the Saône.

The summer of 1840 was fairly dry, but in September it began to rain. This caused a first, small flood on the Saône. From October 19, it rained continuously, and the rains became heavier towards the end of the month. As a result, the ground was completely saturated. Between October 27 and 30, a warm southern wind brought heavy rainfall. Due to the warm weather, the snow in the Jura melted.

At the end of October, rivers in the upper reaches of the Saône overflowed their banks: the Seille, Reyssouze, Veyle, Chalaronne, and Azergues. This also caused flooding in the Doubs and the Saône. The floodplain downstream of Chalon-sur-Saône was submerged. At the beginning of November, new downpours in the upper reaches of the Saône caused the tributaries Azergues and Turdines to overflow. Between Chalon-sur-Saône and the mouth of the Saône in Lyon, the river reached record heights. On the night of November 1 to 2, the Saône overflowed in Mâcon. Half of the city was submerged, and the gas lighting failed, plunging the entire city into darkness. Twenty kilometers further south, Thoissey, at the confluence of the Chalaronne and the Saône, flooded, and 125 houses were lost. Lyon was severely affected. As early as October 30, the Rhône there nearly reached the level of the 1812 flood. On October 31, at 2 a.m., the earthen dike on the Rhône, built in 1837, broke. The water flooded the 6th arrondissement of Lyon and caused several houses to collapse. The water reached a level 35 cm higher than during the previous major flood of 1812. On the night of November 3 to 4, the Saône also overflowed near Lyon, submerging the lower streets by one to one and a half meters. Several bridges on the Saône were damaged or destroyed by the water. It was not until November 5 that the water level in Lyon began to recede. Downstream of Lyon, there were floods along both banks of the Rhône. In Givors, the Rhône and the Giers overflowed, submerging the lower parts of the city by up to a meter. Thirty houses collapsed, the canal banks were damaged, and factories were rendered inoperative. In Vienne, the Gère overflowed. Tain, Valence, and Avignon also experienced flooding. In the latter city, the flooding began on October 29, after the Rhône had been at a low level two days earlier following a long period of drought. The water level continued to rise, reaching a record height on November 2, higher than that of the 1755 flood. Downstream, the agricultural area around the confluence of the Durance and the Rhône was completely submerged. Tarascon and Beaucaire were entirely underwater.

On November 3, 1840, the Rhône had a flow rate of 5,500 m³/s in Givors, 9,500 m³/s in Le Teil, and 13,000 m³/s in Beaucaire. The Durance also had a record flow rate of 3,000 m³/s at Pont-Mirabeau. These values were only approached or exceeded in 1856. For the Saône, the 1840 flood remains the largest in recorded history. For the Rhône, upstream of Lyon, the floods of 1927, 1944, or 1990 (depending on the location) are notable. Downstream of Lyon, it is the flood of 1856.

A persistent, strong south wind caused waves in the flooded areas. This contributed to the destruction of buildings and made rescue efforts more difficult. Moreover, many houses were made of unbaked earth (pisé), which made them collapse more easily. In total, more than 2,000 houses were destroyed by the water. In the department of Saône-et-Loire, 400 houses were destroyed, and in Ain nearly 1,000. Several people lost their lives. When the water finally receded downstream from Avignon on November 20, it left behind a barren layer of sand and stones one meter thick.

The Vaia storm was an extreme meteorological event that affected northeastern Italy (particularly the mountainous area of the Dolomites and the Venetian Prealps) from October 26 to 30, 2018. The event originated from an Atlantic disturbance which, as part of a severe wave of bad weather over Italy (also affecting the neighboring regions of Switzerland, Austria, and Slovenia), brought the region extremely strong winds and persistent rains. The event is erroneously referred to as a "storm" (grade 10 on the Beaufort scale), but the winds reached "hurricane" speeds (grade 12), winds that commonly originate only over tropical or subtropical waters of the planet. The extremely strong warm sirocco wind, blowing between 100 and 200 km/h for several hours, caused the fall of millions of trees, resulting in the destruction of tens of thousands of hectares of alpine conifer forests, thus constituting a true natural disaster: the Crisis Unit activated by the Veneto Region classified the event as worse than the Venice flood of November 4, 1966 (which nonetheless affected the entire region), the Veneto flood of 2010, and other previous meteorological events recorded in the area.

At 2:00 PM on October 26, the civil protection of the Veneto Region decided to issue a red alert for part of the regional hydrogeological network. In particular, there was concern about the situation in the Taibon area, where a large fire (the most significant recorded in Veneto in recent decades), which broke out on October 24, had burned about 650 hectares of forest, compromising the stability of the terrain. Then, on October 28, following weather updates, the red alert for high hydraulic and hydrogeological risk was extended to almost the entire Veneto region.

They fell to the ground in just three days (October 27, 28, and 29) in the mountainous areas of Veneto and Trentino, with up to 715.8 mm of rain recorded at the monitoring station in Soffranco (Longarone), surpassing the data from 1966, and as much as 870 mm in Forni di Sotto in the Carnic Prealps in Friuli. For several stations in the Belluno area, the amount of rain that fell during the event set an absolute record since the Regional Agency for Environmental Protection began rainfall monitoring in the territory (since 1992). The flood affected some municipalities in Veneto, Trentino, and Friuli, as well as Lombardy. The most affected areas were Agordino, Cadore, Feltrino, Comelico, Carnia, Val di Fassa, and Val di Fiemme. The heavy and abundant rains caused the Piave and Brenta rivers to overflow, while to prevent the Adige River from overflowing, the Adige-Garda tunnel was opened. In the mountainous environment, several streams overflowed, and there were numerous landslides. The Alleghe Lake also overflowed.

The sirocco wind reached gusts of 192.24 km/h in Veneto on October 29 (instantaneous value reported at 10 m above ground) recorded by the Arpa station on Mount Cesen and 166.68 km/h by the homologous station on Mount Verena, while in Carnia, gusts reached 200 km/h and 170 km/h respectively at the Osmer stations of Cima Rest and Col Gallina (Polcenigo). In Trentino, at Passo Rolle, the wind reached 217.3 km/h. The extremely strong gusts, comparable according to mountaineer Reinhold Messner to winds recorded on Mount Everest (with very intense average winds often exceeding the highest values of the Beaufort scale, between "violent storm" and "hurricane"), caused the destruction of numerous trees and, in several cases, the felling of entire forests. The areas most affected by the wind were the Altopiano dei Sette Comuni (especially Val d'Assa and Piana di Marcesina), Val Visdende, Agordino (Alleghe, Canale d'Agordo with Valle di Gares, Colle Santa Lucia, Falcade with Valle del Biois, Rocca Pietore, and the entire Valle di San Lucano in Taibon Agordino), the area surrounding Lake Carezza, the Valli di Fassa and Fiemme (particularly Paneveggio), and the Altopiano di Piné, as well as various areas of the Lagorai mountain range. Part of the Lombardy region (especially Valcamonica) was also affected by the events, with the most impacted areas being Passo Crocedomini in the municipality of Bienno and the municipalities of Paspardo and Cimbergo, as well as several areas in the municipalities of Sonico and Ponte di Legno. In particular, due to the uprooting of numerous trees along power lines and the collapse of pylons, there were significant disruptions to the electricity distribution across the mountainous areas of Triveneto. By October 30, Terna, Enel, and SET Distribuzione had managed with difficulty to restore power to 200,000 users in Veneto and Friuli, but by October 31, there were still 10,000 users without electricity in Carnia, 3,000 in eastern Trentino (Val di Fiemme and Val di Fassa), and 8,600 in the Vicenza area (particularly on the Altopiano dei Sette Comuni).

Still in the context of this storm, on October 29, two exceptional high tide events occurred that affected the historic center of Venice: the first peaked at 156 cm at 2:40 PM[23][24], while the second, caused by a thunderstorm accompanied by strong winds, peaked at 148 cm at 8:25 PM.[24] The maximum meteorological contribution (or residual) reached values comparable to or slightly lower than the extraordinary event of 1966, measuring almost 160 cm of residual. The minimum tide level turned out to be the highest in Venetian history at +119 cm.

The final estimate of damages in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, according to the regional civil protection, amounts to 615 million euros. In Veneto (the most affected region), damages were estimated at 1.769 billion euros, while estimates for Trentino are around 250-300 million euros and 85.4 million in Alto Adige. In Lombardy, estimates are around 40 million euros in damages. Regarding forests, due to the wind, an estimated 14 million trees were felled (a figure never recorded in recent times in Italy) over an area of 41,000 hectares. In Lombardy, the damaged forested areas were identified by the Region through photo interpretation of images from the European Union's Sentinel satellite and are viewable on the Geoportal of Lombardy.

Article_Name: Powódź w Gdańsku (2001) – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: Poland Gdańsk flood July 9, 2001 4[1][2] The 2001 Gdańsk flood (also: the flood of the century[1]) – a flood with four fatalities in Gdańsk, which took place on July 9, 2001, as part of the July floods in Poland that year.

In July 2001, a series of floods occurred in the Vistula River Basin, caused by weather anomalies in the form of torrential rains. The daily rainfall totals often exceeded the monthly average for July. This caused significant damage to hydrotechnical infrastructure (so-called flash floods). Gdańsk is located at the junction of several geographical mesoregions. The western part of the city (the so-called Upper Terrace) is situated on the hilly Kashubian Lake District, while the rest of the city (the so-called Lower Terrace) lies on the lowlands – the Kashubian Coastal Plain and the Vistula Delta, where there are areas below sea level. The highest point in Gdańsk is 180 meters above sea level, and the lowest is 1.6 meters below sea level, with a significant part of the city in the Vistula Delta located at around 0 meters above sea level. On Monday, July 9, 2001, around 3:00 PM, torrential rains began in Gdańsk. Within two hours, 90 mm of rain per square meter (90 liters) fell, while the average monthly rainfall for July in Gdańsk was 75 mm/m². A total of 128 liters of rain per square meter fell that day. The rainfall caused the Strzyża stream and the Radunia Canal to overflow due to failures in hydrotechnical infrastructure – breaches in the embankments in several places. The destruction was compounded by water flowing down the streets from the hilly parts of the city. One of the indirect causes of the flood is often cited as the intensive development of construction on the Upper Terrace of the city, which has been ongoing since the 1980s, and the resulting reduction in local rainwater retention. City authorities disagree with this claim, pointing primarily to the extreme nature of the weather events.

Through the Orunia-Św. Wojciech-Lipce district, located in the southern part of the city, runs the Radunia Canal in a meridional direction – a hydrotechnical monument from the 14th century, in the form of an artificial cut of the Radunia River, leading from Pruszcz Gdański to the Motława in the Old Town. The canal runs along the border of the Kaszubian Lake District and the Vistula Delta mesoregions. It collects water originating from the western, higher parts of the city (e.g., the Oruński Stream). On the eastern, lowland side, the canal is surrounded by a wide flood embankment. The maximum capacity of the Radunia Canal was then estimated at 25 m³/sec. As a result of torrential rain, and consequently the excessive inflow of water into the canal from the upper part of the city, the water flow in the Radunia Canal was five times greater than its capacity, reaching 125 m³/sec. This resulted in the breach of the flood embankment in five places. Additionally, the upper pond in Oruński Park, located above the Radunia Canal, overflowed, breaking its dam. South of Święty Wojciech, near the border with Pruszcz Gdański, the canal embankment was deliberately breached to divert water into the Radunia River, which flows parallel at that point. Most of the district on the eastern side of the Radunia Canal was submerged (for comparison, the district had 16,000 residents in 2010). In some places, the water reached as high as the first floor. The agricultural part of the district – Niegowo – was also flooded.
Water flowing down, among others, Kartuska Street and Nowe Ogrody flooded the Gdańsk Main Station, the city hall, and the voivodeship office.

The Strzyża stream flows through Wrzeszcz, originating in the hills above the Tricity Landscape Park. It flows into the Dead Vistula[19]. Due to rainfall, Strzyża overflowed its banks[1]. Additionally, the embankment of the Srebrzysko retention reservoir was breached. Part of the district along Słowackiego Street, from Potokowa Street to Grunwaldzka Avenue, was submerged[12].

As a result of the flood, 4 people died. Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek arrived at the scene. The Trakt św. Wojciecha street, running along the Radunia Canal and at the time part of national road No. 1, remained impassable for 18 days. The Warsaw-Gdańsk railway line was undermined, resulting in the suspension of train traffic for several days. Material losses (excluding private property) were estimated at 200 million PLN. 2,000 people were evacuated, 1,200 residential units required renovation, and 600 needed reconstruction. Many historic buildings were demolished. Due to the damage, 134 buildings were dismantled. Between 2001 and 2005, 41 million PLN was spent on addressing the housing-related consequences of the flood. The events initiated a series of investments in flood protection infrastructure in Gdańsk. Dozens of retention reservoirs were built on watercourses flowing from the city's Upper Terrace, along with several stormwater pumping stations. The restoration of Orunia Park from the flood damage lasted until 2009. Within a decade of the flood, the city of Gdańsk spent 150 million PLN on flood protection measures. Between 2011 and 2014, the Radunia Canal was revitalized at a cost of 133 million PLN. As part of this investment, a Larsen wall was installed inside the flood embankment.

Article_Name: Riada del Tamarguillo de 1961, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Tamarguillo flood of 1961 was the last of the major floods in Seville and one of the largest suffered by the city in its recent history. A third of the urban core was flooded due to the breach of the Tamarguillo stream's defense wall.

The Tamarguillo is a stream that originates in the elevation of Los Alcores a few kilometers from Seville, and its course and mouth have been modified by humans on several occasions over the last century and a half to protect the city from its overflow. In 1961, when the flood occurred, the Tamarguillo entered the city through what is now the Tamarguillo Park, collected the waters of another stream, the Tagarete, ran through the city along the Tamarguillo Ring Road, and flowed into the Guadaira River.

On November 16, 1961, heavy rainfall began in the southern region of Spain and continued in the following days. Due to the rising water levels of the Tamarguillo stream and in anticipation of flooding, numerous homes in the northern area of Seville were evacuated. On the morning of November 25, the water began to overflow the channel and erode the walls of the earthen embankment that served as a defense.

Around 3:45 PM on November 25, a partial breach occurred in the protective wall of the Tamarguillo stream at a location between the Carmona road and the current Kansas City Avenue, approximately near the Rafael Gordillo roundabout and very close to the La Corza neighborhood, which was the first area affected by the flood. This breach widened to about 50 meters. This initial breach was followed by two smaller ones, a few hours later, on the other side of the Carmona road. The first waters quickly reached the neighborhoods of La Corza, El Fontanal, Árbol Gordo, San José Obrero, Miraflores, and the entire northern part of the city from the Ronda de Capuchinos. Independently of this point, that same day, two other critical points emerged further south in the city. The first was caused by the overflow of the same Tamarguillo in an area near the Su Eminencia road, whose waters reached Cerro del Águila, Prado de San Sebastián, and María Luisa Park. The second occurred as a result of the overflow of the Guadaira River, with its waters merging with those of the Tamarguillo in María Luisa Park and reaching the Puerta de Jerez. During the night, an old Guadalquivir riverbed that ran from the Alameda de Hércules and La Campana to Plaza Nueva was flooded, with a maximum water level of three meters in the Alameda. On the morning of November 26, the flooding of the city reached its maximum extent. On Monday, the 27th, water levels began to slightly decrease, and by Tuesday, the improvement was noticeable, revealing the damage caused by the water. That afternoon, the main breach in the Tamarguillo was sealed. No official end date for the Tamarguillo flood was given, but as of November 30, water still remained in some neighborhoods. It has been estimated that the approximate volume of water that flooded the capital was 4,000,000 m³, reaching a height of three to four meters in the most affected areas. According to official figures, the flooded area was 552 hectares, one-third of the total city, and affected 150,000 residents to varying degrees. More recent investigations have increased the number of affected hectares to 3,448, a surface area about six times larger than the official data.

Operation Clavel was a relief campaign for those affected by the November 1961 floods, organized by Manuel Zuasti, director of the Radio España station, and the popular journalist Bobby Deglané. It culminated in a large caravan of 142 trucks, 150 cars, and 82 motorcycles carrying food, supplies, and toys for the victims. It departed from Madrid on December 18 and arrived in Seville the following day amid great anticipation.  
As it entered the city, a small plane accompanying the caravan became entangled with high-voltage cables and crashed into the large crowd waiting for its passage. The accident resulted in twenty fatalities and over one hundred injuries.

Whole_Text.header: Liver region wind and water damage
Whole_Text.content: The Kimosuki Region Wind and Water Disaster (Kimosuki Chihou Fuusuigai) was a flood caused by a typhoon that occurred in Kagoshima Prefecture in October of Showa 13 (1938). It occurred in the Kimosuki River on the Kimosuki Peninsula (Osumi Peninsula). It is also referred to as the "Kimosuki Flood" or the "Kimosuki River Flood."

On October 8, 1938, a typhoon formed east of the Philippines[1]. At 6 p.m. on the 14th, it passed over the sea west of Yakushima[1]. Around 2 a.m. on the 15th, the center of the typhoon reached Yakushima[1]. At 6 a.m. on the 15th, it passed northeastward from the eastern coast of Tanegashima[1]. The typhoon dissipated west of Hachijojima on the 16th[1]. According to records from the Yakushima Rainfall Observation Station, the lowest pressure was 730.2 mmHg (973.52 hPa) at 2 a.m. on the 15th, and the strongest wind speed was 33 meters per second at 3 a.m.[1].

When passing through Yakushima and Tanegashima between October 14 and 15, the speed was 10 to 15 kilometers per hour [1]. During the night of the 14th, over 400 millimeters of heavy rain concentrated locally in a short period, causing problems [1], and the southern part of the Osumi Peninsula recorded over 400 millimeters of rainfall in 24 hours [6]. At the Kanoya Observatory, the daily rainfall was 389 millimeters, and at the Takayama Observatory, it was 400 millimeters [2]. Significant damage occurred, including the collapse of 10 levees in the Kimotsuki River system [6][1]. The areas most severely affected were Takayama Town, Aira Village, and Uchinoura Town [1]. According to Kagoshima University, there were 310 deaths, 125 missing persons, totaling 435 victims, and 629 seriously injured [1]. However, according to the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, there were 304 deaths, 131 missing persons, and 628 injured [2]. Kagoshima University reported 1,969 completely destroyed houses, 1,397 partially destroyed houses, and 10,568 flooded houses [1], while the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism reported 1,532 destroyed and partially destroyed houses and 5,067 flooded houses [2]. The total damage amounted to approximately 36 million yen at the time, with about 20 million yen related to agriculture [1]. At Tashiro Elementary School in Kinko Town, a landslide from the hillside destroyed the wooden school building [6], resulting in the deaths of two staff members [6]. In Aira Town, Kanoya City, flooding occurred, and bodies were recovered at the rescue headquarters [6].

The area with the most casualties was the Takayama district in Kimotsuki Town. According to Teru Iwamatsu, an emeritus professor at Kagoshima University, in the Takayama district, "the mountain collapsed, turning into a debris flow that surged downstream, causing flooding and overflowing." During the Heisei era, a "monument to convey the damage" and the "Takayama River Flood Disaster History Monument" were constructed. According to the inscription on the monument, from October 14 to 15, a total rainfall of 420 millimeters in Takayama Town caused a mountain tsunami, resulting in 118 deaths, 53 missing persons, and 253 seriously injured individuals. The massive floodwaters surged like a tide, making it impossible to prevent the disaster. Houses that were inundated became completely submerged, forcing people to evacuate to rooftops, but some were swept downstream.

On the morning of October 15, information about the damage was conveyed to the prefectural office, but the details were not well understood. However, due to the unprecedented nature of the situation, a relief and rescue headquarters was established at the prefectural office, and a branch office was set up in Kanoya Town. A medical relief team was formed with members from the Kagoshima Prefectural Hospital and the Prefectural Medical Association. On the same day, a maritime team was dispatched to Uchinoura on the police vessel "Asahi Sakura," accompanied by the medical relief team. A land team was dispatched to Kanoya. After the situation became clear, the 45th Infantry Regiment from Kagoshima was deployed on the 20th, and the Kumamoto Engineering Corps was deployed on the 21st. The funding was covered by national subsidies, the prefecture's recovery and reconstruction project budget, and donations collected from across the country. River improvement by the national government had begun in 1937, the year before the flood, but it was fully implemented after the disaster. The river improvement included straightening the meandering Kimotsuki River and constructing embankments. According to the Osumi River and National Highway Office, it is believed that flooding would not occur even if rainfall of the same scale were to happen again. However, during Typhoon No. 24 in 2018, tributaries temporarily exceeded the flood danger level, indicating that situations beyond expectations are possible.
